PETITION.TITLE: El Salvador: Military Aid
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens and residents of Australia humbly pray that:
1. The Parliament heeds our profound concern regarding the penal code reforms of the ARENA Government in El Salvador.

2. We request that as these reforms breach the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, and in consideration of the escalation of human rights violations by El Salvadoran armed forces, the Australian Government convey to the United States that all forms of military aid to the Salvadoran Government should be suspended.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Company Tax Collection System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Government's Budget decision to change the company tax collection system will be a crippling blow to many small businesses, already suffering as a direct result of the Hawke Labor Government's high interest rate policy.
The earlier remittance of company tax payments to the Government will substantially reduce the cash-flow position of thousands of small businesses.

Many small businesses will be driven under as a result of the Government's decision-unable to find funds for both tax commitments and new stock, only able to borrow at record high interest rates and unable to claim any tax relief on such borrowings to meet their tax commitment.
The Government's proposed changes to the company tax collection system has only been introduced as a greedy grab for more tax revenue.

The small business community would prefer the Government to completely abandon the proposal rather than make only minor alterations to the original Budget decision, which are not likely to alleviate the situation to any significant extent.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam: Buddhist Leaders
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House:
That the Australian Parliament expresses its repugnance that the Socialist Republic of Vietnam has kept imprisoned 47 Buddhist leaders since 1984.

And further, that the regime in Vietnam has recently tried and sentenced to death Thich Tri Sieu and Thich Tue Sy, two distinguished scholars from amongst the 47. Both of these religious academics are intellectuals of the highest order, being scholars in Buddhist scripture.

Your petitioners therefore request the House to denounce the intentions of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam and to call on the Vietnamese Government for clemency and a remission of the death sentence as being barbaric.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth.

The proposed cuts in funding to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme will have serious effects on the viability of many family chemists, leading to increased charges and reduction in services and availability of medicines to the community.
We therefore call on the Federal Government to reject the findings of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal and maintain the level of funding existing prior to the Tribunal's findings.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners request that the Australian Government take steps immediately to stop the mining and export of uranium.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the following Bill be introduced: A Bill for an Act to amend the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 to improve the promptness with which undertakings given to the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances are implemented.
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
I commend the work of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. This is an important part of the work of the Senate, which is not often recognised.

However, there is a real concern that-very often-undertakings given to the Committee have not been honoured, in particular, promises to amend particular items of delegated legislation which are deficient or poorly drafted.

Ministers make promises which are based on the advice of public servants. These promises may be made in good faith. But in some cases the advisers have no intention of delivering on the undertakings which they persuade their Ministers to give. I believe that these advisers are simply relying on the terrifying workload of Ministers. Undertakings will be superseded by other pressing matters, and forgotten.
In such situations the Senate is powerless. Even the most conscientious of Ministers-considering their workload-is tempted to treat the matter as water under the bridge.
I have consulted a number of honourable senators, and I believe that the approach set out in the Bill represents a consensus of all Parties.

In essence, the Bill provides that where an undertaking is given but not subsequently honoured, the delegated legislation in question comes before the Senate again, as if for the first time. This means that the Senate again has the power of disallowance which it had the first time.
This renewed sanction should concentrate the minds of those who advise Ministers to give such undertakings.
I believe all senators will welcome this Bill, which gives the Senate the power to ensure that promises made are promises kept.

MARINE NAVIGATION LEVY BILL 1989
The purpose of this Bill is to alter the basis of calculating the method of charging commercial shipowners for the navigational services provided to them by the Commonwealth.

The Bill will also transfer the authority to raise the necessary revenue from the Lighthouses Act 1911 to a Levy Act and its associated Collection Act. This will remove any doubt that may exist as to the constitutional validity of light dues as a method of cost recovery.

Since 1915, the Commonwealth has operated an extensive network of marine navigational aids around the coast of Australia, to facilitate the safe and economic navigation of vessels engaged in trade and commerce.

This network, which presently numbers some 387 navigational aids costing about $39 million per year, is fully financed by light dues paid by commercial shipping engaged on both overseas and coastal trading.
The rate of light dues is 53 cents per net registered ton of the vessel per quarter. The rate is the same regardless of the flag of the vessel or the trade engaged upon.
Through the efficient rationalisation of the system and the effective use of modern technology, the rate of light dues has not been increased since October 1983.

This represents a considerable reduction in real costs to the shipping industry. It has been achieved despite some significant investment in recent years, including in Hydrographers Passage in the Great Barrier Reef and on the North West coast of Australia. These investments have been primarily for the benefit of the bulk export trade in those areas.

The commercial shipping industry is closely consulted on all matters relating to the operations of the navigational aids network through the Maritime Services Advisory Committee on Navigational Safety. There are representatives of both foreign and Australian flag shipowners on this committee.

In recent years, the increasing complexity and variety of navigational services and aids provided to ships, and the increasing disparity between the ships themselves and the trades on which they are engaged, have thrown considerable doubt on the validity of the traditional charging methods.
Two years ago, therefore, the government initiated an examination of the basis of charging light dues.
The new rates of levy contained in the Levy Bill now before the House result from that examination.

Although various alternative methods of charging were considered, no practicable method of charging in terms of cargo values or use of individual aids was discovered. A levy based on the net tonnage of a ship was found to be the fairest of the practicable methods.
It was considered that some variation in the formula for setting dues might be feasible and consultations were immediately started with the shipping industry.
It was also decided that the existing exemptions for naval vessels, fishing craft and private yachts should continue.

During the extensive consultations with industry groups, a wide variety of options was considered. As would be expected with such a diverse range of interests, it proved impossible to reach a full consensus on the most appropriate formula to apply.

Nevertheless, in June this year, as part of the overall reforms of maritime and waterfront activities, the Government was able to announce the new formula preferred by a clear majority of industry representatives.
Under the new formula, the rate per net ton is reduced as the ship's tonnage increases. Smaller vessels will pay slightly more but the large vessels will pay significantly reduced amounts each year.
This will be of particular benefit to the larger bulk ore carriers which carry, in terms of tonnage, the greater part of our exports.
The new levy is based on a sliding scale which ranges from 33 to 63 cents per net registered ton compared with the present 53 cents per ton and will continue to be paid each quarter.

To illustrate, a small coastal vessel of 200 tons will pay some $20 per quarter more; a vessel of 25,000 tons will pay the same as now; and a 72,000 ton vessel will pay some $6,900 per quarter less. These represent significant on-going savings to the large bulk carriers serving our export trades.
The Levy Bill imposes the levy in accordance with the formula I referred to earlier.

It also allows the rate of levy to be varied by regulation. However, to prevent the levy being increased by regulation to a level beyond that represented by reasonable cost increases, a ceiling of 15 per cent per annum has been imposed.

To summarise, Mr Speaker, this Bill and its associated Collection Bill bring up to date the method of charging for the provision by the Commonwealth of navigation aids and related navigational services. While I cannot say that every sector of the shipping community agrees wholeheartedly with the formula arrived at, I can say that it represents the best compromise that could be reached.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
MARINE NAVIGATION LEVY COLLECTION BILL 1989

This Bill sets out the administrative detail related to the collection of the proposed navigation levy. It broadly restates the provisions currently contained in the Lighthouses Act and regulations made thereunder.
Briefly, it provides for the levy to be paid quarterly to a Collector of Customs. Levy is not payable on a ship that merely calls at an Australian port for:
shelter, repairs or refitting
to take on provisions etc.
to change crew or to land a crew member for medical treatment.

The regulations may exempt ships from the levy. Regulations under the Lighthouses Act 1911 already exempt certain kinds of ships from light dues. Honourable members will find a list in the Explanatory Memorandum accompanying the Bill. It is intended that regulations under the Levy Collection Act will, at least for the time being, provide similar exemptions.

The Bill provides also for the repeal of superseded provisions of the Lighthouses Act 1911. It also does not perpetuate an archaic provision of the Lighthouses Act that permits a Collector to distrain goods and equipment aboard a ship and sell them to pay dues.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
