COMMUNITY SERVICES AND HEALTH
LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989

This Bill will amend the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954, the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Amendment Act 1989, the First Home Owners Act 1983, the Health Insurance Act 1973, the National Health Act 1953 and the Nursing Homes Assistance Act 1974.
The major purpose of this Bill is to enable the residents' rights initiatives to be implemented in nursing homes and hostels. The Bill also:
Removes the necessity for a medical certificate for nursing home admission;
Allows for back dating of domiciliary nursing care benefit in certain circumstances;
Provides for proprietors of nursing homes to be approved operators;
Provides for lodgement and processing fees for reviews of budgets or deficits of certain nursing homes; and
Includes certain minor amendments consequential to the implementation of new respite care arrangements in nursing homes.

These measures are based on the Government's social justice policy and continue the reform strategy in the aged care program with particular emphasis on ensuring access and equality, promoting equality and providing opportunities for full participation in Australian society.
The Bill also includes amendments to:
The First Home Owners Act 1983
The definitions of ``proprietor of a laboratory'' and ``officer'' of the health insurance commission
Restrict entitlement to Medicare benefits of certain diplomatic representatives
The administration of the vocational register of general practitioners
Various arrangements of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme

The major purpose of the Bill is to introduce new provisions which give effect to the rights and responsibilities of residents of Commonwealth funded aged care facilities. The Bill provides for a `charter of residents rights and responsibilities' and an agreement between a resident and a proprietor of a facility, based on the charter. The Bill strengthens the legislative provisions for preserving those rights by improving access by authorised persons to facilities, residents and staff. The Bill also seeks to make available information about the standard and general nature of services provided by a particular nursing home or hostel to enable consumers, the elderly or their friends or relatives to make informed choices about suitable care and to encourage high quality care.

In 1986 the nursing homes and hostels review recommended a major program of aged care reforms aimed at providing better quality care and a greater range of choices for frail aged people. The first four reform stages were concerned with the rational use of resources, more effective planning, equitable distribution of funding, effective assessment and equity in care provision.
The fifth state of the reform process was heralded by the release of the report Residents' Rights in Nursing Homes and Hostels in July this year.

In the minds of many people, older members of our society are seen as a group, rather than as individuals. They are often considered to be without influence and dependent on the good will of others. Consequently, they are devalued and may become even more vulnerable to harassment, threats and even physical violence. Older people are also commonly victims of a patronising approach which sees all people over a particular age as unable to make decisions and needing assistance with every task.

Many older people have accepted this negative view of themselves and have become resigned to being isolated and lonely. We must not accept this situation as inevitable. Governments have a responsibility to both enforce rights and educate and inform in relation to those rights.

Residents' Rights in Nursing Homes and Hostels was the final report of the consultant commissioned to identify the issues that concern residents of nursing homes and hostels and to examine the attitudes and approach of nursing home and hostel proprietors and staff to residents of those facilities.

Four major problems were identified in the report-residents' feeling of isolation and boredom; the lack of control that residents feel they have over their own lives; the absence of information about available services; and the fear of retribution if any complaint is made.
These problems are ones which should be of concern both to service providers and to the community in general.

I will not go through the report's recommendations in detail. Instead I will refer to the major changes flowing from the report which the Government, in the 1989/90 budget context, has announced as priority initiatives for implementation over the next four years.
The priorities in 1989-90 will be to implement:

A charter of residents' rights and responsibilities and a resident/provider agreement by 1 July 1990. The standard agreement would be implemented in respect of new residents only from 1 July 1990 and a later date will be negotiated with the industry for completion of agreements with existing residents.

The establishment in each State and Territory office of the Department of Community Services and Health of an effective unit to receive and follow-up complaints from residents or their representatives.

Commonwealth funding for independent advocacy and mediation services in each State and Territory to take up grievance issues on behalf of residents. It is likely that most will be operational in the latter part of 1989-90.

A community visitors scheme to enable residents to have greater access to their local community and to provide residents with information, support and advice. It is anticipated that the scheme will be implemented first in Queensland and Victoria from April 1990.

A comprehensive information strategy to enhance the awareness by residents, potential residents and the community generally, of care options and the key issues to be considered in choosing the right type of care.
Before action is commenced to implement these initiatives there will be extensive consultation with the industry, consumers and staff groups.
I would now like to outline the provisions in the Bill to enable the residents' rights initiatives to be implemented.

While the residents' rights report makes a large number of recommendations for change, it recognised that it is also critical to change the attitudes of our society towards the aged as well as those of consumers, staff and management. The proposed amendments to the Aged or Disabled Homes Act 1954 and the National Health Act 1953 contained in this Bill will provide the framework within which residents' rights issues can be addressed, and thus continue the process of positive change.

The Bill provides the Minister with the power to formulate a statement or charter of the rights and responsibilities of the residents of approved nursing homes and hostels. The charter is a broad statement of principle which will emphasise rights of choice, access to services, rights to independence, participation and involvement in all aspects of daily life, and access of the residents to their own records. It will also state the responsibilities that residents, as adult members of society, should meet in their daily lives, including respecting the rights of others.
The Residents' Rights report suggested that there are a number of advantages of a charter.

`A Charter provides residents with a sound basis for any negotiations with management around particular issues . . . also, it provides a sound basis for the quality of care which management are endeavouring to provide. It is a useful tool for informing residents about what they can expect in a facility and for educating new staff members on the nature and type of facilities they have jointed.'
The charter, along with the proposed agreements, will establish the concept of residents and proprietors being equal partners.

The Bill also provides for the adoption of contractual arrangements or agreements between nursing home residents and proprietors, as a condition of funding. The entering into of agreements as a condition of funding has already existed in hostels since January this year and this Bill will simply extend the arrangements to nursing homes.

The implementation of a standard residents' agreement between nursing home and hostel residents and proprietors is considered essential. The Residents' Rights report stated that, currently, entering into formal legal arrangements between residents and management is not a common practice. This means that neither party has a clear definition of their full rights and responsibilities towards the other party and there are no clearly defined paths to protect those rights and responsibilities.

The Bill also provides for situations where the resident either does not wish, or is not capable of entering into an agreement or is not able to be represented by either a guardian or person holding power of attorney. This is particularly relevant in nursing homes where a significant proportion of residents are unable to manage their own affairs as a result of dementia or similar conditions. These residents are entitled to the same consideration as others, and the Bill provides for them to be cared for in the same manner as those residents for whom there is an agreement in place between a resident and the proprietor. In situations where there is no agreement between a resident and the proprietor, the proprietor will be required to comply with conditions set down by the Minister in a notice in writing. The conditions would be consistent with matters covered in the agreement.

While the proposed amendments provide the Minister with the broad power to determine a common or standard form of agreement to be entered into between residents and proprietors, it is envisaged that the agreement will be consistent with the charter and will cover:
fees and financial information
service provision
security of tenure
participation in decision making, and
dispute resolution
The resident and proprietor may add to this if they so wish, so long as the intent of the standard agreement is preserved.
The Bill also proposes amendments to provide Commonwealth Officers and other authorised persons with greater access to nursing homes in the performance of their duties.

Currently Commonwealth Officers who monitor standards are authorised under section 42 of the Act to enter the premises and access only the documentation related to the operation of the premises as a nursing home. The proposed amendment will extend authorised access by Commonwealth Officers to include residents and staff of the nursing home and to documents related to the provision of care. The proposed authorisation does not imply that residents or staff will be coerced into talking with officers but merely enable officers to have access to such people.

The Bill also facilitates access to residents, staff and documents by those Commonwealth officers who review the degree of care, required by residents and verify the level of subsidy payable. At present access for the purposes of review of resident classifications is not guaranteed. Consequently if a nursing home denied access, no reviews could be undertaken. This means that potentially a nursing home could gain excess benefit by classifying its residents into unjustifiably high categories of relative service need but that the Department of Community Services and Health would not be able to challenge these classifications.

As a key initiative to provide the more isolated residents of nursing homes and hostels with support, advice and links to the external community, the residents' rights report recommended the establishment of a community visitors scheme. Under this scheme, people in the community with spare time and an interest in aged care will visit an allocated nursing home and hostel at least once a month. For this they are to be paid a special honorarium ($600 per annum based on $50 per monthly visit). The Bill makes provision for the Minister to designate people as community visitors and to describe their role and also provides them with access to a nursing home and its staff and residents to perform their function. Community visitors will be selected and trained on the basis of the sensitive and critical function they will be required to perform.

Under another initiative, advocacy services are to be established in each State and Territory. Advocates will be employed by appropriate organisations to speak on behalf of residents and uphold their rights and interests in grievance situations. The Bill therefore makes provision for advocates to have access to nursing homes and their residents to perform their function.

A further proposed amendment of the Bill is to give the Minister authority to publish information on specific aspects of a nursing home or hostel. The purpose of publication is to assist residents, potential residents and their representatives to select a nursing home or hostel suited to their needs or wishes. The information itself will relate to the quality of life for residents and to details about the facility's location, size, fees and method of operation. The information relating to residents' quality of life will be based on compliance with standards determined by the Minister. This information will assist intending residents to become aware of the quality and level of support available, will allow the many good nursing homes and hostels to promote their facilities and serve as an incentive for the few low standard facilities to provide a better service. The legislation provides a time period for proprietors of facilities to comment on the information prior to it being published and it requires the Minister to change the information before it is published where such comments are considered warranted.

The publication of information about residential aged care facilities is a major step forward in promoting the residents' right to know about the facility they live in, the public's knowledge of the care provided for the older people in their community and the high quality of care provided by most service providers.

As I have shown, the residents' rights amendments go a long way towards enabling the frail aged in nursing homes and hostels to be protected and addresses the major concerns identified by the residents themselves, namely those of isolation and boredom; lack of control over their own lives; absence of information about available services; and fear of retribution if a complaint is made.
I would now like to outline various amendments to other provisions relating to the residential aged care program.

The Bill also makes the provision of a medical certificate optional rather than mandatory for the purposes of considering an application for nursing home admission. Currently medical practitioners on geriatric assessment services with the delegation to approve nursing home admissions are required to provide the medical certificate required on the application form, as well as actually approve the application.

The Bill will allow these delegates to make decisions on nursing home admissions even though no medical certificate is provided, thereby simplifying procedures for nursing home admission. However where a certificate is provided, the Bill requires that it be taken into account.
The Bill also allows backdating of approval of a domiciliary nursing care benefit (DNCB) application in certain circumstances.
Currently the date of effect of an approved DNCB application cannot be a date earlier than the date on which the application was received in the department.

A number of applications, for reasons beyond the direct control of otherwise eligible applicants, have been delayed before reaching the department. These delays have disadvantaged some applicants and have occurred for a variety of reasons. For example, completed applications have been mislayed or delayed by medical practitioners or registered nurses or completed applications have been lost in the mail. Previously, act of grace payments were made in some of these cases. The amendments in the Bill will allow for processing in these circumstances.

It is intended that prior to any decision to backdate an application, supporting statements from the doctor and the nurse will be required indicating that they had completed the requisite certifications and advising the date or dates on which this occurred.

The Bill also provides for the Minister to approve a person as an approved operator of a nursing home for the purposes of receiving Commonwealth payments under the National Health Act 1953. The Bill also provides for the Minister to revoke approvals.

These powers are considered necessary by the Government because of the nature and vulnerability of aged persons. In addition under residents' rights proposals in the Bill, residents will be entering into contracts with proprietors, who must be acceptable for the purpose of operating a nursing home.

Further, the amending legislation will assist in removing underlying concerns about some care providers, particularly former proprietors who, having previously treated residents poorly and failed to meet the required care standards, or engaged in fraudulent practices, are now seeking to return to the industry, for example by purchasing an existing approved nursing home. Present Commonwealth approval controls do not provide adequate cover in circumstances involving sale and purchase of nursing homes.

The powers provided in this Bill will ensure that Commonwealth funding approvals are granted to persons who will properly meet the responsibility for the care and accommodation of an extremely vulnerable group of people.

The Bill also provides for the Minister, when approving a person as an approved nursing home operator or revoking such approval, to have regard to principles. These principles, which will be subject to parliamentary scrutiny, will cover such matters as the character and reputation of the person, the ability, willingness and expertise of the person to provide adequate nursing home care and meet the special care needs of nursing home residents; the ability to effectively financially manage a nursing home and the capacity and willingness of the person to comply with conditions of approval of a nursing home for Commonwealth funding.
It is provided in the Bill that a person who is dissatisfied with a decision to refuse or revoke approval may seek a review of a decision through the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

The Bill provides for existing proprietors of approved nursing homes and persons who have been granted approval-in-principle to construct a new nursing home or transfer nursing home beds, to become approved operators automatically under the legislation. Such approvals are of course subject to the revocation of approvals provisions if a person was found to be unsuitable to be a proprietor.

The Nursing Homes Assistance Act and the common form of agreement authorised by that act, permit proprietors of former deficit financed nursing homes to request the Minister to review the approved budget and operating deficit of a home for a period ending before 30 June 1987.

The legislation requires the request in the first instance to be investigated by a nursing homes advisory committee. These committees are established in each state to assist the Minister's investigations by providing a detailed professional and independent review of departmental decisions, where proprietors are unable to reach agreement with the Minister's delegate on the levels of approved budgets and deficits.

The Government has become concerned at the escalation in the number of requests for review received since 1 July 1987, the date from which the Government's aged care reforms were introduced. The industry has indicated that the increase in the number of requests is largely an orchestrated form of protest against aspects of the nursing home reforms. The National Health Act was amended last year to introduce lodgement and processing fees for requests by proprietors to review nursing home fee decisions. The provisions of this Bill remove the current inconsistency between the Nursing Homes Assistance Act and the National Health Act in this regard.

The process of review is a through one involving the gathering and analysis of complex information. The length of time for each review varies but on average consumes almost 100 hours of public service time. In the past, the cost of a review, estimated at about $4000, has been met entirely by taxpayers.

There is a statutory obligation on the Minister to consider these requests for review. However, it is difficult to distinguish between protest or vexatious appeals and those which are genuine. It is in the interests of the taxpayer and nursing home proprietors with genuine grievances, to free-up the nursing homes review mechanisms by ensuring that only those cases which are genuine become the subject of review and that those appeals are expeditiously handled. There is a further need to prevent the situation from worsening by avoiding future protest or vexatious appeals against fee determinations. The government considers the introduction of a lodgement fee of $500, and an additional processing fee of $500 for each half-day a committee meets to consider an appeal, will achieve those objectives. Administration of these arrangements will be facilitated by fees being deducted from payments due to a nursing home proprietor under the common form of agreement or under the National Health Act 1953 on authorisation by the proprietor.

To safeguard the position of genuine appellants both lodgement and processing fees will be refunded in full where a request for review is wholly or substantially successful. Provision is also made for the lodgement fee to be refunded in full to a proprietor who withdraws a request within 84 days following a decision.
The Bill also provides some essentially administrative amendments to the National Health Act 1953 which are consequential to the National Health (Nursing Home Respite Care) Regulations.

Taken together, these amendments remove the distinction between approvals for short-term respite care admission and general nursing home admission. This distinction is no longer necessary since the gazettal of these regulations has removed the need for a separate type of approval for short-term respite care. The amendments will tidy up the Act and will remove the possibility of confusion. All approvals for admission to a nursing home including for short-term respite care, now will be made under the same section of the Act.

I turn now to the amendments to the First Home Owners Act 1983. The Government has been concerned that whilst Australian-born citizens are ineligible for the first homes owners scheme if they have previously owned a home in Australia, migrants and also Australian citizens who have owned a home overseas are treated more favourably as any previous overseas home ownership is disregarded. For obvious reasons, it is not practicable to attempt to test for previous ownership overseas. Further, there are difficulties in applying the scheme's income test equitably as between long term residents and those acquiring a home before they have been here for a full year.
Clearly those with sufficient means or prospects to be able to embark upon home ownership soon after arrival are in an already strong position and stand less in need of assistance from the taxpayer.

Accordingly the proposed amendment requires at least one person involved in each application for assistance under the Act to have had his or her principal place of residence in Australia during the period of 12 months immediately preceding the date of home acquisition.

Another amendment to that Act provides for a child under the age of 18 at the date of home acquisition, or a child born during the period commencing on that date and ending at the expiration of the first anniversary of that date to be treated as a dependent child of an applicant for the purposes of the Act. Additionally the child must be in the custody, care and control of, and ordinarily residing with, an applicant for assistance under the Act at any time during the outlined period. The amendment will simplify administration of the Act as the existing references to the Social Security Act are to be deleted in favour of a test administered by the Department.
The last proposed amendment will overcome anomalies in the existing legislation which result in disadvantage to certain persons who purchase their homes under a terms purchase contract.

The Bill also includes amendments to the definitions of ``Proprietor of a Laboratory'' in section 3 (1) and ``Officer'' of the Health Insurance Commission in sections 3 (1) 23dk (3) and 129aac of the Health Insurance Act 1973.

In 1987, new pathology arrangements were introduced to bring into effect a greater degree of accountability of persons providing pathology services, by requiring that approved pathology authorities (APAs), undertake to maintain certain standards. A failure to maintain those standards results in the possible revocation of the undertaking and the loss of eligibility for Medicare benefits for the services rendered in the APA's laboratory.
It has become apparent that the corporate structure of some providers of pathology services makes it difficult to identify the actual operator of the services.

The new definition of ``Proprietor'' of a laboratory in section 3 (1) of the Health Insurance Act will mean that medicare benefits will not be payable in respect of services rendered in an accredited pathology laboratory unless there is at least one proprietor who has effective control over the staffing, equipment and the premises of the laboratory.

The Health Insurance Act confers upon officers of the Health Insurance Commission a number of powers and duties in relation to the medicare program. Legal opinion is that the definitions as they stand, could be interpreted to mean the persons actually holding office under the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973-that is the members (or Commissioners) and the General Manager. This is plainly not the intention of the original provisions.
The proposed amendment to section 3 (1) of the Health Insurance Act more clearly defines ``Officer'' to specifically represent members of the staff of the Commission.

Section 23dk (3) of the Health Insurance Act requires an approved pathology practitioner to produce to an officer of the Commissioner a written confirmation concerning a pathology service. It is not intended all officers of the Commission should have this power [as would be conferred by the proposed amendment to section 3 (1)] but to confine it to the General Manager.

The proposed amendment to section 129aac is intended to give added confidence to medical providers at formal counselling sessions by limiting the applicability of the section to officers of the Commission who are either medical practitioners, dental practitioners or optometrists.

This Bill will also insert a new clause which will restrict entitlement to Medicare benefits to those diplomatic representatives, their staff and families of countries whose Governments have with Australia an agreement under section 7 of the Health Insurance Act which specifically entitles Diplomatic/Consular staff and their families access to the Health Care System of the host country.

This amendment removes the anomaly whereby in the current Act the inclusion of `eligible overseas representatives' in the definition of `eligible person' ensures foreign diplomatic representatives and their staff are entitled to Medicare benefits while in Australia whereas Australia's diplomatic representatives in the other country concerned may not be entitled to reciprocal health care privileges.

The proposed amendments to section 3H of the Health Insurance Act relate to administration of the vocational register of general practitioners. The amendments will require the exercise of ministerial power under that section by regulation not determination. The changes are in accordance with the commitment made to the Senate on 30 August, and again in the subsequent debate on 7 September, to make this change to the legislation ``at the earliest possible opportunity''. The proposal is consistent with the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance and will provide for greater parliamentary scrutiny.

The Bill also extends the benefits of a health care card (and thus pharmaceutical benefits at the concessional rate of $2.50) to those persons in receipt of a ``formal training allowance''. This amendment simplifies the administration of the formal training allowance scheme and gives those persons the same entitlement as those receiving either unemployment benefits or a job search allowance.
This provision is to apply retrospectively so as not to disadvantage persons receiving this allowance since its commencement in July last year.

Two clauses in this Bill provide for the linking of the relevant secrecy provisions of the Health Insurance Act and National Health Act. These amendments will improve the administration and effectiveness of both the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme and Medicare, particularly in the area of overuse and abuse.
Officers of the Health Insurance Commission will of course continue to be subject to the secrecy provisions of these Acts.
This Bill also makes a technical amendment to the provisions of the National Health Act that relates to the `Special Patient Contribution' arrangements under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.

There are at present only two drugs subject to this provision which allows for the payment of an additional charge by the patient when the drug's manufacturer disputes the price determined by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Pricing Authority.

Under the present arrangements, if a prescription for any quantity other than the maximum quantity, or a multiple of this quantity, is written the patient has to pay a full special patient contribution.

This amendment provides a simple formula for the calculation of a pro-rata special patient contribution for any quantity of the drug prescribed by the doctor and thus provides a more equitable method for calculating the special patient contribution in all cases.

The Bill will correct an anomaly in the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. Under the National Health Act at present, a prescription written for a patient who is entitled to free or concessional pharmaceutical benefits, must establish, to the satisfaction of the pharmacist supplying the drug, that he or she is entitled to that benefit by recording the card number on the prescription. This information may of course be recorded by the patient or any other person (including the pharmacist) acting as an agent for the patient.

Situations arise where persons fail to establish their eligibility status at the time of supply for a variety of reasons. Sometimes this failure arises not through oversight or carelessness on the part of the person or the agent. It could be caused by an error in the pharmacy or private hospital or because the person involved was admitted in an unconscious state, or was suffering from an illness which impaired his/her abilities.

It is thought that in these circumstances, it would be unjust not to allow for such persons to be retrospectively accorded their correct status and consequently, expenses incurred would be correspondingly reduced, as a consequence.
There is currently no provision in the National Health Act for such an adjustment to be made. This proposed amendment to the Act provides for such an adjustment on the following conditions-
that whether such an adjustment would be allowed would be at the discretion of the secretary of the department; and

that this discretion will only be exercised in relation to cases where the claimant can provide satisfactory evidence that he/she had paid for a pharmaceutical benefit at a level above that appropriate to his/her eligibility status and that this event occurred in circumstances beyond his/her control (or that of the agent's) and was not due to their oversight or other avoidable circumstance.

The arrangements for residents' rights, consequential upon amendments to the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954 and the National Health Act 1953, are expected to cost an estimated $0.89m in 1989-90, $1.58m in 1990-91 and $1.75m in 1991-92. Expenditures would be incurred in relation to honoraria payable to community visitors costs relating to the preparation of statements on standards and funding for advocacy services.

Consequent upon the amendment to subsection 58e (6) of the National Health Act 1953 there may be a small additional cost (estimated $10,000 in 1989-90 and $20,000 annually thereafter) arising from domiciliary nursing care benefits being payable from a date earlier than the date of receipt of the application to eligible applicants whose applications have been lost or delayed through no fault of the applicants. These payments are no more than those to which the applicants are entitled under the eligibility criteria in the existing legislation.

Consequent upon the amendment to the Nursing Homes Assistance Act 1974, the proposed lodgment fee of $500 and an additional processing fee of $500 per half day will yield revenue estimated at $45,000 in 1989-90, with anticipated revenue of $20,000 and $5,000 in 1990-91 and 1991-92 respectively. The fees are consistent with existing provisions in the National Health Act 1953 for requests for review of nursing home fees under that legislation and will have a deterrent effect on nursing home proprietors lodging non-genuine appeals. Proprietors who have their appeal wholly or substantially upheld will have their lodgment fee refunded and no processing fee will be applied. The main Commonwealth savings will be in avoiding non-quantifiable additional costs in processing non-genuine review applications.

The amendments to the First Home Owners Act 1983 to impose a 12 months residency requirement for recent arrivals before they can qualify for assistance is expected to result in savings of $2m in 1989-90 and $3m in each of the three subsequent financial years. The remaining amendments to the First Home Owners Act 1983 have no financial impact.
There is no financial impact consequent upon other amendments to the National Health Act 1953, the Health Insurance Act 1973 or the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Amendment Act 1989.
The amendments relating to pharmaceutical benefits will not result in any financial outlays.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
BOUNTY PHOTOGRAPHIC FILM BILL 1989

This Bill proposes new legislation, the Bounty (Photographic Film) Act 1989, to provide bounty assistance to Australian manufacturers of sensitized photographic colour film from 1 January 1990 to 31 December 1992.
This legislation will remain in force for a further period of two years to 31 December 1994 for the purpose of securing the performance of undertakings under this legislation.

The bounty arrangements contained in this legislation provide in Clause 10 for a bounty to be paid at a rate of $3.75 per square metre of silver halide colour sensitized photographic film which has been sensitized and finished in Australia pursuant to conditions noted in Clause 7, which I will discuss shortly.
The Government's decision to bring forward this legislation results from the Government's consideration of recent events relating to Kodak Australasia.

On 24 August 1989 Eastman Kodak of the United States (the parent company of Kodak Australasia) announced that it would be restructuring its worldwide operations following disappointing financial results. The restructuring taking place over the next twelve months involves the sale, closing down or re-organisation of several operating units with combined revenues of $1.25 billion and the cutting of 4500 jobs worldwide.
One operating unit selected for closure by Eastman Kodak was Kodak Australasia's manufacturing operations at Coburg, Victoria.

Kodak Australasia's Coburg operation is Australia's second largest exporter of elaborately transformed manufactures. The operation contains a major research and development, manufacturing and distribution capability employing some 1500 people. For 1989, Kodak Australasia forecast that of its total sales of $472 million, exports of $164 million will be generated.

The Australian operation is recognised, even by Eastman Kodak, as an efficient and world competitive operation. However, for strategic reasons, Eastman Kodak is unwilling to close down its less efficient operations in other parts of the world. For example, Eastman Kodak's plants in Europe are positioned to take advantage of the changes in 1992; Eastman Kodak is unwilling to close down its South American operations because of the existence of high tariff walls and very favourable taxation regimes; and its plants in the United States represent Eastman Kodak's corporate home base.

Following an initiative by the management of Kodak Australasia, an undertaking from Eastman Kodak was obtained that if Kodak Australasia could substantially improve its economic performance, Eastman Kodak would undertake to maintain and develop its Australian operations.
To achieve this target, Kodak Australasia undertook to deliver $20 million per annum in productivity improvements and to approach Federal and State Governments for additional temporary assistance.

The Victorian Government recently announced that it would assist Kodak Australasia through various measures at a level of approximately $6 million over three years. This was granted on condition that the Federal Government would provide further assistance.

In considering the question of whether to provide assistance to Kodak Australasia, this Government has taken into account the significant contribution Kodak Australasia has made over a number of years in the areas of wealth and job creation, skills, technology and, most significantly, exports independent of any form of Government assistance programme.

The signals from Eastman Kodak also suggested that a window of opportunity existed not only to overturn the closure decision but to press for a commitment to enhance Kodak's Australian operations in the Asian region, in return for temporary assistance from this government.
In reaching a decision to provide assistance, the government took account of the following major commitments from Eastman Kodak and Kodak Australasia.

First, Kodak Australasia will be retained as a manufacturing plant for colour film employing sensitizing operations for a minimum of three years and finishing operations for a minimum period of five years.

Second, Kodak Australasia will retain its corporate mandate as the sole producer of Kodacolour 100 colour film for Australia and at least those Asian and other markets currently supplied by the company.
Third, Kodak Australasia will retain its export mandate into those Asian and other markets currently supplied by the company, and be entitled to seek further export markets in these regions.
Fourth, Kodak Australasia will implement significant productivity improvements through award restructuring, inventory, overheads and production line improvements.

Fifth, in the event that Kodak Australasia does not maintain its mandate for the Asia Pacific region over the next five years, Kodak Australasia has agreed to pay back any Federal Government assistance provided.
Finally, Kodak Australasia will be broadening its research and development activities within Australia over the next five years.

Any changes in Government policy that would provide a comparative financial advantage to Kodak Australasia (e.g. reduction of corporate tax rates or of tariffs on input costs) will be taken into account and any assistance provided reduced accordingly.

In the light of Kodak's decision, the Government favours the provision of support to Kodak and believes that a production bounty effectively incorporating the conditions referred to is the most appropriate form of assistance. This will, in the Government's view, enable the company to carry out and complete its restructuring satisfactorily, expand its export base substantially and enhance its research and development capabilities.
The Bill contains the following substantive elements:
To be eligible to receive bounty under this legislation, Clause 7 requires the producer of bountiable film:
(a) to carry out in Australia all the sensitizing and finishing operations in respect of the film;
(b) to complete the finishing of the film in the first 3 years of the 5 year period to which the Act applies; and
(c) to be registered for the five year period to which the Act applies.
Clause 16 dealing with the registration of persons under the legislation, will enable regulations to be made prescribing conditions to be met by bounty claimants, including:
a requirement that a registered person perform finishing operations for the whole of the period to which the Act applies;
a requirement that a registered person maintain prescribed production levels, employment levels, and in a plant of a prescribed production capacity; and

a requirement that a registered person enter into a photographic industry development agreement for the period to which the Act applies, with progress under that agreement subject to an annual review.

Bounty will be paid on the production of bountiable film where the producer satisfies all the preconditions I have described, and where the producer lodges a claim for payment within the first 3 years of the scheme. The proposal to limit this bounty to a three year period brings this legislation into line with other pieces of bounty legislation which are scheduled to phase out by 1992-93.

Retaining the legislation for five years however enables the Government to recover bounty payments in the event that the requirements of the legislation, including the registration conditions to be prescribed under Clause 16, are not complied with by the intending claimant for the entire 5 year period.

The Comptroller-General of the Australian Customs Service is empowered to periodically monitor and audit the application of the bounty under Clauses 20 to 24 to ensure that the country is paid in accordance with the legislation.

In framing this bounty legislation the Government considers that its implementation will encourage the long term growth and development of sensitized film production in Australia, assist in the modernisation of plant and equipment and lead to Australia enhancing its position as a major exporter of photographic film and related products. Exports are expected to total $1 billion in earnings over the next five years. The Government is satisfied that the commitments entered into between Eastman Kodak, Kodak Australasia and the Government, and this legislation will provide a policy environment which will encourage health and efficiency in a sector vital to Australia's future growth as a manufacturing nation.
Financial Impact Statement

The amount of money available for the payment of bounty, or advances on account of bounty under this scheme, is limited to that amount which is appropriated by the parliament for that purpose (subclause 12 (2) and clause 31).

In announcing the bounty scheme on 31 October 1989, the Government indicated that only the first 3 years of the bounty scheme would receive an appropriation totalling up to $36 million (at an annual limit of up to $12 million).
The financial impact of this Bill by financial years is therefore:
$6 million for 1989-90;
$12 million for 1990-91;
$12 million for 1991-92; and
$6 million for 1992-93.
I commend the Bill to the Senate
GRAIN LEGUMES LEVY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1989

The principal purpose of the Bill is to amend the Grain Legumes Levy Act 1985 and associated regulations to allow different rates of levy to be determined for the various grain legumes covered by the grain legume research scheme. In recognition of the higher per unit value of crops recently added to the scheme, the maximum rate of levy prescribed in the Act is proposed to be increased from $2.60 to $5.00 per tonne.

The Bill also provides for an increase in the levy rate for peanuts from $1.25 to $2.00 per tonne and changes of an administrative nature in respect of peanuts and mung beans. All changes have been recommended by the Grains Council of Australia, which is the growers' organisation defined in the Levy Act.

The Grain Legumes Levy Act, in conjunction with the Rural Industries Research Act 1985, gives effect to a grain legumes research scheme which is funded by a levy payable by growers on the production of certain grain legumes. The levy rate is presently $1.24 per tonne for all leviable grain legumes, which can be varied by regulation up to a maximum rate of $2.60 per tonne. Grower contributions to research by way of the levy, are matched by the Commonwealth on a dollar for dollar basis up to 0.5% of the industry's gross value of production.

Australian grain legume production has increased very markedly over the past decade and today makes a significant contribution to the Australian cropping industry. Moreover, the industry has developed into a major rural commodity export earner. National production in 1988/89 is estimated at over 1.8 million tonnes valued in excess of $400m. Exports for the same year were in excess of 782,000 tonnes valued at $207m.

Improved prices relative to cereals has been a significant factor in the strong growth in grain legume production. There is, however, increasing recognition among the farming community of the value of grain legumes as a rotational crop, both to provide nitrogen for subsequent cereal crops and to assist in the control of cereal disease. Grain legumes are thus expected to continue to play an important part in farm management, as well as broadening the market base for rural producers.

Reflecting the increased grower interest in grain legumes in recent years, the Government has approved a number of additions to the grain legumes research scheme. Initially only lupins and field peas were leviable under the Act. Faba beans, chick peas, mung beans, pigeon peas and peanuts have since been included. The value per unit of production of the crops added to the scheme, however, varies considerably from that of lupins and field peas.

The objective of the proposed amendments to the Grain Legumes Levy Act 1985 contained in this Bill is to provide for a levy determination mechanism for grain legumes leviable under the Act to more closely reflect the price received by the grower for the particular crop grown.

It will assist growers of all grain legumes covered by the scheme, to reach the target level of 0.5% of gross value of production which the Government considers to be the appropriate minimum level of industry contributions to research. Contributions to that level receive the benefit of full matching contributions by the Commonwealth.

The amendment will provide for different rates of levy to be payable on individual leviable grain legumes or groups of leviable grain legumes, by way of regulation. The maximum rate for any levy under the scheme will continue to be prescribed in the Act, but is to be increased to $5.00 per tonne as requested by the growers' organisation.

The first grain legume proposed to attract a separate level rate is peanuts, which for administrative efficiency, is prescribed in the legislation in this instance. The rate of $2.00 per tonne has been the subject of a specific recommendation of the growers' organisation as required by the Levy Act. Also in regard to peanuts, a change to the legislation is necessary to ensure that the levy is applied on an ``in shell'' basis, reflecting the fact that a proportion of production is sold in that form.

In relation to the financial implications of the Bill, the higher levy rate for peanuts will generate an estimated additional $29,700 in industry contributions to the grain legumes research trust fund in the first full levy income year. Provision has been made for the increased Commonwealth matching contribution to commence in the 1990/91 financial year, at the level appropriate to a commencement date for the Act of 1 January 1990. None of the remaining provisions of the Bill have direct financial implications.

The Bill also provides for the addition to the scheme, by regulation, of the mung bean species Vigna mungo. The addition is necessary to ensure that all commercially grown species of mung bean are listed and thus leviable.

The existing Grain Legume Research Levy Regulations will be made redundant by the legislative amendments proposed and are to be repealed. The amendments provide express authority for further levy rates to be prescribed by regulation subject to the maximum rate prescribed in the Act.

Subject to the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Bill entering into force, the grain legumes research scheme will continue to be administered by the Grain Legumes Research Council. It is envisaged that the scheme would be administered in due course, as part of the proposed Grains Research and Development Corporation, reflecting the close links between cereal and grain legume crop production.

The commencement date of this legislation will be a date to be proclaimed. A commencement date of 1 January 1990 would accord with existing provisions of the Act and ensure that all peanuts harvested in the 1989/90 season attract the higher rate of levy.
I commend the Bill to Honourable Senators.
INCOME TAX (INTERNATIONAL AGREEMENTS) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989

I am pleased to introduce this Bill, which will provide legislative authority for the entry into force of comprehensive double taxation agreements between Australia and Papua New Guinea, and Australia and Thailand.
The Bill will also provide legislative authority for the entry into force of protocols to amend Australia's existing comprehensive double taxation agreements with France and Singapore.

The Papua New Guinea and Thailand agreements, which were signed on 24 May 1989 and 31 August 1989 respectively, deal with all substantial forms of income flowing between Australia and the other two countries.

The agreements substantially accord with other comprehensive taxation agreements concluded by Australia in recent years. The Government believes the agreements will contribute positively to the strengthening of trade, investment, and wider relationships between Australia and these two countries.

A feature of the agreements is that they each provide for ``tax sparing'' credit relief to be extended by Australia for tax forgone by Papua New Guinea and Thailand under specified development incentives investment.

Where income derived by an Australian resident taxpayer has benefited from one of the nominated development incentives, each agreement calls for the tax credit to be allowed by Australia to include the foreign tax forgone.

By this means, the development incentives will retain their attractions for Australian investors and allow them to compete on favourable terms with investors from other countries as they will not be negated by the imposition of Australian tax.
I note here that the agreements were negotiated on the basis of the existing income tax laws of the respective countries.

The Government recognises that aspects of proposed changes to Australia's general foreign tax credit system, which have been foreshadowed as applying from the beginning of the 1990-91 income year, could affect the practical operation of the tax credit provisions of the agreements, including the tax sparing mechanism.

For example, proposed income tax exemptions under our domestic law for certain dividend payments and branch profits derived by Australian companies from comparable tax countries are likely to provide at least a great relief from Australian tax, and would operate in relation to such income from foreign countries including those with which tax treaties have been concluded.

The protocols to Australia's double taxation agreements with France and Singapore will amend these agreements in a number of respects in relation to the prevention of double taxation and the removal of possible avenues of tax avoidance. The protocols will generally update those agreements in line with Australia's more recently concluded comprehensive tax rebates.

The French protocol, signed on 19 June 1989, will amend the agreement to provide that Government service pensions will only be taxed by the country paying the pension, except where the recipient is a citizen or national of the other country. As announced by the Treasurer when the protocol was signed, this measure will partially restore an arrangement previously applicable under the French agreement for retirement pensions derived before 1 July 1987. It will have effect in relation to Government source pensions derived from that date.

Other pensions will continue to be taxable only in the country of residence of the recipient. As a related measure, the protocol allows contributions to a recognised pension fund in one country to qualify for a purchase price offset against pension income that is taxed in the other country.

Of other measures of some significance, one will assist each country to apply its current domestic law provisions relating to international profit shifting arrangements and another will bring the definition of ``royalties'' more into line with Australia's income tax law and modern comprehensive taxation agreements.

The Singapore protocol was signed on 16 October 1989. It will operate to delete a provision of the existing agreement with Singapore under which Australia is required to provide a rebate of tax for dividends paid to a resident Australian company by a Singapore company in which the Australian company has at least a 10 per cent interest.

That provision is incompatible with Australia's general income tax law now that the intercorporate dividend rebate in relation to foreign dividends derived by an Australian company has been withdrawn. The deletion of that provision will be effective in respect of dividends paid after 11 March 1988, being the date of an announcement by the Treasurer which foreshadowed this change.
Another measure gives ``tax sparing'' relief for income which Singapore exempts, special incentive measures to promote economic development in Singapore.

An exchange of notes which took place at the time the protocol was signed will extend to 30 June 1987 the operation of earlier `'tax sparing'' provisions in the agreement with Singapore, after which the amendments contained in the protocol will bring new tax sparing arrangements into operation in relation to certain designated development incentives currently provided by Singapore.

Other amendments to be made by the protocol will modify the existing agreement in relation to taxing rights over royalties, business profits, dealings between associated enterprises, airline and shipping profits, and income or gains from property.

Each of the agreements and protocols will enter into force when all necessary constitutional processes are completed both by Australia and the other contracting countries. The enactment of this Bill will complete the processes required of Australia.
The agreements and protocols will help facilitate trading relationships with the other countries but it is not possible to predict the eventual effect on the revenue.
May I commend the Bill to the Senate.
SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 4) 1989
Over the last 6 years, the Federal Labor Government has reconstructed Australia's social security system.
Once regarded as little more than a passive payment agency, the social security system now has strong and active links to employment, training and labour market services.
Social security policy has become an integral part of the Government's economic, wages and taxation policies.

The social security, wages and tax systems have been restructured to deliver fairer and more adequate incomes to all at every stage of life. Together these systems now provide a solid base of economic security for all Australians.
The barriers and difficulties confronting the different groups within the social security system have been progressively identified and tackled.
Today's social security system offers incentives and opportunities for those of working age to move from payments, designed for short term support, back into jobs.
Assistance has been targeted to those most in need while administrative procedures have been constantly improved to minimise the risk of payment abuse.

The impetus for many of these changes has been the social security review which last year completed its historic `life cycle' examination of the system-the first time this has been done since World War II.
The results of our reconstruction are clear.
For the first time ever, Australia has a guaranteed level of income support for families with children.
Australia now leads the world in providing adequate, secure child support to separated parents.
The increasingly strong links between Australia's social security system and labour market assistance for the unemployed and sole parents are setting the pace for reform in OECD countries.

These links provide opportunities to participate in the mainstream of community life for people at risk of being excluded. They ensure that the community does not bear the cost of unnecessary and counter-productive welfare dependency.
This Bill would implement further fundamental reforms to the social security system.

In the 1989-90 Budget and retirement income policy statement, the Federal Government announced a fundamental restructuring of the relationship of the public pension and tax system on the one hand, and private savings and support for retired Australians on the other.
This restructuring will provide a sound basis of income security for the retired and for those who will retire-in the next decade and in the longer term.
These changes, like every element of the Government's social policies, are fully funded on introduction and sustainable in the long term. They complement the Government's reform of superannuation.
This Bill would reshape income support to take account of the different forms of savings available to retired people and ensure that they can live with dignity and security in their own homes.
Our policies will guarantee access to a fair, adequate, secure and sustainable retirement income for all Australians.
The most significant reform for older Australians will be a major restructuring of the overlap between the pension income test and taxation.

This Bill would implement our promise that, from 1991, the income test free area will be indexed annually. The free area will also be 100% tax free. Further, from 1995 no age or service pensioner-full rate or part rate-will pay income tax.
These plus other significant reforms to date mean that every major element of the social security system will be protected into the future by guaranteed automatic adjustment for inflation.
This Bill also contains carefully crafted and co-ordinated measures to provide better opportunities and incentives for self provision for the aged, the disabled, sole parents and the unemployed.
The Bill would overhaul the interaction of private superannuation and the social security system.

The treatment of annuities and superannuation pensions under the income test will be brought into line with their treatment in the tax system. The Bill would exempt from the income test that part of the undeducted purchase price which represents the notional return of the after tax purchase price of a superannuation pension or an immediate annuity.

These changes would be complemented by exclusion of superannuation pensions from the assets test and by special rules for the treatment of immediate annuities under the assets test. This will ensure the changes have the effect of encouraging the use of private savings to provide retirement incomes-rather than becoming a vehicle for income test avoidance.

Labor's better incomes policy acknowledges the wide range of needs of retired and pre-retired people. This Bill would enable people who are disabled or have become unemployed before age pension age to retain the full benefit of their superannuation for retirement. Income which accrues on compulsorily preserved superannuation will be exempted from pension and benefit income tests until the pensioner or beneficiary reaches age pension age-except when the person draws on the superannuation. In those cases, the growth will be treated as income over the 12 months following the withdrawal.
Compulsorily preserved superannuation will be disregarded under the assets test.
Through our retirement income policy we will provide opportunities for all Australians to provide for their retirement. We will deliver better incomes in retirement to all Australians.

When the Whitlam Government was elected the age pension was only 19% of average weekly earnings. In 3 years Whitlam raised the level of the pension to almost 25%. However over the next 7 years the conservative parties in government allowed the pension to fall back to about 22% of average weekly earnings.

This Labor Government has steadily regained the ground lost under the conservatives. And through this Bill pensions would be lifted to more than 25% of average weekly earnings-in fact to their highest level relative to average earnings in 40 years. From April 1990, single rate pensions and benefits for people with dependants, will rise by $2 a week on top of indexation. Pensions and benefits for married people will rise by $3.30 a week on top of indexation.

When the department becomes aware of the death the balance of any entitlements under these new arrangements would be cashed out, as soon as practicable, to a lump sum to assist with funeral and other costs likely to arise.

The legislation would make it clear that where payments continue during the 14 weeks after death to an account in the name of the deceased-whether alone or jointly with the surviving spouse-the financial institution would be entitled to pay those amounts to the spouse. This will address a major practical problem that faces many newly widowed people-continuing access to their bank accounts.

This Bill would dramatically simplify the earnings credit-to provide extra assistance to pensioners who undertake short term jobs and to provide a springboard into employment for pensioners seeking permanent jobs-especially sole parent pensioners.

From April 1990, earnings credit accrual will be standardised. Pensioners will build up credit at a set rate depending on the income test free area that applies to them-this will be $40 a week for single people, $35 for each of a married couple plus $12 for each dependent child. The maximum credit will remain at $1,000. This amendment will create a more worthwhile, understandable and efficient earnings credit scheme.

The aged package included in this Bill, and complemented by other measures announced in the Budget, is the most comprehensive, detailed and coherent social policy development in the history of Australian Federation. It is based on the detailed work of the social security review and was crafted following extensive consultations conducted by the government on the issue. I would like to record in particular the government's appreciation of the efforts of the members of the Prime Minister's task force on retirement incomes jointly convened, by Mr Speaker, Mr McLeay, and the member for Phillip Ms McHugh. Their efforts and the efforts of the thousands of retired people who spoke with them ensured that this package is a package for the long term.

It is with deep regret that I record that the Opposition has still not committed itself to the long term commitments in this policy-the indexation of free areas in 1991 and the removal of all age and service pensioners from the tax system in 1995.

A retirement income policy must be stable and long term. If the Opposition is serious about all Australians having adequate incomes in retirement, if they are serious about enhancing our national savings effort they will use the debate on this Bill to unequivocally commit themselves for the long term to the national retirement income policy. Their failure to do so, or any qualification of their commitment, will be a clear signal to the retired and pre-retired people of Australia about the priority the Opposition gives to better incomes for all in retirement.

Many provisions of this Bill which address the needs of the aged extend to veterans and their dependants in receipt of a repatriation service pension in the same way as to social security age pension recipients.
This Bill also provides for increases in the rates of payment of a number of minor benefits for severely handicapped veterans.

Over the last 5 years Labor has rebuilt the integrity of Australia's unemployment benefit system. We have fundamentally restructured the system and converted it from a passive payment system to an active system linked to labour market policies and programs designed for the broad range of people dependant on unemployment benefit. This Bill would continue with the reform of benefits entitlements that has underwritten that restructuring.

The labour market and income support issues facing older unemployed people are of particular concern to the government in terms of social justice, economic and retirement income policy objectives. There has been a disturbing long term trend of declining labour force participation by people aged 55 and over. Together with the retirement income policy, this Bill would provide more adequate assistance and better opportunities and incentives for regaining employment to the older unemployed.
First, the work test for beneficiaries aged 55 and over would be restructured-to enable older beneficiaries to retain or regain close attachment to the labour market.

The dynamic newstart strategy-described by the Opposition spokesman as ``spectacularly successful''-introduced in February this year allows participation in CES-approved training courses and voluntary work while unemployment benefit continues. The strategy helps the long term unemployed to get back to work. This Bill would provide the basis to extend the strategy to all older unemployed beneficiaries regardless of how long they have been on benefit.

Further, older beneficiaries on benefit for 12 months or more will be able to engage in training or voluntary work for even longer-for up to 26 weeks in a year. They will also be able to participate in substantial ongoing part-time employment as an acceptable alternative to the requirement to seek suitable, full-time work.
The maximum rate of benefit for people aged 60 or more would be aligned with pension rates after 6 months receipt of benefit.
The 26 week rent assistance waiting period would be abolished for beneficiaries aged 60 or more.

Third, people aged 60 and above who have been receiving unemployment or sickness benefit for at least 12 months will become eligible for a health benefit card rather than the less beneficial health care card which they currently have available to them. This new card will provide the full range of Commonwealth fringe benefits.

These measures will be complemented by a hefty boost in availability and appropriateness of labour market programs-such as jobstart, jobtrain, skillshare and the new enterprise incentive scheme-for the older unemployed. Different methods of helping and encouraging older unemployed people back into work are being trialled over the next 12 months.

These measures stand in sharp contrast to the Opposition's approach. The Opposition argues that all long term unemployed people should be removed from unemployment benefit and placed on special benefit-or receive nothing. Their position is also that jobstart, skillshare and the new enterprise incentive scheme-centrepieces of Labor's approach for the older unemployed should be abolished.

There is no doubt that this Bill-in providing for modifications to unemployment benefit to help people back to work-is inconsistent with Opposition policy. The debate on the Bill provides to the Opposition an opportunity to put down the details of how they would deal with the older unemployed.

Over the last 4 years this Labor Government has completely restructured income support and labour market assistance for the young. The common allowance structure-under which Austudy for young people at school is paid at the same rate as job search allowance-or JSA-for unemployed young people has removed the incentive for young people to leave school for unemployment.
The JSA structure has also provided an integrated basis for delivery of income support and labour market assistance.

The results of Labor's approach are dramatic. The numbers dependent on social security have plummetted while the proportion staying on at school has sky-rocketed. However we recognise that some young people have missed out-and so we developed the youth social justice strategy announced in the budget.

That strategy involves an integrated comprehensive $100 million program to address the barriers facing disadvantaged young people and to respond to the concerns about youth homelessness highlighted in the Burdekin Report. This Bill would implement the social security aspects of that program.

Young homeless allowance would be increased on 1 January 1990 by $7.50 a week, bringing the total payment for homeless young people to $95.10 week-and the payment will be indexed every year from then on so that it keeps its value.

Young homeless allowance has been subject to a 6 week waiting period. To avoid the hardship that this may cause and recognising that delaying payment cannot actually resolve family problems, the government has decided to reduce this waiting period to 2 weeks. For those who have faced a history of domestic violence, sexual abuse or other similar serious problems, the waiting period would be abolished altogether.

This Bill would implement an independent rate of JSA for young people who are exempt from the parental income test because of their independent status. the rate payable would be $95.10, an increase of over $41 a week. The new rate, which would be indexed every year, would be paid from the beginning of 1990 to young people who have not lived at home for 6 months, who have worked full-time for at least 13 weeks since then and who do not get any financial support from their families.
In addition the $25 minimum rate of JSA would be indexed on 1 January each year commencing in 1990.
This Bill would reinforce the government's encouragement for young unemployed people to move back into the labour force or to continue full-time studies.

An employment entry payment of $50 would be available to people who take up full-time employment after being on JSA for 9 months or longer. Their spouses would be eligible for the same payment which acts as a recompense for some of the hidden costs involved in taking up a job.

People who receive JSA or junior rate sickness benefit for 9 months before starting work would no longer have to serve the normal 13 week waiting period if they need to reapply within 13 weeks of losing benefit.

The newstart work test concession which is currently available to long term beneficiaries would be extended to young people who have been on JSA for at least 3 months. This would enable them to participate for a total of 8 weeks each year in CESS-approved voluntary work or short training courses.
Finally, students who reapply for JSA or unemployment benefit within 4 weeks of attempting a return to study would not have to serve a second 13 week education leaver's deferment period.

In addition to this significant range of reforms for our youth, the labour market package announced in the budget continues the promotion of a more active unemployment benefit program through several innovative measures.

To encourage married beneficiaries and their partners to make the most out of the labour market opportunities that come their way through part-time work, the Bill would provide for them to earn a further $30 a fortnight between them above the usual $60 without losing any benefit.
A sole parent beneficiary whose youngest child receives JSA would receive an increase in the rate of benefit to the same rate which is paid to the sole parent of a child receiving Austudy.

To remove another inequity in this area, a sole parent pensioner or beneficiary whose only child attracts Austudy or a similar payment would no longer be paid the higher ``with dependant'' rate of benefit or mother's/guardian's allowance once that child turns 18.

To provide appropriate assistance to sole parents, formal training allowance payable for part-time training would not be counted as income under the pensions income test-bringing it into line with the way formal training allowance for full-time training is handled.

Recipients of unemployment benefit and JSA would be automatically issued with health care cards as from June 1990 without the need to apply a separate income test. Those beneficiaries along with sole parent pensioners who have received payments for at least 12 months would be entitled to health care cards for at least 6 months after starting full-time unemployment. This measure will remove a significant disincentive to regaining employment.
The Government is committed to providing adequate support for Aboriginal people in rural and remote areas.

Family payments at present can be made only to the immediate family or sometimes to an institution. More appropriate mechanisms may be available for Aboriginal children living in remote or isolated communities. From next year, bulk payments of family allowance at the higher rate would be available to Aboriginal community organisations which provide services of benefit to the children concerned. This arrangement would apply only with the agreement of the people concerned.
These measures form part of a package to lift the standard of service provided by the Department of Social Security to isolated and remote communities.
This Bill contains several other measures in the area of family payments.
From next year, parents with a child under 16 earning $100 or more a week would no longer be entitled to child payments for that child. The $100 would be indexed each year.
Child payments for a student child would cease when the student turned 16 unless Austudy or its equivalent was not payable.
Parents with children who are receiving formal training allowance would no longer be eligible to receive family payments for those children.

From April 1990, invalid pension would not be granted to people over age pension age. Currently, infirm elderly people who do not meet the residency requirements for age pension can gain access to the same rate of payment through the invalid pension system which does not have the same residency requirements. The amendment would reflect the clear purpose of invalid pension as a payment related to incapacity for work for people of workforce age.

Section 19 of the Social Security Act provides a scheme for the protection of personal information held in the social security system by making it an offence for departmental staff to record or disclose such information outside the course of their duties. Where there is a legitimate public interest reason to disclose information, those receiving it, whether officers or not, are bound by the same section 19 restrictions in passing on that information.

This Bill would close a loophole in the provisions which could allow people who have acquired personal information from officers acting in breach of the section, and who may in turn use or disclose that information, to do so without themselves committing an offence. Receiving, using or disclosing information concerning a client without lawful excuse or authority, or advertising or holding out that one has access to such information would be an offence under the Act.

The Bill would continue Labor's vigilance in guaranteeing the integrity of the social security and veterans' systems. It would provide for the imposition of an interest charge of 20% on amounts defrauded from either system through major frauds.

I now refer to the significance of 1990 in the annals of the ANZAC tradition and to the government interest in the commemoration of this historic event which is to include a visit to Gallipoli by a number of World War I veterans. The Government is concerned to preserve the integrity of the significance of this event. Misuses of the term ``ANZAC'' have already taken place. To prevent further misuses and abuses of this sort, this Bill introduces increased penalties for the use of the term ``ANZAC'' without the authority of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
