SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think this is a matter of considerable concern to this chamber and to the taxpayers of Australia. We are looking here at very large sums of money in terms of legal expenses. One can understand that a reference to the Senate Standing Committee on Privileges is not to be taken lightly. Indeed, given the turmoil within the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC), the vote of no confidence in the Chairman and the allegations of various improprieties and mismanagement, it warranted serious and close scrutiny, and I think it is fair to concede that it would have required laymen to seek the advice of those with considerable legal expertise.

SPEECH.PARA: But the matter that I think warrants further investigation is the question of the nature and extent of that legal advice. Of course, it is traditional, except for the very brave or foolhardy, to insist upon specialist legal representation by barristers or advocates when appearing before courts, tribunals or boards of inquiry. So I do not think anyone could be critical of counsel being retained for that purpose. But in respect of this question of privileges there was never a hearing. Therefore, the legal advice that was obtained was in respect of matters of presentation, preparations of submissions, the taking of evidence and consultations with various witnesses and advisers. It seems to me, from almost 18 years at the Bar in Victoria, that it is somewhat of a luxury to retain senior and junior counsel to undertake that sort of work. The normal role and function of counsel is to provide advice in the initial stages as a sort of general outline approach, to assess what the inquiry might be about, what the nature of the assembling of material might involve, and then to commission it, in effect. People go off and take evidence, statements and the rest and then, quite commonly, it is brought back before counsel for perhaps a day or two of fairly intensive analysis of all that has been obtained and further advice is given as to the manner of the conduct of the proceedings.

But in this instance senior and junior counsel seem to have been retained for a very extensive period, travelling around Australia for the purpose of various consultations and discussions. I suppose that the brevity of counsel's opinion is often in inverse proportion to the extent of the work undertaken. On the most charitable assessment, it is hardly illuminating to be told that Mr Adams, QC, charged $2,500 a day for reading documents, various consultations, conferences and tape-recordings. That description appears consistently throughout his memorandum of fees. It throws no enlightenment on the adequacy or the necessity for that work to be undertaken by, presumably, one of the leading counsel at the New South Wales Bar.

When one is talking about charging at the rate of $300 an hour for senior and junior counsel-this would seem to be not at the usual two-thirds rate; nonetheless junior counsel are being engaged separately and solicitors, expenses are running concurrently-one is talking about a very expensive exercise. It seems to me that this matter requires some further explanation. The notion that only senior counsel can conduct interviews and discussions seems to me to be overstating the position. It would certainly be a field day if one were at the Bar and maybe my view would be somewhat different then, but, in trying to be objective about the matter, I have to say that, when all we have in the accounts is basically general descriptions of that order without much condescension to detail, there is a need for further explanation.

For example, in Mr Adams's memoranda the only mention made of persons with whom he consulted seems to be of Mr Cedric Wyatt, who at one stage was the Acting General Manager of the Aboriginal Development Commission. Other than the reading of documents, conferring with Mr Howie, an instructing solicitor, and drafting a submission, there is no mention at all of any of the persons with whom conferences were held or discussions conducted. It seems to me that, if all Mr Adams was doing was reading material and talking it through with a range of people, that did not need to extend over a period of weeks, as it obviously did. The idea of charging $2,500 a day for one counsel seems to me to be verging on the extravagant. I note that there seem to have been some occasions when Mr Adams travelled interstate but did not charge an additional travel cost. On another instance, on 24 November, he charged $250 for fares but also $175 for car hire.

It is hard to escape the conclusion that if the client had been in the private sector, and not one of Australia's largest companies, there would have been a much greater reluctance to authorise this sort of expenditure. I think we need to know whether counsel's briefs were marked beforehand, whether there were any discussions about whether this was an open-ended commission, to what extent it would be necessary and desirable for senior counsel to conduct these conferences and discussions first hand or, indeed, whether they could not just as adequately have been carried out by an experienced solicitor from one of Australia's leading firms, Minter Ellison.

I have no doubt at all that under the occasional guidance of senior counsel there would have been any range of people within the firm who could have done the job just as well. Minter's, as one might expect, was not backward in rendering a bill of costs. I do not seek to quarrel with that. I do quarrel with its judgment in retaining senior counsel on what would seem to be an open-ended and pretty generous basis. It seems to me that the Parliament is entitled to an explanation.

When we are talking about fees in the order of $51,000 for Mr Adams, QC, and $44,000 for Minter Ellison we are talking about very considerable sums of money payable from the public purse. Given that the Aboriginal Development Commission has on a number of occasions been accused of extravagance and mismanagement, I have some sympathy for it in the sense that I do not think it really had much control over its own destiny other than the decision to seek legal advice in the first instance, which no doubt was a proper one. From then on it is basically in the hands of its lawyers. It would seem to me at first blush that the primary responsibility resides with the solicitors not only to investigate the matter fully and thoroughly but also to have very close regard to their obligation to minimise the costs. There would also be a temptation when one has a client in the public sector with very deep pockets not to be really troubled greatly by the cost factor. I think this does rebound on the client, the Aboriginal Development Commission, and the taxpayer down the line. That can then have very unfortunate consequences for the Aboriginal community, which could be regarded superficially as having incurred very large sums of expenses. We are talking about $160,000 in respect of a reference to the Privileges Committee which did not ever come to trial. That seems to me to be a very--

TALK.START.PARA: —So what!
—If the Minister takes that cavalier approach--
—Could it be predicted that it would never come to a hearing?

—No, but it does not follow from that that counsel is required to be engaged at ever step of the way. SPEECH.PARA: I have been involved as counsel, as I am sure Senator Durack has been, in any number of cases where I was delighted to be retained on the basis that I wandered around the country talking to various people. I find it particularly offensive for the Minister to engage in such casuistry. He misunderstood completely what I said about Minter Ellison. He said that I said Minter Ellison had played no part in this and purported to enlighten the Committee that Minter Ellison had charged $44,000. I said that 10 minutes ago. I said that one of the matters of concern was that Minter's bill was $44,000 and Mr Adams's bill was $51,000. I thought I had made it abundantly clear that it was right and proper to engage a firm of Minters considerable expertise. If any criticism prima facie attaches it is to the firm that engages counsel on an open-ended basis.

I am not prejudging this matter. Honourable senators may not be aware that the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs currently has before it a reference on the costs of justice. Some of Senator Cooney's colleagues, such as Senator Schacht, work themselves into a lather at every petty example of counsel charging anything more than the base rate and somehow regard this as yet another example of the greediness and grasping nature of all lawyers, Senator Cooney and me included. If they were to have their way no lawyers would be retained to represent people before courts, tribunals, boards of inquiry, special audits, privileges committees and the like. They would say that it was an unwarranted extravagance and that we were ripping off the system, no matter how reasonable we might think the charges to be. If Senator Schacht views charges of $2,500 with equanimity, I am delighted to hear it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Temporary Chairman. Senator Alston is discussing what might or might not have happened with a committee. We are considering the Estimates and he is straying completely from the matter before the Committee.
—There is no point of order. Senator Alston is speaking to his motion.

—Let there be no misunderstanding that no-one on this side of the chamber wants to engage in any unwarranted or unjustified attack on anyone for the conduct of these proceedings. I find it a matter of deep regret that somehow the mere raising of the question is treated as a slur, because it is not. We have an obligation on both sides of the chamber to be satisfied that costs incurred for which the taxpayer will be responsible are reasonable. That is all we are talking about. All I have said, without any element of prejudgment, is that the memorandum of fees rendered is inadequate to make this sort of judgment. When we are talking about $160,000, we are entitled to have a bit of detail.

SPEECH.PARA: If Senator Tate is trying to run the proposition that a board of inquiry or a hearing of the Privileges Committee coming up justifies the retention of senior and junior counsel over a period of months, he is putting that sort of inquiry into a completely different category. Senator Cooney would know that just because a trial is coming up it does not mean that counsel remains involved with the meter ticking for a matter of weeks beforehand. There is a conference with counsel at which the material which has been obtained is considered; there may be the odd conference with a witness; counsel then goes away-the solicitor does the work-and goes back the day of the hearing, or maybe the day before, and has another decent conference to consider the tactics that will be applied, and in some instances decides to settle the case-in my experience, Senator Cooney was rarely interested in settling cases, certainly not for reasonable sums of money-and gets on with it. It is quite out of the ordinary to suggest that senior counsel can be retained over a period of months in the lead-up.

All I am saying to the Committee is that we are entitled to an explanation. I am not prejudging the matter. Senator Tate suggested that somehow I am doing that and that I want the Senate Committee to impose its judgment. That shows an abysmal misunderstanding of what is involved in the concept of prima facie reasonable. All we are seeking is some further elaboration that will satisfy us and put at rest the concerns of those who might on the face of it say that $160,000 worth of legal costs seems pretty high. Not too many cases incur legal costs of $160,000. It is not good enough to say that as this was a reference to the Privileges Committee any sum was justified. Quite clearly, some implicit restraint was exercised in that only one silk was retained. It is not usual to retain senior counsel over that length of time and we are entitled to know why that was so.

I would much prefer that Senator Tate resumed his usual objectivity and treated this matter seriously. It is not a question of taking sides. It is not a question of defending or attacking the legal profession. I would not have thought that I could be accused of having a bias against the legal profession. All I am saying is that in the public interest, where sums of this magnitude are involved, we are entitled to a bit more information than we have to date.

The material was made available to me by the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) with a note saying, `Given to assist the senator and to this end we waive privilege'. I do not know what that means exactly. Presumably it was to assist me to make a judgment about the adequacy of the charges. Having gone through the accounts in some detail, the most that I find is `read documents', `various conferences and consultations', `listening to tapes', `read documents', `travel to Canberra' and `various consultations and conferences'. That is about the extent of it.

I would have thought that a client likes to know what he is being charged for. The client may know and may have copious notes that will tell us what was going on. However, I want to know why that work could not have been undertaken by Minters. After all, Minters did something for $44,000, which is not an insignificant sum. I simply ask why senior counsel seems to have been doing what may well have been routine work that either was undertaken in conjunction with the solicitors or could have been undertaken by the solicitors instead of senior counsel. That is all we are asking.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why wasn't it done in-house?

—I am not critical of the ADC for going outside. I do not think that it is required to rely simply on in-house advice that it might obtain. Presumably it does not have the best qualified lawyers in the land and no-one would be critical of it for that. Being confronted by a Privileges Committee hearing is a very serious matter deserving of outside and expert legal representation. I do not quarrel with any of that. Going to Minters-I regard Minters as one of the best law firms in the land-was a perfectly proper thing to do, but that does not mean one has carte blanche and from then on goes for broke and runs up whatever amount of money one likes, irrespective of its reasonableness. The public, as the ultimate payer of the bill, is entitled to know why certain work was undertaken at a particular level. All this braggadocio in which Senator Tate engages misses the point entirely. I will give him the benefit of the doubt and suggest that it is a Pavlovian response rather than a considered reaction.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not seeking to prejudge anything. I hope that I have at least an elementary understanding of the matter to the point where it raises concerns that can be examined carefully by Senator Cooney's Committee. I have every confidence that Senator Cooney and his colleagues will take this on board very seriously in the context of their current inquiry. I do not think that it will involve a tremendous amount of work. It may involve mere correspondence to elucidate some of the matters of concern. That is very properly within their scope. If they choose to reject this on the basis that this is part of an unwarranted attack, they will be doing the legal system in this country an injustice and will bring into disrepute the notion of legal representation before parliamentary committees. Ultimately they will be quite counterproductive to the cause that I think Senator Cooney and I share-that is, to see people properly represented, to see them get the best possible advice and to see that the costs they have to pay are reasonable in the public interest. That is what I am concerned to see continue into the future.

I would not like to see a situation where there is one episode that, on the face of it, seems pretty high and to some people perhaps even extravagant, and a knee jerk reaction which says, `Oh, you are just having a bit of a bash, you are playing the man not the ball, so we will reject any reference'. All that will happen as a result of that is that the Government will be seen to have buried the issue. People will say that their concerns have not been allayed, and it will be just that much harder next time around to justify those sorts of expenses being incurred.

In the interests of taking a considered and responsible approach to an issue, I think it would be perfectly proper for Senator Cooney's Committee to look at the matter. It will not do it in any sort of public atmospherics; it will do it in a careful and considered manner. The people on that Committee are more than capable of looking objectively at the issue. Given that the Government is in control of that Committee, I would not have thought that there was any risk involved from the Government's point of view. No doubt the outcome will be one that I, as a member of that Committee, will be satisfied with. I hope that the Minister will reconsider his first reaction to this, look at it in the longer term and bear in mind the interests of those who one day may well require the very sort of high powered legal representation that many of us would regard as necessary. The last thing we want to do is encourage a perception that somehow, if it is the public purse, one can go for one's life; that one does not have to answer any questions or justify any bill, no matter what size it might be. If we get to that point, I can assure the Government that there will be a very serious reaction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion. I believe that further investigations are needed into this matter. I do not need to remind the Committee that we have a responsibility to examine appropriations. When an extraordinary event involving a set of legal costs amounting to $160,000 is revealed in answer to a question on notice after the conclusion of the sitting of an Estimates committee-it has, therefore, come to the attention of the Committee of the Whole-it is appropriate for senators to draw to the attention of this chamber the nature of this extraordinary cost. I believe that this matter is insufficiently explained in the two-page answer to the question on notice given by the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) and even in the supplementary note that has been directed to Senator Alston.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Alston has spoken as fully as the available facts allow about the legal matters, and I do not wish to canvass that again. I also do not wish to canvass the conduct and findings of the Senate Standing Committee on Privileges. I am a member of the Privileges Committee and several of its members are now in the chamber. We were thorough and careful in the pursuit of the reference that the Senate gave to us. The Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) has said that there does not need to be any further investigation of this matter. I hope that the Minister is not inferring that this is not an extraordinary total bill. I hope that the Minister is not giving the impression that a bill of $160,000 for several days of legal inquiry on a matter that did not come before the Senate Committee is quite acceptable. I hope he is not giving the impression that a legal bill of $160,000 is anything other than extraordinary.

The Minister is correct when he says that the conduct of Aboriginal Affairs and of the ADC throughout most of last year-indeed, throughout most of this Parliament-has been in disarray. I make that statement without any reflection upon the officers who are present in the chamber but with direct reflection on the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand). I said in my speech during the second reading debate on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill that I have not made such a charge before of a Minister. I make it with the greatest degree of reluctance, but I happen to be persuaded of it by the facts. The disarray in the ADC followed the Minister's ideological commitment to the pursuit of his Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) legislation at all costs. What are some of the costs? Some of the costs are this $160,000 bill. The Senate is given the responsibility of examining appropriations and assessing items of appropriation. In my opinion, the Senate is not at all happy that this is one of the costs that have flowed from that disarray.

The root cause of these costs is the intervention by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, into the affairs of the ADC by sacking all but two of the commissioners-persons whom he could not sack because of the terms of their appointment by the Governor-General. This caused an immediate civil war in the ADC. Is there anyone in this chamber who wants to deny that there was a civil war in Aboriginal affairs last year? The silence is very eloquent. Of course there was a civil war. Before May last year the ADC had the very clear view that the reorganisation of Aboriginal affairs by this ideological Minister was an error, that it was wrong, that it was not in the interests of Aboriginal affairs and that it was not in the interests of the people of Australia-and it had every right to hold such a view. When the Minister detected that the ADC had that view, and because the ADC is a principal witness in this matter-this was in the period before the legislation came to us for final debate; it had been referred by us to a committee, and the views of the ADC, which is responsible for the majority of programs in Aboriginal affairs, must be taken into account-the Minister pulled the political carpet from under the ADC and sacked all its members, bar the two he could not sack, and put into the ADC cronies of his own choosing who would have his pro-ATSIC view.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Teague, there is a motion before the Chair and I think you are starting to drift away from it. The motion is the one that was moved by Senator Alston. I would ask you to stick to the motion before the Chair.

—I support the motion. In the following months the new commissioners carried out the views of the Minister. They supported ATSIC. There was an entrenched war between the two whom the Minister could not sack and the officers of the ADC who had their own conscientious views-and, of course, those officers included the principal legal adviser of the ADC. In the middle of this disarray when all these costs were run up, Mr Brendan Bailey was forced to retire from the Commission. He had to leave. He retired on 13 January 1989, so there are questions to be asked as to whether there was any competent legal advice after 13 January 1989.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that the $160,000 bill is broadly made up of three amounts: $102,000 for legal costs arising from the defence of the new commissioners that the Minister had appointed to the ADC-$102,000 to give legal representation to those who had been pushed into office to do the Minister's bidding; $18,000 to defend the interests of the Chairman and the former General Manager of the ADC, who had the contrary views; and $41,000 to defend the interests of one person, the Secretary to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, a person who was appointed, as Secretary to the Department, to be a new commissioner on the ADC, that is, Mr Perkins. So that is $41,000 for Mr Perkins's legal costs, $18,000 for Mrs McPherson's and Mr O'Brien's costs and $102,000 for all the new commissioners, which amounts to the $160,000 before us.

There has not been an explanation as to how those costs could have arisen. Putting aside the considerations of privilege-which I have already spoken about and had every opportunity to contribute to as a member of the Privileges Committee which reported to the Senate-that all stands. Without referring to anything that Senator Alston has already said about the procedures of determining responsible legal costs, that all stands. I am concerned about the unanswered questions as to how this burden on the taxpayer of $160,000 can arise and not be fully explained. I hope that the Minister is not implying that this is anything other than an extraordinary amount of money. I am not debating whether there was disarray in the ADC-there was disarray. There was a civil war between the ADC and the Department as a consequence of the determined position of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs.

If this motion is not supported by this chamber because of the numbers on the other side-and I ask the Minister to consider the merits of this matter being fully resolved by an inquiry by the Senate Committee-then it is an attempt by the Government to put yet another matter under the mat so as not to embarrass itself or its Minister. It is a scandal that there has been a civil war and such total disarray in Aboriginal affairs in this nation. This kind of cost is totally extraordinary and must be fully accounted for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very tempted to answer some of the comments made earlier by honourable senators on the other side of the chamber on matters concerning Aboriginal affairs in general, but we have had a very extensive debate on that-one of the longest debates which has ever occurred in this Senate. I will resist the temptation yet to again defend the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand). I do not think he needs further defending; it has all been put on the record and continuing smear and innuendo will not change that.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I want to make a very important point, and I know Senator Teague will be interested in this, as will other honourable senators. We have here a further motion to refer a matter to a Senate committee. Honourable senators will know that certainly on two occasions this week I sought the permission of the chamber for a Senate committee, because of the compression of time and pressure of business, to be allowed to sit while the chamber was sitting. Permission was rejected on one occasion, and on the second occasion it was granted for a committee to sit for half an hour. The reason is that we are rapidly running out of time. There is far too much for Senate committees to do and we just do not have the time. Honourable senators who are considering how they will vote on this particular motion should give some thought to the days and hours of sitting that this chamber has to complete before it ends its business this year, and the pressures on individual senators who not only have to serve in the chamber and on committees but also have to serve electorates.

This motion concerns a reference to Senator Cooney's Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee. At the moment Senator Cooney and his Committee are in deliberations-he has just arrived in the chamber--

TALK.START.PARA: —Very heavy deliberations.

—They are very heavy deliberations, on the pilots dispute. That Committee had to get the permission of the Senate in order to meet while the Senate is in session and complete its important inquiry. I am not knocking the merits of this particular reference, but I would argue that it is a physical impossibility. I am aware of the previous inquiry conducted by Senator Cooney's Committee, a committee of which Senator Alston is a member. Its report entitled Company Directors Report on Social and Fiduciary Duties and Obligations of Company Directors was brought down in this chamber earlier in the week. I am aware of the difficulties that the Committee had in meeting the deadline that the Senate itself imposed upon it. Quite frankly, I do not think that enough thought has been put into the demands that are made of senators, committees and the chamber as a whole when we move to refer things to committees with deadlines-in this case, the first day in March. Some senators not only want but absolutely need a break, and I suggest that many of those senators are members of that Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee, which is so well chaired by my eminent colleague Senator Cooney.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —I regard this morning's performance by Senators Tambling and Alston as absolutely disgraceful. It is a continuation of the drama of theatre rather than being concerned about the issues. I concede that the question of costs in any particular matter is one of concern to the Australian community and of obvious concern to the Senate, and hence a general reference was given to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. I talked about animus before-and I do not say this of Senator Alston, who has obviously been brought in to do a job, as Senator Barney Cooney quite often is by us, and act in a very professional and reasonable way at the tail end of a debate when all of us have exhausted our histrionics and hysteria in this chamber as parliamentary performers. But the fact is that the only counsel he mentioned was Mr Adams-a person who has been denigrated in this chamber before and has been the subject of comment by senators on the other side of the chamber in the Committee of the Whole, as I recall. There was no mention of the $7,500 paid to Mr Ellicott, QC; no mention of the $9,000 paid to Professor Jack Richardson; and no mention of the $4,000 paid to Chester Porter, QC. All the attention was focused on Mr Adams.
—I did not refer to anyone.

—No, but Senator Teague gave the name to Senator Alston, and that is the person he mentioned when he moved the motion on behalf of Senator Teague. The fact is that the Opposition has zeroed in on one counsel but at least three other counsel have been paid very considerable amounts of money. Without saying anything adverse about Senator Alston-I think he was acting on instructions-he could have given an impression of greater objectivity on the other side if he had mentioned the other counsel.

SPEECH.PARA: But that is not my real complaint. My real complaint against Senator Tambling is that last night we had three or four conversations about the progress of these Estimates through the Committee of the Whole. We had several discussions about what subject matters might come up this morning and the pace of proceedings so that, if he wanted information, I could get it from officials. Never once did he mention this matter. It was sprung on us 10 minutes into the debate this morning. It has obviously been prepared; it is in typewritten form. I am sure we could have been informed of this last night and had conversations with the Chairman of the relevant Senate Committee in order perhaps to come to some better understanding of what is sought and whether the Senate Committee could take it on in the context of its larger reference.

What we have here is just a continuation of the constant theatre. I did use the word `vendetta'. I am not sure that that is an inappropriate word in relation to these matters. I have since been informed that Senator Cooney is of the view that the matter could be dealt with by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, given the larger reference that it has. He is not happy that this has been foisted on him, and I am sure the other Committee members will not be happy that this has been foisted onto the wider inquiry. In deference to the expression of consent by the Chairman of that Committee, I am prepared to indicate that the Government will not oppose the motion. But I hold to the view that this could have been handled by Opposition senators in a much more professional way than the deceitful and theatrical way it has been handled in this morning's proceedings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) for his indication that the Government will not oppose the motion. I just want to say a couple of things by way of explaining my position. It needs to be understood that I had not heard of Mr Adams until I saw these documents. I am not aware of any previous attacks on him, about which Senator Tate is obviously exercised. Any vendettas that may have been conducted previously against Mr Adams or anyone else have taken place without my knowledge. Senator Tate asked why I focused on Mr Adams and not on Messrs Ellicott, Richardson and others. I have the answer that Senator Tate also has, which sets out some totals, but I know nothing more than that Professor Richardson charged $9,000 and the account is dated 20 April. That is meaningless to me.

SPEECH.PARA: But, as a result of a request for further and better particulars from the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC), it has provided me with quite a substantial wad of papers. Those papers relate only to Mr Adams and junior counsel, Mrs Katzman. It is on that basis that I have expressed the concerns that I have because I regard those accounts as inadequate as all they do is talk in the most general terms about various consultations and conferences. That is what really exercised my reference to the Committee. I am glad that the Minister has calmed down sufficiently to allow that inquiry to be undertaken. It does not need to be an extensive inquiry; the matter may well be resolved by an exchange of correspondence.

It is quite unfair for the Minister to suggest that somehow we were selective in our choice of Mr Adams and Mrs Katzman and that we omitted to mention the others. I know nothing at all about the other accounts; that should be pursued separately. I do not suggest that the Senate Standing Committee concentrate only on the accounts of Mr Adams and Mrs Katzman. All of those items should be investigated in more detail. But, having obtained a level of further detail, it was my judgment that that was inadequate to make any sensible judgment of whether those costs incurred were reasonable. It is simply on that basis that Mr Adams and Mrs Katzman have been the primary focus of attention in this debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot let this pass. I understand from officials that a phone call was made on Wednesday for the details that have been provided to Senator Alston. I do not know whether he made the phone call.
—My office.
—The phone call was made from Senator Alston's office. Quite clearly, similar material could have been provided about Mr Porter, Professor Richardson and Mr Ellicott, if it had been requested.
—We did not request information only on Mr Adams and Mrs Katzman. We requested information on legal costs incurred by the ADC in relation to the Privileges Committee; this is what came back.
—I still find it pretty remarkable.
—If I were you, when this is over, I would have words with your officers for misleading us.

—I will take Senator Crichton-Browne's advice. I have indicated the Government's position. I understand that the Australian Democrats will support the motion; so it will go through with the concurrence of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly did not anticipate that the debate on that topic would take the time that it has. The time has really blown out due to the reaction and response of the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) to the initial comments raised by Senator Alston, which were very professional, very reasonable and a proper request. However, before going on with other comments, I reject totally the Minister's assertion that I or the Opposition senators have conducted a vendetta in this portfolio. My objectivity in this regard since I became very active in the portfolio in October 1988 has been continually one of accountability and efficiency of a portfolio. As Senator Teague has said, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) has continually caused the agitation of problems that have continually needed further scrutiny by the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister would probably not concur with this, but I believe there should be a royal commission into the whole portfolio. Whilst there has been a plethora of inquiries and reviews and we now have a new mechanism, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC), coming into effect, when one considers that some 600 questions were asked in this year's consideration of the estimates-we should study in detail the index of those questions and compare them with previous years-one cannot help but be amazed at the continuing problems in this portfolio because of the lack of ministerial control and direction.

I will take another general issue first and then proceed to several points of detail. During the recent hearings of Estimates Committee E I requested that certain witnesses be brought before the Committee. The Committee, as a result of the casting vote of the Australian Labor Party Chairman of that Committee, decided that it was not appropriate for officers of the Northern Land Council to be brought before the Committee. The Minister certainly concurred with my request for officers of the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account to appear, and I appreciate his reaction and response in that regard because it was most helpful. In the area of the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account and the administration of land councils, we certainly ascertained a number of very important issues, which are highlighted in the report of Estimates Committee E.

However, the issue of the calling of witnesses was contentious. The Labor Party chose to use its numbers on the Committee and the result is recorded on pages 5 and 6 of the Estimates Committee E report. However, since that time it has again been necessary to look at the issue carefully. I am aware that the Clerk of the Senate, Mr Harry Evans, has had an exchange of correspondence with the Chairman of the Committee, Senator Michael Beahan. For the record, it is important that the exchange of correspondence become available and official. I seek leave of the Committee to table that exchange of correspondence.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I turn to the more specific matters of the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account and land council administration. History will show that the very measures that I continually use on the portfolio, accountability and efficiency, point to the need for a more independent inquiry. If the Minister does not take note of them much more seriously than he has in the last two years, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) will again have to force an inquiry on him because of the events that will take place in the next few months. Alternatively, there may be a need for a royal commission.

SPEECH.PARA: The funds flowing from the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account to the land councils are special appropriations and are in effect the mining royalty equivalents. Even so, they have already been commented upon in a very graphic report by a consultant to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Crough. Honourable senators will recall that I tabled a copy of that report some time ago in the Senate. It had been made available to me, although not by the Minister. It is obvious from the Crough report and from information that we ascertained during Estimates Committee hearings that the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account has been eating into its capital base in order to meet the increasing demands of the two major land councils. The situation as revealed by Mr Crough's report is serious. The Estimates Committee intends to keep this matter under review at future hearings.

Earlier today with respect to comments of the Australian Audit Office I commented that some of the information which was given to us by an officer of the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account and a Department of Aboriginal Affairs officer did not accord with the information available to the Australian Audit Office. That means that future Estimates committees will have to keep the matter under review. By the end of the current financial year some $85m will have passed through the coffers of the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account. By far the largest proportion of that has gone on the administration of the Northern and Central Land Councils. The Northern Land Council has obviously had major financial problems for the last year or so due to its administrative incompetence. Again, in this regard I sheet the blame home to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, because through the entire saga of his promotion of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission and various other changes he has topped up the funds to the Northern Land Council from the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account in an unprecedented manner.

The historical records to be found in the Hansard reports of the Estimates Committee hearings and Hansard records of the other occasions on which I have tabled information show that the Minister has to a large extent used top-up funds to provide for the administrative mechanisms of the Land Council. This has happened at a time when the Department and the Aboriginal Development Commission have been under tremendous administrative pressures and have experienced many problems. The Minister has used these moneys by directing them through the land councils to give him access to an alternative bureaucracy both for political advice and for stratagems in seeking to communicate with Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory. It has created huge divisions and tensions in the Aboriginal constituency in the Northern Territory. It has created huge chasms that I believe need never have been created, particularly in view of the functions of the Land Council.

The Director of the Northern Land Council bureau, Mr John Ah Kit, and I have been engaged in what could be described only as an interesting press exchange for the past few weeks with regard to the issue of administrative incompetence. My statements in the media and in other public places have been based on information that has been provided to me by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs through Estimates Committee E. Unfortunately, Mr Ah Kit has chosen to use figures that are not as comprehensive as those to which I have access through the Estimates Committee. For example, the 30 June 1989 audited report of the Northern Land Council is with the Council and Mr Ah Kit himself has acknowledged that it will be tabled in the Parliament by the end of this sitting. I certainly hope that he has consulted his Minister and that the Minister intends to honour the undertaking given by Mr Ah Kit because in the last few years those audit reports have been kept away from the Parliament until well into the following financial year. It has been acknowledged that the report is currently with the Northern Land Council and that it contains considerable qualifications and reservations with regard to the financial estimates to 30 June. Therefore, the report is very important and should be tabled so that the full position with respect to the Land Council's financial situation can be fully understood.

In the hearings of the Estimates Committee Mr Beadman acknowledged that there were considerable problems as at 30 June. I am led to believe that at that date the indebtedness of the Northern Land Council was some $1.6m. Since then, Mr Ah Kit has publicly acknowledged that the indebtedness is $1.2m, but he has totally ignored the indebtedness for holiday pay, sick pay, accrued leave, and all the other employee benefits of some $400,000 of the Northern Land Council. Fiddling with figures and misleading people is most dangerous. We therefore need on the table that fully audited report of the Northern Land Council.

For the last couple of years the Northern Land Council has received $7m per annum from its usual funding source as well as its ministerial discretionary grant top-up funding. The results of the work of the Northern Land Council have not been in any way a reflection of that funding. I have continually called for inquiries into the Land Council, but have been disregarded. The Minister has certainly not come back to me and Mr Ah Kit seems to be hiding from the issues I want addressed. I refer, for example, to the cost and extent of the Northern Land Council's political activities since Mr Hand was appointed the Minister in July 1987. I also refer to the administration of the extensive Land Council trust funds, particularly those relating to mining royalties, particularly as in the last few annual accounts of the Northern Land Council it is acknowledged that only cost accounting figures are shown with regard to the trust accounts. There is no accounting on a proper accrual basis of trust funds which the Northern Land Council administers for the some 50 Aboriginal communities in the Northern Territory. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman--
—Anything will do-just to fill in time.

—That is a little racist joke. I want to raise a matter with the Minister which I raised on a previous occasion. That is the question of what is deemed by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs in respect of the Freedom of Information Act to be in the public interest. As honourable senators would know it is with no great pleasure that I have established on a number of occasions that a number of Aboriginal communities have white advisers and bookkeepers who have improperly dealt with the finances of the association and the taxpayers' money. Almost without exception on each occasion that I have sought the auditor's report for an Aboriginal group I have found that it has been woefully inadequate: the funds have not been properly accounted for, the bookkeeping has been in a shambles and on some occasions the money has been misappropriated or it has disappeared with the bookkeeper. Invariably grants have not been properly discharged within the terms required by the Department.

SPEECH.PARA: For instance, over the last 12 months I have sought the auditor's report from the Wangkatjungka community, the Junjuwa community, the Kalumburu community, the Marra Worra Worra community and the Oombulgurri community-just to name four or five that come to mind immediately. On each occasion the audited report has shown that gross deficiencies existed in the bookkeeping arrangements and that major failures existed within the guidelines of the Department. On each occasion I have been required to obtain information under the Freedom of Information Act and to pay the appropriate fee-about which, of course, I quite properly should not complain. On each occasion I have made application for refund of the fee on the basis of it being in the public interest. On each occasion the Department has denied the refund. It has refused a refund on the ground that I have not established public interest.

I have to say, with respect, that I cannot imagine what yardstick the Department can use. If it is not in the public interest to establish that, by virtue of the disclosure of the auditor's report of the auditing and the accounting of public moneys, there have been gross discrepancies, incompetence or failure, what is? It is not because of some perverted, perverse or curious interest that I have in the matter that I have requested the audited reports. I have asked for them because I have not been satisfied that the Department's guidelines have been complied with or that the funds have been used properly on behalf of the Aboriginal community for whom they are intended.

Honourable senators will all know, of course, the result of the special Auditor-General's inquiry in the past 12 months in respect to the failure to discharge certain grants. The Auditor-General has without exception found gross failures by the Department, by officers of the Department and by members of the communities. I have brought those matters to the attention of the Senate because I think it is fundamental to the use and the application of public funds that there be proper accountability and proper disclosure of that accountability. On each occasion when I have written to the Department and sought a refund simply on the ground of public interest, it has been denied unilaterally because the Department considers it not to be in the public interest. If that is a clever trick to dissuade, to discourage or to put off people from seeking this sort of information, because there is a financial penalty for so doing, let us have it out in the open; let us know where we stand; let the Department just double the fees to make it intolerably impossible for the average citizen-never mind a member of the Federal Parliament-to learn how these funds have been allocated, whether they have been accounted for properly, whether they have been used for the purposes for which they have been intended and whether they have been applied in a proper, decent and responsible fashion.

We now know as a result of the Auditor-General's report and as a result of the release of these audited reports that there has been an abysmal failure, that there has been a gulf between standards of requirements and standards of application. So I just ask the Minister whether it is unreasonable for a Federal member of parliament to seek to demonstrate by the exposure of these reports that there is a public interest issue in question. I would have thought that the Department would have judged under these circumstances that it is in the public interest. I do not know that it necessarily ought to rest upon whether or not the audited report demonstrates some failures to deem that it is not in the public interest; but in the event that it demonstrates that there is some failure of proper accountability, surely that is in the public interest. If it is not, a less charitable person than I could conclude that it is an attempt to coverup and I hope that is certainly not the case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —The first point is that obviously there is no attempt to coverup because the documents were made available. The second point is that I think there could be a good argument that, even if the audited reports indicated absolute adherence to the highest standards of accounting and that there was no problem, it was in the public interest that that be disclosed. It is of interest to know whether Aboriginal communities are operating in a way which is impeccable in regard to accounting for public funds. I, of course, cannot substitute myself for the departmental officers who are properly vested with the function under the legislation of making decisions as to whether remission of fees is permissible or justified in terms of the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I express a view, though, that I think the sorts of matters that Senator Crichton-Browne has raised require to be given weight. I believe that the sorts of matters that he has raised are matters which should be given great weight by any departmental officer who is making a judgment as to whether there should be a waiver of fees in the public interest. As I say, I do not think it depends in any sense on the nature of the outcome of the audits. I refute the idea that there has been any attempt at a cover-up, because there has been full provision of the documents, as I understand it. I believe that, in the many relevant and proper considerations which are taken into account by departmental officers, the question of the judgment of a parliamentarian as to whether a matter is in the public interest should be given a good deal of weight in considering the competing interests which must be balanced. Obviously it is a question of balance. I express that view as to the weight which ought to be attached to the sorts of considerations which Senator Crichton-Browne has brought forward for the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not want it thought that my measure of public interest is weighted by the level of failure by officers, whoever they might be, either of a department or of the associations, to administer their duties properly. Quite to the contrary, and I think Senator Tate makes a very valid point; that is, it is in the public interest to expose and demonstrate that the funds have been applied for the purpose for which they have been intended and that appropriate bookkeeping standards are met. If they are impeccable, I think that is all the more reason for showing that there is a public interest cause.

SPEECH.PARA: Without wishing now to debate the fundamental issue which caused me to seek the documents under freedom of information, the great tragedy is that, every time it is demonstrated that there has been an improper administration of funds or even an improper use of funds, in the minds of some in the community a dichotomy is created between white taxpayers and Aboriginal recipients. That is a tragedy for all Australians. The people who inevitably get hurt when there is a lack of adequate standards and accountability are the very people for whom the funds are intended. At the end of the day the only people who are deprived are not the taxpayers-it is just that their funds are used improperly or inadequately-but the people for whom the funds are intended. For that reason it is important that there be demonstrated to all of the community that there is proper accountability and application of the funds.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak on group D. I am not sure whether Senator Tate is the responsible Minister for the arts.
—I will take it for the moment. I would like to be!

—The problem is that I want answers to my questions. I want to raise some questions about the National Film and Sound Archive where the answers I received in the Estimates committee were rather incomplete or unsatisfactory. The national collecting bodies in the arts budget are the Australian National Gallery, the Australian National Maritime Museum, the National Library of Australia, the National Museum of Australia, and the National Film and Sound Archive (NFSA). All these are bodies with a role of collecting and preserving important Australian materials, whether of cultural, artistic or historical significance. I want to bring up a curious feature in this year's Budget which involves a policy issue that could not properly be put in the Estimates committee. The policy issue concerns how the relative amounts are assigned amongst these collecting bodies.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at what happened this year. The amount allocated to the National Gallery will go up from $17.4m to $18.8m. The amount allocated to the National Maritime Museum-which is not yet in operation-will go up from $7.5m to $11.6m. The amount allocated to the National Library will go up from $28.2m to $33.7m, and that allocated to the National Museum-which also is not yet in operation-will go up from $2.8m to $3.7m. These are all substantial increases. That is understandable in the climate of the times and the economic situation. But it is surprising that the National Film and Sound Archive allocation will actually go down, from $7.36m to $6.68m. This is disturbing because of its collecting task.

All the bodies I have mentioned are collecting bodies. I do not want to give the impression that I am denigrating any of the other collecting bodies; it is the question of the relative allocation of resources that is important. The National Film and Sound Archive has a more urgent role than any of the other collecting bodies. Even while I am speaking, several cans of film will be lost forever because of the lack of funds to keep up with the urgent task of preserving them. I am not destroying them; I am merely saying that by natural processes they are decomposing in the short time I am talking. There is an enormously urgent task to stop them deteriorating and decomposing. In the few years since it was established, in 1984, the National Film and Sound Archive has made enormous progress in accelerating the copying and preserving processes, but it does not have time to waste.

I would like to ask the Minister-and I do not know whether Senator Tate can answer this on behalf of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson)-how the funds are allocated amongst the various collecting bodies. In assessing how much the Government has to give them, it must take into account how much the NFSA could be expected to gain from commercial activities. In the past the National Film and Sound Archive has seemed a very fruitful area for getting community support-non-government support-from rich film-makers, television channels and so on. I think that has been the cause of a relatively low government subvention to the organisation; in fact, there has been a fall this year. But those situations have dramatically changed. Will the National Film and Sound Archive go to Mr Skase, or Mr Bond, or whoever now owns Channel 10 for preservation?

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer is in the negative.

—I thank Senator Baume. The answer is negative. They will not get it. I think that the allocations have been distorted because of what can now be shown to be an obsolete concept through a change in circumstances-of how much community support the National Film and Sound Archive can expect. I would like the Minister to say whether he accepts this diagnosis and whether, in the changed circumstances which affect the National Film and Sound Archive and may do irreparable damage to our film and sound collection, particularly our film collection, the Government will in the Supplementary Estimates give sympathetic consideration to the changed circumstances.

SPEECH.PARA: My second question relates to questions I placed on notice at the Estimates committee hearings. I asked:

It is now five years since the National Film and Sound Archive was established. When will the appropriate legislation be introduced into the Parliament by which the now not-so-new National Film and Sound Archive will operate?
I was provided with the following answer:
The Minister has asked that a submission to the Government be prepared concerning the establishment of the NFSA as a statutory authority.

That is the normal bureaucratic response: `Let us have another inquiry'. One inquiry, whose report was called Time in our Hands, was held when the National Film and Sound Archive was set up. All these structural questions were dealt with then. Why do we need another inquiry now to gallop over the old battlefield that was dealt with in 1984? Can I have an assurance that this is not a bureaucratic delaying mechanism but that a proper structure for the National Film and Sound Archive will be addressed quickly?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —While the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) gathers his thoughts as he comes into the chamber, Senator Hamer has given me the opportunity to talk about the Sound Preservation Association of Tasmania, which is a voluntary organisation run by Mrs Gwen D'Emden, who is a marvellous and enthusiastic lady who has managed to gather a great collection of material which is--

I had the great pleasure of opening the site of the display which the Association provides in Hobart, near the Theatre Royal, for those who care to go to enjoy perusing the collection of old radiograms and listening to old records which record so much of our past-not only the great performances of entertainers but also great moments in our history, our common memory and culture. There is a special relationship between that voluntary community organisation and the National Film and Sound Archive. The former acts as a sort of outpost of the National Film and Sound Archive in Tasmania and does much work on the Archive's behalf in a way which entails very low cost to the National Film and Sound Archive but nevertheless preserves much material in Tasmania which would otherwise be lost. I take that to be the burden of Senator Hamer's remarks today.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Hamer asked whether I accept his diagnosis of the reason for increases for some other collecting bodies and a decrease for the National Film and Sound Archive. That must be a factual matter, and naturally I accept that. I cannot give an expert opinion on whether it will lead to the drastic consequences which are feared-namely, that there will be an inability to preserve materials which are deteriorating due to the manner of their composition. I am not sure that that would be the case because I can imagine that all resources are being diverted to ensure that that should not occur. I pay tribute to those Australians, particularly in Tasmania, who take a very enthusiastic and thoughtful interest in preserving the records of our past. In particular, we should compliment Mrs Gwen D'Emden and the Sound Preservation Association of Tasmania.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was asked by the Minister for the Arts, Sport and Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson), who arrived after I had spoken, to summarise my questions. With the indulgence of the Committee, I will do so. I will not repeat all I said; I will only repeat the key points. To return to the questions, if one looks at the five collecting organisations, the Australian National Gallery, the National Maritime Museum, the National Library and the National Museum-of course, the National Museum and the National Maritime Museum are not yet in operation-one will see that all have received significant increases this year, whereas the vote for the National Film and Sound Archive has been decreased from $7.358m to $6.686m.

SPEECH.PARA: My question was: to what extent is Government input to the allocation of resources to these various collecting organisations assessed on the basis of what they could reasonably expect to raise from community activities? I am in no way trying to denigrate the other organisations-I agree with the Government's intentions that all these organisations do their best to get funds from interested people in the community.
