From answers given at the Estimates Committee hearings it now appears that yet another inquiry is to be set up. The Film and Sound Archive has been in existence for five years and it still does not have a statutory basis. I want to obtain an assurance from the Minister that there is a very real determination to get a statutory basis for the Film and Sound Archive. I hope that the commissioning of another inquiry is not a normal bureaucratic device to delay having to make a decision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I share Senator Hamer's view that the natural field for fund raising in the area of the National Film and Sound Archive has been significantly reduced in recent times. Clearly, the television networks will not be in a position to provide much in the way of funds for the National Film and Sound Archive in the next few years. One would imagine that Mr Bond, Mr Skase and Mr Cosser are all engaged in fighting for their survival rather than being in the happy position of being able to devote more funds.

SPEECH.PARA: In the conversations I have had with Mr Scott in particular, it would seem that television is not the only area in which one can raise money. The National Film and Sound Archive has a degree of confidence that there are other areas in the media which will be prepared to contribute funds and that there is an affinity, if you like, in the media. Even if one is in the print media, it does not mean that one is anti-sound. Mr Scott's view was that more money could be raised. Mr Scott has a radio background and was confident that others in that industry might assist. As Senator Hamer is probably aware, a private group is also involved. Alan Rydge's company has a significant library which it is working to augment. I think Mr Scott is confident that money could still be raised from all of those areas.

I will get Senator Hamer an answer regarding how much the Archive raised from private sources in the last 12 months. I am not sure whether there is an adviser here who can tell us about that. As soon as I find out, I will let Senator Hamer know. With regard to a statutory basis for the Archive, a point that Senator Tate made with which I certainly concur, is that in recent times there has been difficulty in getting legislation through the Senate and even getting legislation listed is proving very difficult.

TALK.START.PARA: —We can go through lunchtime on Thursdays.

—I noticed yesterday that we got two Bills through yesterday during lunchtime because other senators exercised their right-and I do not complain about this-to speak during the Senate's version of a grievance debate. That being the case, only two pieces of legislation got through. In fact, the third piece of legislation was my heritage legislation, which once again was not able to be dealt with. There is difficulty in getting legislation listed. There is also some strain in terms of resources in drafting legislation. It is certainly an objective of mine to provide a statutory basis for the Film and Sound Archive. However, I will not promise that I will be able to achieve that in the near future. I think it is still some time off.

—I will clarify what I was asking the Minister. I did not actually ask him how much the National Film and Sound Archive had been able to raise from the community. I asked this question: Was not the Government's subvention to the Film and Sound Archive based on certain assumptions as to how much the Film and Sound Archive could reasonably be expected to raise from the community? Would not those assumptions have been radically altered because of the events of the last few months? Therefore, should not the Government, if necessary, consider increasing the Government's subvention, its grant, so that the Film and Sound Archive could have a reasonable income to meet its needs?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —One must take into account what the National Film and Sound Archive thinks it can raise, in looking at what is a proper amount of money to be provided by Government. As I said, in the talks I had with Mr Scott, which were, from memory, held earlier this year, he was fairly confident that its fundraising activities, which were by no means concentrated on television, would continue in a reasonable way. Therefore, I think it is fair to say that the Archive is fairly happy with what the Government is doing. Senator Hamer also referred to the supplementation of existing appropriations. In the additional estimates $230,000 is provided for the National Film and Sound Archive.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask some questions and make some comments about the Antarctic Division.

—With the Chairman's indulgence, could I just interrupt for one moment? It would be of assistance if we could deal with the whole of the Antarctic first. I know that we do not have a pilots dispute. However, we have a difficult situation with the pilots. It would be of assistance to our Antarctic Division representatives if they could get their part of the estimates over now and then head for Hobart. It would be of assistance if that could be agreed upon.

—Before the Minister got to his feet I was just about to say that. I am well aware of the problem his adviser has. I hope to finish my questioning before Question Time. I start with a bit of history. The letting of the tender for the Aurora Australis has been of concern to me for some time. I know the effect it will have on our Antarctic program, which I think everybody is looking forward to. We all know that in recent months world attention has been switched to Antarctica. Both the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and Senator Richardson, who is at the table, have made a lot of political mileage out of the environmental aspect of Antarctica.

SPEECH.PARA: In the time I have in this debate I do not intend to make cheap political points. I just repeat that the events leading up to the launch of the Aurora Australis were unusual to say the least. The fact that the Minister announced the contract of the tender for the ship to P & O Polar before the contract had been signed certainly delayed the commencement of that operation because there were some six months of protracted negotiation before the final contract was signed. It could be said that in the final analysis that cost the taxpayer around $27m. Aspects about the tendering for the vessel, including whether it could have been cheaper to build overseas, have also been raised. There is some evidence to suggest that that would have been the case. Nevertheless, I agree with the argument put that there were certain advantages in having the ship built in Australia. There were certainly some political advantages in announcing prior to the New South Wales election in which Mr Unsworth was defeated that the ship would be built at Carrington Slipways Pty Ltd.

Events have now followed on. Originally the Aurora Australis was to be completed and ready for duty at the commencement of this season, which was in October. I know that it was delayed. I think that Senator Cook, in answer to a question I asked, said that it would be around January. I ask the Minister whether January is the expected date of commencement of service of the Aurora Australis. What will happen if it is delayed further?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not certain where the figure of $27m extra costs comes from, how it is arrived at and what relationship it bears, if any, to the decision to announce the successful tenderer prior to the signing of the contract, which is of course quite normal. Had I not done so, the industry would have been in uproar. Senator Calvert cannot suggest that, with all of those people wanting the right to deal with this vessel, I could in some way keep quiet a decision to choose a successful tenderer, and then spend six months negotiating with him without the others gradually finding out. That sort of surreptitious behaviour would, in my view, have been stupid and would have provided no commercial advantage to the Commonwealth whatsoever. I will be interested to hear how Senator Calvert can tell me that that would cost another $27m.

SPEECH.PARA: The decision that it would be built in New South Wales was not for government but for the successful tenderer, which conducted negotiations with yards in New South Wales and Western Australia and chose New South Wales. The latest advice I have on the delivery dates is that P & O Polar has advised the Department that delivery is expected in the period of 1 February to 15 February.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Richardson asked me how I arrived at the figure of $27m.
—How you relate it to this.

—On 25 May I asked a question during the appropriations debate. Senator Richardson's colleague Senator Walsh was in the chair. I put it to him that, if the successful tenderer was announced prior to the negotiations being finalised, the known tenderer was put into a position in which he could extract further concessions from, in this case, the Government. Having gone back through the documents, I can say that there is no doubt that the extra concessions gained after the announcement of the tender could have been around $25m to $27m. Senator Walsh himself said that prima facie it was possible. He went on to give the sort of answer that Senator Richardson gave: he did not believe the tenderer had tried to exploit the potential advantages. Not only Senator Richardson's announcement by press release but also a letter of intent being made available to the tenderer certainly placed the tenderer in a position to extract further concessions. I am led to believe that that in fact happened.

SPEECH.PARA: I will get back to the other answer Senator Richardson gave me-that the delivery date is now the beginning of February. That is very interesting. Many people at the Antarctic Division will be pleased to hear that. I would like to know what effect the fact that the Rolls-Royce of polar shipbuilders, Wartsela, has gone bankrupt is having on the availability of the ship? As Senator Richardson realises, it was the main technical adviser to P & O in building this ship. Will it have any effect on the program?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —The fact that Wartsela is in liquidation is much more of a problem-if it were to be a problem at all-for P & O than for the Government. In any event, I am advised by Aurora Australis operators that the equipment and material supply is essentially over; the job has been done. The outstanding technical assistance is not fundamental. We believe, therefore, that the effect of Wartsela's financial situation on delivery and on the actual ship that is delivered will be either non-existent or so minimal as to not matter.

—I have another query about the construction of the Aurora Australis. I have previously asked this question: Because the ship was being custom built for the Antarctic Division and the Commonwealth being the sole charterer of the Aurora Australis, how are our interests being protected during the construction phase? In the Estimates hearings I asked why the Commonwealth did not engage an independent qualified technical inspector to oversee the construction of the ship in the Commonwealth's interest. I got such answers as, `We do not pay if it does not perform'. The answers talked about the quantum of damages and the litigious situations that could arise. I also believe that some misleading answers were given to me about the role of the ship classification inspectors. I have been very concerned about the fact that the Commonwealth has been overseeing the building of the ship-I note this from the specifications-by way of progress photographs. I believe that, as a ship of this magnitude is being custom built for the Antarctic Division, the Commonwealth's interests should have been looked after by the appointment of an independent inspector. Given that that did not happen, has the approach that has been taken been rather impractical and akin to locking the stable door after the horse has bolted or, in this case, after the ship might have been sunk?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the responsibility of P and O Polar to provide a vessel to the Commonwealth which meets the specifications and which is in accordance with the requirements of the Ship Classification Society for registration of the vessel. So both P and O and the Society have specialists on site and it is their job to monitor the details of construction. The Antarctic Division itself has a requirement for a vessel which provides the operational and functional requirements that were set out in the charter and all the accompanying specifications. So while the Antarctic Division ship project manager and other officers of the Division, in conjunction with specialist consultants, have monitored the construction in terms of those requirements, they are not responsible for the certification and registration of the vessel. It is the responsibility of P and O Polar to provide the Commonwealth with a vessel which meets the classification rules and regulations as certified by the Society and we have no reason to believe that that is not being done.

SPEECH.PARA: We have received progress photographs, which is normal in this situation. They are provided in the monthly reports that the Division gets on the monitoring of construction. They are required by the owner, in any event, as a record of construction, but they are of assistance to the Division. X-ray photographs are taken in accordance with plans drawn up between representatives of the Classification Society and the ship designer to meet the requirements of the Classification Society to survey the vessel. Given that those things are all being done together, I have no doubt that this will result in the job being done properly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just to put the record straight, could the Minister state who will certify, before the ship is taken on charter, that as built it complies technically with the requirement specification issued by the Division in the terms of the offer made by P and O Polar and accepted by the Government?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought I had already answered that. It is the responsibility of the Classification Society, not ours.

—So the Commonwealth itself will be relying on the classification inspector to certify that the ship meets all the requirements that were set down in the specification drawn up by the Division. Is that correct?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories) (11.34)-There are two requirements running separately here. The Classification Society has to certify that the vessel is okay for registration, but it will be the responsibility of the Division to say whether the requirements that were set out in the original specifications have been met. It would be the responsibility of the project officer in the Division to determine that; it is a functional requirement.

—That is all I was worried about. We are going to charter a ship that has been built to the requirements of the Division. Who will take the responsibility of saying, `Okay, this ship is exactly as was set down by the Division. This is what we wanted and it meets all the specifications'? That is really all that I wanted to find out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories) (11.34)-In order to protect the Commonwealth's position, one of the specifications laid down was that the Classification Society would approve the vessel. That builds in, if you like, another protection for the Commonwealth's position. So, in some sense, we have done even more than the honourable senator requires.

—I have a couple of other queries which relate to answers I received at the Estimates Committee in respect of the Antarctic station plans. During the Estimates Committee hearings I was told by the Acting Director that there is no doubt that we have to give more priority to questions such as the Antarctic wilderness park and the preparation of the Antarctic Treaty system. As I said in my opening remarks, this is because of the focus on the Antarctic, particularly from an environmental point of view. Resources have been diverted from the preparation of the Antarctic station management plans to the preparation of paperwork for the international meetings that are being held and also to provide support for the Government's posturing on environmental issues in the Antarctic. Since the preparation of station management plans is directed towards protecting the Antarctic environment rather than talking about it, when will the management plans for all Australian summer and winter Antarctic stations be completed?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Posturing by the Government, as the honourable senator puts it, happens to coincide with the Opposition's policy. I am interested to hear his comment. Does this mean that the Opposition no longer has a policy of supporting the wilderness park? If that is the case, the honourable senator ought to come out and tell us that; I think all Australians would be interested to hear it. Far from posturing, we regard it as important and we will continue to pursue it. When I met the French environment Minister last week, the week before, or whenever it was, he said that he believed our proposal to be irresistible.
—I hope it was just the proposal that he was talking about.

—So do I. I for one hope that he is right. Moving on to the specifics of the honourable senator's question about the plans for the stations, obviously it is a matter of balance as to what resources go into that and what resources go into this program of international meetings on the Antarctic, and we seem to be having plenty of them at the moment. Clearly, the Division has a responsibility to service our requirements on that and it is doing so. Naturally enough, that has meant some delays in the plans being prepared. I cannot give the honourable senator an exact timetable of the plans but I am assured by the Acting Director that some will be available next year and the rest, in all probability, the year after.

—I was trying to make the point that once the station management plans are put in place, we will be actually protecting the environment rather than talking about it. From a practical point of view, it is far more important to get station management plans in place than talk about the environment. We should actually be doing it rather than talking about it. That is why I was trying to find out when the management plans for summer and winter Antarctic stations will be completed. But the Minister cannot give me an answer on that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not want Senator Calvert to think that these plans, once they are prepared and published, will in some way lay down some radical changes to the way in which we operate in the Antarctic. We are in the Antarctic now. We are acting to protect the environment. The plans will reflect what we are doing to protect it and how we hope to protect it in the future. We are doing as we speak. There are those who might suggest that it is more important to continue doing than to continue writing plans; nonetheless we will do both.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that assurance. I now move on to an area that was also raised in Estimates. I refer to the strategic transport planning. The Minister will be aware that in Estimates the matter of the Antarctic Division's budget for the conduct of Hercules flights to Casey was mentioned. I think the Acting Director mentioned a figure of $100,000 for the hiring back of construction equipment that was recently disposed of by the Division after I questioned him on that. During the discussions on the possibility of Hercules flights to Casey I asked whether any studies had been done in the past into the use of Hercules aircraft into Casey. I was told of a previous study on a compressed snow runway. Its major conclusion was that it was viable to make a compressed snow runway. I have since learnt that in the plans the Government has in place for flying Hercules into Casey it will not be using a compressed snow runway.

SPEECH.PARA: I also asked whether any studies had been done before on the use of Hercules aircraft into Casey. I did not receive what I believe was a proper answer. I am aware now that there was a study conducted for the Antarctic Division in 1985-a review of Antarctic air transport operations. One of the conclusions it made on the matter of an airfield at Casey was that it was impracticable as a regular transport link for operational reasons. The main reasons related to the poor and unpredictable weather conditions in the vicinity of Casey and the fact that it could lead to a high proportion of delayed and aborted flights. There was some mention about that during the Estimates by the Acting Director. He did say that this was one of the problems. The fact is that the findings of the 1985 study do not indicate that flights by Hercules planes down there are all that viable. I just want to know why, when I asked those questions about Casey, I was not told about this 1985 study. I would also like to know why, it having been said a compressed snow runway is viable, it is proposed not to use a compressed snow runway.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is proposed to use one. That is the main point. I go back to Senator Calvert's concerns about not being informed of the earlier study. The earlier study was actually looking at a different physical location of a proposed runway. The 1988 team of defence people found when it went down to have a look that there was a better position that was even closer to the base, so it settled upon that new position. As I understand it-I cannot claim to be an engineering expert-the compression of snow will be critical to the preparation of this ice-snow runway. It is a combination of techniques in which compressed snow is critical. It is at a different place to that which was looked at in the 1985 study. I hope that that answers Senator Calvert's queries.

—It does in part. I remember asking a question of the Acting Director at the time about whether there had been any flights into Casey by Hercules and whether the Americans had cancelled flights because of their concern about safety. I think the Minister said that it was before his time. I wonder whether since then somebody has had some recollections as to whether that was the case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just found out some very disturbing information which is a bit of a worry.
—You are talking about the politicians, I presume.

—Yes, that is right. As I understand, it the Americans did have some ski equipped planes going in. They were cancelled for two reasons. One was a safety concern and the other was that they did not like the idea of flying politicians in. They thought that there were better things to do. In any event, the Australian Government is not looking at ski equipped planes but at planes landing with wheels on this compressed snow-ice runway. We do not believe that there ought to be any problems with safety as a result of that.

—I believe that when the politicians' flight left there was a white-out and bits and pieces of the plane were left all over the runway. Fortunately for the politicians it actually made it back. In conclusion on that particular area of flights to the Antarctic, the Minister would be well aware of the much publicised flight that Dick Smith made to the Antarctic. I wonder how credible that was in retrospect. I really think that he may have been a bit lucky. Does the Minister think that one flight by one intrepid adventurer is any reason on which to base a regular transport link?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Dick Smith's flight certainly had great value-and I do not want to downplay it-but he was very fortunate in going at the right moment when the conditions were particularly good. Obviously we could not guarantee those sorts of conditions on a permanent basis. Nonetheless, the trip was of value. We would obviously be putting in a forecasting centre for the Hercules flights going down. Mr Smith's use of Twin Otters was encouraging as far as the Division was concerned. It is one of the reasons why the Division has recommended a change from using long-range helicopters between the bases to using Twin Otters. While we would not take the Dick Smith flight on its own as a basis for future actions, certainly there were benefits for us all in looking at his experience. Hopefully we will be able to benefit from that experience by using Twin Otters between the bases.

—I am a little concerned about this whole question. Perhaps the Minister can tell me more. Since 1985 has there been a significant upgrading in the weather forecasting in the area? The weather does change quickly. It is probably the main problem with the whole exercise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we are looking at a period of time over which we build up capacity for forecasting. There will be a forecaster at Casey for the trials this year. For the following season we would hope to have a proper forecasting centre in operation. I do not think it is possible to do that for this season in the time available but there will be a forecaster there and we will build on that for the following seasons.

—The only other matter I wish to touch on concerns some answers I received in the Estimates Committee hearing relating to the infamous voyage of Icebird No. 5, of which the Director would be well aware. I believe that some of the answers I received were a little vague, and I can understand why. There was a bit of a misunderstanding about that. Was Icebird on Casey voyage No. 5, 1988-89 deliberately slowed down on the instructions of the acting director and the acting logistics manager?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the critical point here is that the Icebird could not leave on its next proposed voyage any earlier. For that reason the acting director suggested that Icebird should optimise its time in the Casey region.
—Given the fact that it may have been slowed down, did the voyage leader and the captain question or object to the slowing down of the voyage?
—Yes.

—Does the Minister agree that if the objectives of the voyage had been pursued expeditiously and advantage taken of the good weather and sea conditions, as it should have been, it would have been possible for the ship to be back in Hobart four days earlier than it was, as maintained by the captain and the voyage leader-that is, before Christmas?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot give a personal assurance on this matter, but I am advised that the Division would have very serious doubts as to whether time savings of the order Senator Calvert is mentioning would have been possible.
—Is a copy available of the report of the voyage leader or the captain? If so, would it be possible for me to get a copy?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I would be happy to make a copy of the report available to Senator Calvert.

—I appreciate the cooperation of the Division in providing me with the documents I have queried on this matter. I conclude by saying that I hope the Aurora Australis commences work very soon. Whilst I do not believe the Director is concerned, I am concerned about this season and what effect the delay in the construction of this vessel may have on the Antarctic season and the extra pressure that may be putting on the Division.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we would all like to have seen the Aurora Australis finished a little earlier, but in a massive undertaking of this kind delays have to be expected. I think the Division moved swiftly to ensure that the effect of this delay was minimal. I do not believe that any more could have been done.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —It being 11.55 a.m., pursuant to sessional order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Temporary Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.
The Temporary Chairman having reported accordingly-

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, as luck would have it, my question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, representing the Prime Minister and the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer the Minister to Mr Peter Morris's reported comment on the court decision in the pilots dispute that, while the Government opposes the use of penalities against unions, anyone who chooses to go outside the system must face the consequences. I ask the Minister whether he recalls the Prime Minister saying on 20 August, after meeting with the airlines in Melbourne-incidentally, that was a Sunday, the day before the Industrial Relations Commission hearing at which the pilots were to appear-which was set for the Monday-and I quote:

QUESTION.PARA: I say, without equivocation, that when the airlines decide to initiate those legal processes with significantly very drastic financial penalities against individual pilots and their organisation, the airlines will be pursuing those legal processes with the full support of my Government.

Can the Minister confirm that this was the day before the pilots were required to meet an Industrial Relations Commission deadline on their nine to five campaign, in other words, when the dispute was still before the Commission and within the Government's much loved system? Why is the Government now trying to squirm out from under the fact that, even before the Commission processes had been completed, the Prime Minister gave the strongest possible endorsement to the use of common law remedies? Is it not further a fact that the common law is available, and has always been available, to be used by any party in an industrial dispute, regardless of whether the parties happen to be in or out of the centralised system? Does the Minister agree that, like it or not, the Government is now stuck with the fact that its Prime Minister has given total support for the use of such remedies in industrial disputes?

TALK.START.PARA: —I must apologise firstly to Senator Chaney for being a minute late.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. In the light of the obvious and mounting public concern about the situation in Cambodia, does the Government have any ideas as to how the settlement process in Cambodia could be further advanced and the present stalemate in negotiations broken? Is the only possible form of transitional government one that gives a place to the brutal and genocidal Khmer Rouge? Would it not be a better reflection of reality, and create a better climate for the settlement of the Cambodian problem, if the seat in the United Nations (UN) presently held by the CGDK-the Coalition Government of Democratic Kampuchea led by Prince Sihanouk, Son Sann and the Khmer Rouge-were declared vacant?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —All of us share a passionate conviction that the killing in Cambodia has gone on too long, that it must stop and that a workable, durable solution-to ensure that it never happens again-must be found. All of us share an equally passionate conviction that Pol Pot and the other genocidal butchers of the Khmer Rouge killing fields should never again be allowed to exercise power in Cambodia.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia has been among those countries working hard to try to find such a solution. Bill Hayden took a series of initiatives through the mid-1980s which were very important in helping break the log-jam which then existed, and more recently I have been involved in what seems like an endless series of meetings and conferences-with the regional countries, the permanent members of the Security Council, other involved and interested countries such as France, India and Canada, and the four internal Cambodian parties-trying to craft a strategy which will bring the conflict to an end once and for all.

At the Paris conference two months ago we came very close to succeeding. A comprehensive settlement strategy was mapped out involving, in broad terms, the monitored withdrawal of all Vietnamese forces; a cease-fire; the cessation of external support; the creation of a transitional administration; and the holding of free elections-all under the supervision of an international control mechanism. That settlement strategy foundered for a number of stated reasons. But only one of them was really crucial: one side to the conflict, the combined resistance forces of Prince Sihanouk, Son Sann and the Khmer Rouge, together with their international backers, demanded a place for each of the four internal parties, including the Khmer Rouge, in the transitional administration; this was a demand which the People's Republic of Kampuchea Government of Hun Sen, and its international backers, were not prepared to concede.

Since then there has been a resurgence of fighting. The external backers of the internal Cambodian parties have continued to supply them with arms and materiel, and positions have hardened rather than softened. A number of international efforts have been mounted to renew the dialogue process, some of them very public, others much less so. We particularly applaud the efforts that are being made to find ways through the impasse by Thai Prime Minister Chatichai, the Paris conference co-chairmen, Foreign Ministers Alatas and Dumas, and United States Secretary of State Baker. It is my sincere hope that these efforts will lead to real progress, but so far none have borne fruit.

International opinion remains overwhelmingly in favour of a comprehensive settlement-in which all the outstanding issues would be simultaneously addressed-as the support for the Association for South East Asian Nations (ASEAN) resolution in the United Nations last week made abundantly clear. But at the same time it is becoming obvious that some of the detailed elements in the kind of comprehensive settlement proposal that has been on the table to date may need some re-thinking if the new deadlock is to be resolved. Everyone acknowledges that the problem causing most difficulty is the composition of the transitional administration, and in particular the role proposed in that administration for the Khmer Rouge-even on the basis that the Khmer Rouge would have but a minority voice in a quadripartite administration, and that it would be shorn of its former leadership.

In the last few weeks I have been exploring with a number of my ASEAN and foreign ministerial colleagues, and with others including the Deputy Prime Minister of the Hun Sen Administration in Cambodia, Mr Kong Som Ol, and US Congressman Stephen Solarz, whether it might not be possible to create a form of transitional administration, still within the framework of a genuinely comprehensive settlement, which did not give rise to the same objections and apprehensions as the existing proposal on the table. I further discussed this whole issue this morning with the heads, or their representatives, of all the ASEAN diplomatic missions to Australia, outlining to them the possible approach that I now put on the public record, and which I will of course be following up with my foreign ministerial colleagues.

The idea that I have found most attractive, and which I believe deserves very close examination by all the participants at the Paris conference, is one that would involve building a transitional administration directly around the authority of the United Nations-some variation of the kind of UN administration which previously has been put in place in comparable circumstances, most recently in Namibia. Such an arrangement would mean that no Cambodian party would be in a position to decide the country's destiny pending free and fair elections organised by the UN and held under international supervision. It would involve a compromise by the present Hun Sen Administration-being prepared to step back from its present role as the de facto government of the country-and by the three resistance parties, which would not have a role in the transitional administration either.

The proposal addresses concerns about the Khmer Rouge being in a position of even marginal, transitional authority, which so many people have found abhorrent for obvious reasons, given its appalling record. It also clearly preserves the objectives of a comprehensive settlement and, crucially, provides the framework within which the external players, including China, may be prepared to draw back from the conflict. The idea is not, in fact, dissimilar from one suggested to me by Prince Sihanouk, at a meeting I had with him in early August in his residence in Paris, that Cambodia be placed under a form of `UN trusteeship'.

It would be difficult, if not impossible, for the UN to play the role envisaged for it were the Cambodian seat to remain occupied-as it is at the moment in New York-by one contesting group, the CGDK. Australia has never accepted the claim of either the CGDK or the Hun Sen Government to be the legitimate occupants of the UN seat, as was made clear on the last occasion the issue was tested-in 1982. Other countries have in the past taken different views about the occupancy question. But, as became very clear in the corridors of the Paris conference, there is very little, if any, dissent from the view that any international control mechanism to supervise the transition to peace in Cambodia should be under the authority of the UN, and that a logical corollary of this is that the Cambodian seat at the UN should be declared vacant, or at least occupied by whoever constitutes the transitional administration, for the duration of that transition period.

As the Australian permanent representative to the UN, Dr Wilenski, stated in the General Assembly on 15 November, Australia assumes `that as part of a comprehensive settlement a change in seating will take place-either the seat will be declared vacant or will be occupied by the interim authority, until elections install a legitimate government which can take its rightful place in this body'. If the UN itself were to be the interim authority, it follows that the Cambodian seat would have to be declared vacant. These are ideas that I shall be further exploring with my counterparts in the weeks and months ahead. A sane and civilised way through the present impasse in that tragic country must be found, and the Australian Government will not rest until it is.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister and the Treasurer. —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Consumer Affairs, relates to the large variety of infant and children's toys now being retailed for Christmas shopping. Is the Minister concerned with the safety aspects of many of these toys, particularly those imported from countries which do not comply with a strict code of manufacture and safety testing procedures? Will the Minister indicate any steps his Department may have taken to protect consumers and their young children from dangerous and potentially fatal toys and to inform the shopping public how they can identify such items?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Colston for raising this issue because it should be of concern to the community and to government. It is not a minor issue. The cost to the community of accidental injuries is in the vicinity of $9 billion per annum and injury from products is an important part of that cost. The Government has approached the problem in a comprehensive and coordinated way. We have recognised the need for a system of injury surveillance and prevention as operates in both the United States and the United Kingdom. We also recognise that with a comprehensive system there can be benefits to all levels of government, to industry, to the community and, of course, to individuals.

ANSWER.PARA: To this end we have taken a number of measures. The first, and probably the pivotal one, is to fund the Australian Institute of Health and the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs to assist in a pilot program on injury surveillance. It is based on information being available at selected casualty departments in hospitals in some States, and this program over its short term of operation has already logged and analysed in the vicinity of 150,000 inputs on injuries and their details.

The Commonwealth is taking the matter one step further by funding the Australian Consumers Association to analyse the data that the national injury surveillance prevention project (NISPP) holds and its own records primarily to identify products that are either defective or hazardous. The NISPP data has been the starting point for a Federal safety standard-and this goes very much to the heart of Senator Colston's question-for children's toys that was announced and made applicable earlier this year. In essence, it is a standard that protects children, particularly smaller children, from the dangers that are inherent in toys that are sold to their parents for them. That standard is mandatory and applies to items produced either inside or outside Australia. So toys sold in this category have to comply with the safety standard.

Senator Colston raises a broader question of enforcement. We have responded to the enforcement problem in two specific ways. In implementing that standard Bureau officers conduct random checks. In fact, quite recently, we had to ban a toy the paint on which had something like 40 times the permissible levels of lead. That toy has been taken off the market. In the lead-up to Christmas there is a greater need for parents to be alerted to the hazards involved in toys. At the moment the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs is conducting a regular annual survey of toyshops to locate which toys may pose a hazard. I expect the results and details of that survey to be announced in the near future. They should be available before Christmas so that parents can be alerted to them.

The other aspect of government response in this area is a fundamental one-that is, to educate the community, and particularly parents, about safe toys for children. To that end, we have been conducting a campaign and have in fact published a booklet for parents to alert them to the hazards inherent in buying toys. As I said at the start of my answer, the question is a fundamental one in that the range of injuries arising from accidents in our community results in a massive cost not only to the families and individuals involved but also to the whole budgetary process.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a good question, but shorten the answer.

—If Senator Boswell would stop interjecting I probably would shorten it. In fact, I probably have one line to go. We will be announcing the results of our survey to alert parents further to the dangers involved, particularly at this time of the year.

—Is the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories satisfied that the report of the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) Legislative Assembly Standing Committee on Conservation, Heritage and Environment on the so-called National Aquarium meets all environmental concerns? Is the Minister aware of the names of the aquatic biologists whose opinions were sought? Did these biologists in fact give any opinions? Are these opinions available for public scrutiny? Is it a fact that there has been a substantial change in the lease purpose of the National Aquarium since application was first made by the developer? Finally, is the National Aquarium proposal subject to the Commonwealth Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act? What other Commonwealth legislation is applicable to a development with potential consequences in three Australian States as well as the Territory?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate Senator Sanders giving my office some notice of this question; but it arrived only five minutes before Question Time, so I have to say it was not much notice. I cannot answer all parts of the question, but I will do my best.
—Does that mean you can be quick?

—I am not going to take a long time over it, but I am going to answer the question, which Senator Sanders is entitled to ask. I was asked in the first part of the question whether I am satisfied with the ACT Assembly's report on the National Aquarium. The reality is no, I am not. Because I am not satisfied with the Assembly's report I have asked my Department to assess it to make sure that the Murrumbidgee and Molonglo rivers are adequately protected. I am not saying that I believe they are not; I just do not know, and I think that the citizens of the ACT are entitled to know, as also are the citizens of New South Wales, who could well be affected by where the rivers flow.

ANSWER.PARA: As Senator Sanders would know, this matter arose in the first instance as a proposal for a trout farm. Certainly, an environmental assessment was conducted into a potential trout farm. What we now have is a National Aquarium and tourist development, which has also been physically moved to the other side of the river from where the original assessment was done. There appears to be some debate as to when exactly that change occurred and how much assessment of that change has been done. That is why I asked my Department to assess it for me. I expect an answer from the Department next week, and I hope to be in a position before the end of next week to make a statement on what I believe should occur.

I do not know the names of the biologists. That is one of the things I could not find out in the time I was given; so I cannot answer that part of the question. As I have already said, my Department's report next week should tell us exactly when this change occurred and whether or not any assessment was done of it.

Senator Sanders asked whether the proposal is subject to Commonwealth legislation. The answer to that is yes. As to what other Commonwealth legislation might be applicable to a development, I suppose the usual gamut applies. The Foreign Investment Review Board would be concerned if there was foreign money in it, but I do not think there is, so I doubt that. I do not think that the National Aquarium wants to export, so I cannot imagine that export controls are going to apply either. I think we are essentially relying on the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act, which does apply, and next week I will determine whether or not I will make an order as to its application.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first part of the question relates to the corporations power and whether it should be used to protect the National Estate forests in the south-east. Apart from that, he has given no advice to the Australian Government and I do not think he will be giving any advice to the Australian Government in the near future. However, I understand he has given, or is about to give, some advice to the Opposition at a seminar to be held in January entitled `How to be a Minister'. I hope Opposition members will listen very carefully to his advice at that seminar because they have got a long way to go. Sir William Cole has already given some advice to the Opposition. His advice to the Opposition is, `Don't change the capital gains tax. Don't introduce this speculative gains tax because it will distort investment decisions and--'
—Senator Lewis is very sensitive on this issue. Perhaps he has got a few quid to make.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The comment made by the Minister in relation to Senator Lewis, casting aspersions on Senator Lewis's motivation, is clearly disorderly and clearly ought to be withdrawn.
—I withdraw the remark, if it is offensive to Senator Lewis.
—Mr President, with due respect, I did not ask for the comment to be withdrawn, but that addition to it makes it worse.

—Mr President, I withdraw, but what a ridiculous objection from Senator Puplick. —I do not know whether the Leader of the Government is being tasteless or disorderly, Mr President, but I suspect it is a bit of both. I suggest you remind him that he is supposed to be here answering questions.

I remember that a few years ago members of the Opposition got some advice from Professor Russell Mathews on how to manage the Australian economy. Professor Russell Mathews told them then that, if they wanted to manage the Australian economy properly, they had to have a capital gains tax. They ignored that advice. I assume they will ignore the advice given by Sir William Cole. But they need this advice very badly and should heed it if they hope to be good Ministers.

—Senator Lewis keeps interjecting. I see that he is getting conflicting advice from all over the place. He is getting advice from Sir William Cole on how to be a Minister and not to get rid of the capital gains tax. He is getting advice from Sir Henry Bolte on how to make a transition into government. I can imagine Senator Lewis, in his new role as shadow Minister for transition to government, going down to see old Sir Henry Bolte on his farm and Sir Henry taking him out and saying, `Look at these pigs of mine here, Austin. They all have their snouts in the trough. We have to look after all these pigs with their snouts in the trough, Austin, because they represent 2 per cent of the animals on this farm. We have to look after them and get them big and fat. You see those sheep over there, Austin, representing 98 per cent of the population of this farm. Well, Austin, together we can look after the pigs and pull the wool over the eyes of the other 98 per cent. We can pull the wool over their eyes and look after the pigs who have got their snouts in the trough'. That would be the sort of advice that Senator Lewis would get from dear old Sir Henry Bolte.

—Has the Minister for Resources seen reports of predictions by the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) that exports of energy commodities will continue strongly for the next 10 years? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —A report by the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics entitled Projections of Energy Supply and Demand Australia 1989-90 to 1999-2000 was released on 9 November. Its major findings were that domestic energy consumption will rise by an average of 2 per cent annually. Australian energy production will grow at an annual rate of 4 per cent. The major increases in exports are expected to be in black coal, uranium and natural gas-natural gas due to the North West Shelf project reaching full production and export. The rate of energy efficiency in Australia, which has not been as strong as the Government would have liked to have seen in recent years, is expected to improve as energy prices, mainly for oil, begin to rise slowly. ANSWER.PARA: I am advised that the statement by Mr Gengos was in the context of a question by the Coroner regarding what would it have taken to detect the falsifications of records alleged at the inquiry to have occurred, how many officers did the CAA have available to conduct surveillance on Oxley Airlines, and what would have been the likelihood of successfully detecting the falsifications.

It needs to be understood that The Civil Aviation Authority establishes and promulgates standards relating to air safety. The industry, that is, individual pilots and operators, have the responsibility to adhere to those standards. The CAA also monitors the industry's adherence to prescribed standards and takes the necessary action when it is found that the standards have not been complied with.

I am advised that in May 1989 it was found that officers of the NSW Field Office had interpreted a section of the Civil Aviation Orders regarding specific equipment in aircraft differently from all other Field Offices. This became apparent as a result of the operation of a Queensland based operator, operating into NSW. The Canberra Office of the CAA clarified the policy in this area and advised all Field Offices accordingly. The Coroner accepted this clarification and went on to say that the lack of Australian Distance Measuring Equipment in the Oxley Airlines aircraft was not illegal, nor was it a factor in the accident. Mr Gengos gave factual evidence on this and all other matters addressed.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of the Bill is to implement changes to the operations of the Australian Heritage Commission as agreed by the government following a comprehensive public review of the Commonwealth Government's role in the conservation of the national estate.
Each of the amendments proposed in the Bill is concerned with one or more of the following matters:
clarification and improvement of the Commission's operational procedures;
the inclusion of powers for the Commission to administer the National Estate Grants Program
the removal of a sub-section unnecessarily discriminating against Aboriginal sites;
the exemption of authorities of the self-governing territories and Australian Airlines from the requirements of the Act, in accordance with government policy; and
administrative changes to clarify certain operations of the Act and correct some minor technical defects.

Before examining the provisions of the Bill in detail, let me first explain the history of, and the principles underlying, the Australian Heritage Commission Act and the reasons why the proposed amendments are considered essential.

The Australian Heritage Commission Act was passed by the Commonwealth Parliament in 1975 following a major public review conducted during 1973 and 1974 by the committee of inquiry into the national estate under the chairmanship of Mr Justice R. M. Hope. The principal recommendation of the committee of inquiry was that a commission be established to administer national estate matters and that its enabling legislation contain provisions obliging all Commonwealth agencies to act so as to ensure maximum possible conservation of all items in the national estate.

Subsequently the original act was amended in 1976 following a review by the new Government of Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser. The amendment act of 1976 re-affirmed the key elements of the original act as recommended by the Hope Committee. The main amendments related to:
the removal of specific powers from the Commission to advise the Government on expenditure and grants of financial assistance. (The current Bill aims to restore this power);
a reduction in the number of Commissioners from 19 to 7;
a provision to limit the Commission's power to enter aboriginal places in the register of the National Estate. (The Bill aims to repeal this provision);
the removal of permanent head powers from the Chairman of the Commission; and
a provision requiring the Commission to seek the approval of the Minister before appointing Committees (the Bill aims to remove that limitation).

Since 1976 there have been a number of other changes to the Act but these have concerned specific administrative issues such as public service reform. They have not affected the fundamental principles of the Act.

The Commission thus remains comprised of a part-time chairman and up to six part-time Commissioners with various skills and interests related to the natural, aboriginal or historic environment. The Commission's main responsibilities can be summarised as:
preparing and maintaining a register of natural estate places;
advising the Commonwealth Minister responsible for the environment on all matters relating to the National Estate;
advising other Commonwealth Ministers and Government authorities on Commonwealth Government proposals which might affect the National Estate; and
developing policies and programs for research, professional training and public information and education;
In addition, the Act requires that:

before a Commonwealth Minister, department or authority takes any action which might significantly affect the National Estate values of a registered place the Commission is informed of the proposal and given reasonable opportunity to consider it.
The Act also requires that:

no action be taken by a Commonwealth Minister, department or authority that adversely affects a place in the register, unless there is `no feasible and prudent alternative', and if there is no such alternative then all necessary measures must be taken to minimise the effects.

These responsibilities of the Commission, Commonwealth Ministers and agencies have remained unchanged since 1976. However, they were again subject to review in 1978 and 1979-this time by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on environment and conservation, chaired by the Hon. John Hodges MP. In general, the Committee concluded that the Act and the operating procedures of the Commission were satisfactory and appropriate. All the recommendations of the Hodges Committee for amendments to the Australian Heritage Act will be implemented by this Bill.

In June 1985, the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, the Hon. Barry Cohen, MP, announced yet another review of the Australian Heritage Commission Act. The purpose was to assess whether, after ten years, the mechanisms were still adequate and appropriate and to recommend changes where necessary.

The Minister invited public submissions from all interested parties including State and Territory governments, local government, conservation groups and development groups. Over 150 submissions were received and a two-day seminar held to discuss the review attracted over 100 participants. The report of the review, which also took into account the Hodges Committee report and representations made to the Government on the operations of the Act, was distributed to all interested parties in August 1986, with an invitation for comments before final recommendations were made for amendments to the Act.

Honourable senators can readily see that the amendments proposed in this Bill have not been lightly arrived at. Since its passage by the Parliament in 1975 the Australian Heritage Commission Act has been the subject of intense public scrutiny and almost constant review by Government or the Parliament. This process has identified a number of desirable changes to the Act to improve the Australian Heritage Commission's efficiency and effectiveness. However, it has also demonstrated beyond doubt the Commission's essential ongoing role in the Commonwealth Government's efforts to conserve and protect the National Estate.
The Commission's achievements have been considerable:

It has established a substantial database of places of National Estate significance. This includes over 9,000 places entered in the register of the National Estate and the interim list of the register of the National Estate.

Using its database, the Commission provides advice on the National Estate to a wide range of Commonwealth Ministers, Departments and authorities. In 1988-89 the Commission provided such advice under section 30 of its Act on 336 occasions.

In addition, the Commission's expertise on National Estate matters is acknowledged by State and local Government and private firms and individuals. The Commission's advice is often sought even though there is no statutory requirement. This occurred 83 times in 1988-89.

Educational activities to foster understanding of the National Estate have also been at the forefront of the Commission's priorities. The publication of The Heritage of Australia-the Illustrated Register of the National Estate in 1981 followed by individual State editions for Tasmania, South Australia and the Northern Territory, and Western Australia have been significant milestones. Film co-productions such as The Land of the Lightening Brothers and the highly acclaimed Nature of Australia: Portrait of an Island Continent have added substantially to Australians' awareness of and concern for the National Estate.

As the Commonwealth Government's principal advisory body on matters related to the National Estate, the Australian Heritage Commission has often faced a difficult task in carrying out its responsibilities. The Commission has been required to provide the Government with National Estate advice on some highly controversial issues-the destruction of the Bellevue Hotel in Brisbane, the Franklin Dam and the wet tropics of Queensland to name but a few. Nevertheless, its activities are not limited to such issues. Much of the Commission's most effective work is carried out in collaboration with Government and the private sector, out of the public limelight. This often leads to real achievement in the conservation of the National Estate-without controversy, without confrontation and without any public attention or fanfare.

This has been recognised by the Government in considering the review of its role in the conservation of the National Estate. While some legitimate concerns have been raised about the Commission's operations, these can be readily addressed through the amendments proposed in this Bill. The fundamental need for the National Estate to be conserved through the continued operation of the Commission is undeniable. Community and Government support for this proposition has grown even stronger since its initial articulation in the Hope Report of 1974.

This is not to say that there has not been some misunderstanding of the Commission's role. Indeed, I suspect that this misunderstanding, particularly regarding the effect of having a place listed on the register of the National Estate, has been deliberately and mischievously fostered by some development interests opposed to Commonwealth Government actions to conserve the National Estate.

Of course, this is the nub of the matter. People and organisations opposed to the Government's overall environmental policies often cannot or will not distinguish the basic concept of the register of the National Estate from decisions made by government on issues involving the National Estate. In fact the Australian Heritage Commission simply identifies the National Estate and advises on National Estate values. It has no power of intervention or proscription. It is the Government which is responsible for deciding about ``feasible and prudent alternatives'' to actions affecting National Estate values.

It is also incorrect to claim that listing on the register of the National Estate somehow locks up areas or forecloses options for economic and social development. There are many examples throughout Australia of listed areas being used for economically productive purposes which do not have an unacceptable impact on the heritage values of the area.

Calls for greater ministerial control of the Commission or the inclusion of other than National Estate criteria-for example, economic significance-in the registration process are therefore particularly ill founded. Parliament advisedly gave the Australian Heritage Commission an independent statutory role in registering places of National Estate significance and bringing them to the attention of Commonwealth Ministers and agencies. The judgments required in registration decisions are not and should not be political. They should be objective and backed by expert scientific assessment. Only through such a process can heritage values be considered alongside other values-land use, economic and so on-when Government decisions are being taken.
Turning now to the specifics of the Bill, clauses 1 and 2 deal with the short title and commencement date.
Clause 3 relates to interpretation and raises a number of issues.

The definition of `authority of the Commonwealth' will be amended to remove the authorities or bodies established under the laws of the Australian Capital Territory, the Northern Territory and Norfolk Island and Australian Airlines from the requirements of the Act. This is in accordance with the Government's policy of treating the self-governing Territories as States in most respects and with its decision to make Australian Airlines more commercially competitive.

Terms used in the proposed new part of the Act dealing with the National Estate Grants Program are also defined. Definitions of the interim list and of the term `owner' as used in describing those persons that the Commission must inform before publishing a notice of intention to register a place are also included.

Clause 4 of the Bill will insert into the Act specific criteria against which places under consideration for entry in the register will be measured. This will clarify the definition of the National Estate already included in the Act and will reflect procedures which have been used by the Commission for some time.

Clause 5 will reinstate the original wording of paragraph 7 (A) of the Act as originally passed and extend its provisions to allow the Commission to give advice on identification of the National Estate as well as its conservation, improvement and presentation. The reinstatement of subparagraphs concerning advice on expenditure and financial grants will be consistent with the Government's decision to transfer the administration of the National Estate grants program to the Commission.
Clause 5 will also insert specific functions in the Act for the Commission to administer the NEGP.
Clause 6 makes it clear that the Commission may enter into contracts. The Act has no specific provision for this at present.
Subsection 22 (5) of the Act provides for the removal of a place from the register. Clause 7 of the Bill will provide for the removal of part of a place from the register.

Clauses 8 to 12 of the Bill reflect the need recognised in the review for the operational procedures of the Commission to be more ``transparent'' to public scrutiny. Hopefully these changes will help inform people of the Commission's role and avoid some of the misconceptions I noted earlier.

The proposed amendments provide detailed procedures for the entry or removal of a place in the register including the notifying of owners, the provision of location maps and statements of significance, the handling of objections, the appointment of independent assessors by the Minister and clarification of the operation of the interim list.
Although objections to proposed registrations may be submitted on any grounds, the Bill makes it clear that the Commission must give prime consideration to the National Estate significance of places.

Clause 8 also provides for the repeal of subsection 23 (5) which currently restricts the Commission's ability to enter Aboriginal sites in the register. This subsection was introduced as an amendment in 1976 to avoid possible conflicts between decisions by the Commission on the registration of land and recommendations by Land Commissioners on Aboriginal land rights. The subsection is an unnecessary discrimination against Aboriginal sites and, on the experience to date, its removal will not result in the conflicts forecast in 1976.

Clause 13 of the Bill will legitimise an existing practice whereby the Commission is normally given an opportunity to comment on proposed actions by Commonwealth ministers and agencies that might significantly affect a registered place. The proposed amendment will require the Commission to provide comments as soon as practicable.

Clause 14 deals with the National Estate Grants Program and will transfer its administration from the Urban and Regional Development (Financial Assistance) Act to the Australian Heritage Commission Act. No major changes are proposed to the nature or administration of the program except a provision for the Minister to make grants to approved bodies directly as well as at present through State and internal territory governments.

Section 39 of the Act includes a requirement that the Commission must obtain the approval of the Minister before entering into a contract involving the payment or receipt of an amount exceeding $50,000. Clause 15 of the Bill will increase the amount to $200,000, reflecting inflation and the growth of the Commission.
Clause 16 will permit the Commission to appoint committees without restriction, returning to the original 1975 wording of the Act.

Clause 17 will correct technical deficiencies in public notices published prior to 20 November 1979. These deficiencies were minor in nature and the Bill will validate the notices which included them.

Mr President, this Bill re-affirms the basic principles underlying the Australian Heritage Commission Act while at the same time introducing a series of improvements to the operational procedures of the Commission. These improvements will clarify the Commission's role, make it more open and more accountable yet retain its independence as the Commonwealth Government's principal advisory body on the National Estate.

Australia is fortunate in having a unique heritage which in large part has not been degraded or destroyed like some other countries. However, this means that we have an even greater responsibility to protect it for future generations. This Bill should be seen as a measure of the Commonwealth Government's determination to do so.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
I present the explanatory memorandum for the Bill.
