Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill amends the taxation laws in a number of respects.

This Bill contains the measures announced in the 1989-90 Budget for a new tax collection system for companies, complying superannuation funds, complying approved deposit funds and pooled superannuation trusts, in conjunction with a move to full self-assessment. The changes also apply to trustees of unit trusts that are taxed as companies.

Other Budget announcements that the Bill deals with extend income tax deductions for fees paid to professional tax advisers and for expenses incurred by life assurance companies in gaining the investment component of certain premium income. Another Budget measure recognises the nature of certain share based financing arrangements as loans rather than as equity investments for tax purposes.

The Bill also proposes amendments on the subjects of superannuation tax, approved deposit funds, the gift provisions and the prescribed payment system. Minor amendments as a consequence of earlier changes to the Social Security Act, and of the reduction in the top marginal rate of personal income tax on 1 January 1990, are also included.
Since the Budget, detailed consideration has been given to the most appropriate arrangements for the payment of tax by companies and superannuation funds.
In this process, the Government has considered the submissions of leading business organisations and professional bodies.
In the light of these further deliberations, the arrangements contained in this Bill differ in several respects from those outlined in the Budget Papers.
These differences address concerns expressed about the original proposal and were the subject of announcements by the Treasurer on 2 November 1989 and by the Acting Treasurer on 22 November 1989.

The major modifications announced respond in a significant way to the submissions of the business and professional bodies whilst preserving the fundamental basis of the new tax arrangements for companies and superannuation funds as an important initiative in improving the equity of the tax system.
I turn now to the details.
Collection of tax
The new system will first apply to assessments in respect of income of the year of income ending on 30 June 1990.

An initial payment of tax is to be due by the 28th day of the first month after the end of the income year-generally 28 July-equal to 85 per cent of the notional tax amount, that is, broadly, the tax payable on income of the preceding year at the current year rate, or 85 per cent of the taxpayer's estimate of the actual tax liability.
Payment of the balance of tax due for the relevant year is to be made by the 15th day of the ninth month after the end of that year-generally 15 March.

For early balancing companies and funds, payments are to be due on equivalent dates after the end of the substituted accounting period, but no initial payment will be due earlier than 28 January following the end of an accounting period.
Late balancing companies and funds will be on the same relative footing as all other entities that are subject to the measures.

Specifically, the dates for their initial and final payments of tax will be determined on the basis of their substituted accounting period, but in all cases final payment will be required not later than 15 June of the year of payment.

For tax payments attributable to the 1989-90 income year, or substituted accounting period, companies and funds with a notional tax in the range $1,000 to $400,000, or that have a notional tax of $400,000 or more but estimate their actual liability to be within that range will be given an option as to the basis of paying their tax.

They may make the two payments on the 28th day of the first month and the 15th day of the ninth month as outlined earlier or they may pay their total liability on the 15th day of the sixth month after the end of the year of income, or substituted accounting period.

In subsequent income years, the option to choose either of the two methods of payment will be available to companies or funds with a notional tax in the range of $1,000 to $20,000, or that have a notional tax of $20,000 or more but estimate their actual liability to be within that range.
There will be no liability to make an initial payment of tax where the notional tax or estimated total tax is less than $1,000.

Companies and funds in this situation will pay their total tax liability by the 15th day of the ninth month following the end of the income year, or substituted accounting period, subject to the payment being not later than 15 June of the year of payment.
The gain to revenue from the new system of collecting tax is estimated at $855 million in 1989-90 and $150 million in 1990-91.
Self-assessment

Under self-assessment of income tax returns, which has operated since 1986, taxpayers lodge a return which is not generally subject to technical scrutiny and determine their taxable income. The Commissioner of Taxation simply calculates the tax payable and issues an assessment.
The changes announced in the Budget merely take the present arrangements one step further for companies and funds under the new collection arrangements.
These entities will calculate their own tax payable and pay this amount to the Commissioner, in an instalment, if applicable, and a balancing payment with their return of income.
An assessment, which will retain all existing rights of objection or appeal, will be deemed to be made on the day the return is lodged.
To facilitate this change, the Bill makes provision for the self determination of foreign tax credits, and the offset of franking deficit tax against company tax liability.
These are not significant changes to the existing self-assessment system, but they do present an opportunity for other major improvements, to which I now turn.
Amendment of assessments
In debate over self-assessment, calls have been made for a review of the concept of ``full and true disclosure'' which exists in the present rules for amendment of assessments.
The Government accepts that this concept has reduced relevance in the context of a system of self-assessment, and has decided to remove it from the amendment rules for all taxpayers.

The Bill will give effect to this decision and will alter to four years in all cases the limitation period applying generally to amendments increasing a taxpayer's liability, other than in cases of fraud or evasion or other special provisions where the right to amend at any time is retained.
The Commissioner will be able to seek an extension of this new four year statutory limit from the Federal Court of Australia, or by agreement of the taxpayer.
Consistent with this change, the period in which an amendment may be made to reduce a taxpayer's liability is to be increased from three to four years.
Keeping of records
In line with the changes to the time limits for amending assessments, records relating to tax information will be required to be kept for only five years, instead of the present seven years.

This period will be extended where the period for amendment is extended by the Court or under agreement with the taxpayer. The rules for the keeping of records are also being modified to require companies and funds subject to the new collection and self-assessment arrangements to retain for subsequent review documents used to calculate their taxable income and tax payable that they do not have to provide in simplified returns.
Other changes
Some related matters raised by the new system are under review.

Of particular importance are reviews being undertaken by the Commissioner of Taxation in relation to the information currently required to be furnished with returns generally, the tax agents' lodgment program, and the operation of present arrangements for the remission of penalties.
Under existing arrangements, a taxpayer in doubt about the proper tax treatment of a particular matter may request advice from the Commissioner.

The Commissioner is also reviewing the question of providing an avenue-by means of the remission of interest payable where an assessment is amended-to encourage entities subject to the new self-assessment system to lodge these requests ahead of their returns, and will release further information on this matter as soon as possible.

Some other issues which have been raised in the context of self-assessment are nearing settlement. In particular, you will be aware that the professional bodies have been working closely with the Commissioner on audit access guidelines and they have now been released.
Tax advice

Hand in hand with these arrangements goes the Budget proposal to allow tax deductibility for the management and administration of a taxpayer's income tax affairs, which also will be given effect in this Bill.

Examples of expenditure that will be an allowable deduction are fees paid to a recognised professional tax adviser for income tax advice, costs of disputing an assessment such as tribunal fees and court costs, and costs associated with an audit of a taxpayer's affairs by the Taxation Office.

Deductions will not be allowed for capital expenditure but depreciation of items, such as a computer, used in connection with the management or administration of a taxpayer's income tax affairs will be allowable.
No deduction will be allowed for expenditure incurred in relation to an offence under a law of the Commonwealth, a State or Territory or of a foreign country.

A related amendment will permit taxpayers to have amounts paid for professional advice concerning the impact of taxes on the acquisition or disposal of an asset included in the cost base used to calculate the taxpayer's capital gain or loss on the assets.
These changes will apply to expenditure incurred on or after 1 July 1989 and the cost to revenue is estimated to be $40 million per annum, commencing in 1990-91.
Life assurance companies

As announced in the Budget life assurance companies are to be allowed a taxation deduction for expenditure incurred on or after 1 January 1990 in gaining the investment component of life insurance premium income. This measure will put life assurance companies on an equal footing with other investment mediums but it does not extend to friendly societies and other registered organisations which benefit from a lower tax rate.
The revenue costs of this proposal are estimated at $30 million in 1991-92 and $125 million in 1992-93.
Share based financing arrangements

Share based financing arrangements entered into to obtain finance are more appropriately regarded as lending arrangements than as investments of share capital. It follows that dividends paid under such arrangements ought to be treated in an equivalent manner to payments of interest on loans.

Consistent with that concept, and as announced in the Budget, the dividend imputation system is to be modified so that all dividends paid in respect of shares issued under share based financing arrangements carry no entitlement to imputation credits or the intercorporate dividend rebate.

This measure will apply to dividends paid on shares issued on or after 16 August 1989 or under finance arrangements entered into on or after that date, and will prevent losses of revenue the potential size of which cannot be quantified but could have become substantial.
Tax exemption for approved deposit funds

The Bill also gives effect to a measure, announced on 26 June 1989, to enable more people to take advantage of the special tax exemption given to qualifying fixed interest approved deposit funds under the May 1988 changes to the tax arrangements for superannuation.

The amount of exempt income of a qualifying approved deposit fund is calculated by reference to balances that remain from time to time of amounts that were on deposit for eligible depositors at 25 May 1988. To assist people who may have withdrawn amounts from an approved deposit fund after 25 May 1988 before the special exemption was announced, the existing law treats withdrawn amounts that were redeposited in the same approved deposit fund before 1 July 1989 as though they were on deposit on 25 May 1988.
An amendment in this Bill extends the 1 July 1989 deadline for redepositing such moneys to 1 September 1989.
As details of people who took advantage of this extension are unavailable it is not possible to estimate the revenue effect of this measure.
Taxable contributions to superannuation funds
The Bill will also correct a technical deficiency in the superannuation tax provisions.

The amendment, announced on 16 October 1989, will ensure that fully funded complying superannuation funds cannot avoid tax on contributions by exploiting the tax exemption intended to cover cases where an employer does not fund benefits until retirement. Under the exemption, the fund is not assessed on the contributions and the benefits paid are treated as `untaxed' benefits and subject to a higher rate of tax.
This aspect of the law was drawn to the Government's attention because of concerns at the potential effect on the superannuation industry.
The intention of the law in this area has always been clear, and the amendment to the Bill is therefore to apply from the commencement of the new arrangement for superannuation funds on 1 July 1988.
Gifts

An amendment to the gift provisions of the income tax law is proposed by the Bill to allow gifts of the value of $2 or more made on or after 7 April 1989 to funds that provide money for the acquisition, construction or maintenance of hostels for school students from rural areas.

The proposal is part of the Government's $637 million Education and Training Strategy for Rural Australia announced in April by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy.
The revenue cost of the proposal is estimated to be less than $500,000 in a full financial year.
Owner builders

Finally, the Bill will modify the prescribed payment system provisions of the law to ensure that a householder will not be treated as an owner-builder if the actual work on a major part of a domestic construction project is actually carried out by a builder or by others on his or her part.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum, which contains more detailed explanations of the provisions of the Bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Knowles) adjourned.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

INTERJECT.PARA: The disastrous consequences for interest rates paid by home buyers, farmers and small businesses of the continuing lack of action by the Hawke Labor government to deal effectively with the balance of payments and foreign debt crises.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw particular attention to the fact that the matter of public importance being debated here this afternoon refers to the `disastrous consequences for interest rates paid by home buyers, farmers and small businesses'. We hear a lot about the disastrous interest rates being paid by home buyers. There is no question that those rates are disastrous; there is no argument about that. But I often think that that charge is too narrowly based. After all, home buyers are paying what for them is a disastrous rate of 17 per cent. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has recently seen fit to do one of his rather grubby deals with the four major trading banks whereby those banks will receive, in addition to their pre-tax profits, $230m or thereabouts in the next full year in return for some kind of undertaking by them that they will not raise the home interest rate even higher than its already exorbitant level, at least for the time being.

SPEECH.PARA: If I may say so, I think we should in passing spare more than just a thought for the other groups mentioned in the matter of public importance-namely, farmers and small businesses. They are not paying interest rates of 17 per cent but are paying interest rates of anywhere between 21 and 25 per cent. What is more, the Treasurer is not doing deals on their behalf to keep the rates down even to those very high levels. I hope that when people in South Australia tomorrow and in Queensland tomorrow week are considering how they should cast their ballots, they might consider very seriously sending a message to Canberra on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —They will.
—As Senator Parer says, they will. I think he is quite correct in that regard.
—They will, except you will be the one who will be getting the message.

—Notwithstanding the interjections from an over-excited senator across the chamber, there is not the slightest doubt that the people of this country understand where these interest rates are coming from. They are coming from the Treasurer and the Government of this country. There used to be a bumper sticker that had a certain appeal. It was in the terms `Don't vote-it only encourages them'. I certainly hope that tomorrow and on Saturday week people do not vote Labor because, if they do, it will only encourage the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, and the Treasurer, Mr Keating. SPEECH.PARA: Even over the past six weeks or so interest rates have not so much been pushed higher but have been very strongly shored up at their existing very high levels by official action. TALK.START.PARA: —For months now Ministers have been holding out in one way or another the prospect of some decline in interest rates in what was, at the time in question, the not too distant future. In fact, we can go right back to the Western Australian elections in the earlier part of this year, when in late January in Perth the Prime Minister forecast that interest rates would fall before the end of 1989. Subsequently, of course, the Prime Minister has had to admit that that forecast was totally incorrect, as events have proved, and was made simply in a desperate-and, indeed, a barely successful-attempt to keep the Dowding Government in office. However, those promises are beginning to ring very hollow. Yesterday, in the light of the balance of payments figures which were published for the month of October, the Acting Treasurer (Mr Dawkins)-Mr Keating being overseas, and I will come back to that later-pointed out in a press release as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Government does not believe that today's figures provide any basis to allow moderation of monetary policy.
There could not be anything much clearer that that. Mr Dawkins was saying that there will be no reduction in interest rates on the basis of those figures. He continued:
Today's current account outcome, even though an improvement-
that is debatable-
continues to be above sustainable levels.
He concluded by saying:
Consequently the Government is determined that policy will continue to be directed at reducing our current account imbalance and the related build up in Australia's external debt.

What he means by those words is that that will be done by reducing overall demand in the economy, and hence the demand for imports, through the maintenance of these present crushingly high interest rates. That is almost a matter of little remark today, because people have become numbered by these interest rates to the point where they no longer really look for any reduction in the near future. In today's Australian Financial Review, Mr Steve Burrell has written an article, obviously based upon some discussions he has presumably had with `senior officials', as he calls them. He states:
Monetary policy is set to remain tight well into 1990 . . .
Later he says:

There is a strong view among senior officials that the Government must err conspicuously on the side of caution on monetary policy, keeping interest rates at present levels until it is absolutely clear that the slowdown evident in some sectors has spread throughout the economy.
While the authorities concede there is a risk that keeping interest rates high well into the middle of next year-
I ask you to mark those words, Mr Deputy President, `well into the middle of next year'-
could tip the economy into a deep downturn, they-
the senior officials he is quoting-
believe the risks of easing policy too early and too fast are greater.

What has Mr Keating said about yesterday's figures? Mr Keating, of course, was in London yesterday. He has been embarking upon a little globe trotting, I think principally with the objective of keeping out of the country while the election campaign in South Australia is going on. Mr Keating had very little comment on the figures themselves. He contented himself with talking about wages policy. He said:
The obvious point of all this is that if you can't run a proper wages policy, you can't run the Australian economy. Wages are the key to reducing inflation.
He is, of course, quite right in those two comments. Wages are part of the key to reducing inflation. The other part, of course, is productivity.

TALK.START.PARA: —He never talks about that.

—He never talks about it, as Senator Parer says. In the last 24 hours there has been a remarkable event which does have some bearing on the capacity of governments in this country and, indeed, citizens, to run a wages policy, that is, the judgment by Mr Justice Brooking in the Supreme Court of Victoria yesterday-what I call the Hawke-Brooking judgment-which will have some bearing upon that matter. I do not have time in these remarks to expand further on that matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Other people have made judgments about the Australian economy today. The Business Council of Australia in its latest bulletin has produced a major article on the so-called accord, entitled, `The Accord-Success or Failure?'. In the executive summary to that article the Business Council of Australia talks about Australia's relatively poor performance in nominal wages growth, productivity, unit labour costs, inflation, interest rates and, therefore in international competitiveness. It states:
The growth in investment and employment-
which are supposed to be a couple of the hallmarks in this area-
has also been achieved at the cost of high external debt which has left us vulnerable to adverse movement in the world economy.
It concludes with the following:
. . . the price being paid for the Government's special relationship with the trade union movement-
that is the process by which we run a wages policy according to the Treasurer in London yesterday-
includes allowing the ACTU, and not the Government, to determine the nature and pace of labour market reform.

The conclusion of the Business Council of Australia is that the costs of the accord are now increasingly outweighing its benefits. There is no dissent on that point. A debt summit is being called by the Business Council of Australia next March in order to attempt to energise the Australian public to the serious nature of the debt crisis beginning to confront us. Indeed, it has been confronting us for some years now.

Sir Arvi Parbo, one of the very senior members of the Business Council of Australia and the Chairman of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, when discussing this matter a week or so ago on radio, said: `Australia's name stinks today overseas'. What a deplorable position when probably the most respected businessman in Australia-I do not wish to be drawing invidious comparisons but I think most people would agree with that-is asked a question of that kind on public radio and has to say that Australia's name stinks abroad today. No wonder Mr Keating has gone overseas trying to drum up a bit more confidence in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has been overseas so often that that is why it stinks.

—I note that interjection but will not expand upon it. The Macquarie Bank Ltd issued a very well researched document on the foreign debt problem entitled Australia's Economic Challenge: Agenda for Action. In the media release accompanying that document the Macquarie Bank states that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . on its present course Australia's foreign debt will double to $200 billion (or 44% of GDP) within five years and $500 billion (or 59% of GDP) by the year 2000.
It also states that:
This will take it past the 15 most heavily indebted developing countries which currently are unable to service their debts.
Mr Tony Berg, the Bank's Managing Director, said:

If fundamental changes are not made in the way we manage our economy, Australia will soon have a level of foreign debt which would put us in the ranks of Third World countries which currently cannot pay their debts.
That is the yawning abyss-

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a yawn, that's for sure.
—That is the kind of yawning abyss under the kind of policies which have been put in place by the present Hawke-Keating-Richardson Government in the past 6 1/2 years.
—And Bannon is the Federal President.

—As my colleague reminds me, Mr John Bannon, the Premier of South Australia, is the Federal President of the same Party which has presided over this destructive process for the past 6 1/2 years. What have we heard from Mr Bannon? Have we heard him criticising this process? Have we heard him in any way arguing with his colleagues, as Mr Dunstan did in a somewhat similar desperate situation perhaps a decade ago? Have we heard him actually getting up and criticising the Australian Labor Party in Canberra? Not a bit! Mr Bannon supports it to the hilt.

SPEECH.PARA: We have had another document published in the last week or so by Citibank Ltd predicting a doubling of Australian assets owned by foreigners in the next five years. In other words, Citibank arrived at very much the same conclusion as did Macquarie Bank. Goldman Sachs, one of the major four or five New York investment banks, has talked about the same topic. This week the Melbourne Sun, under the heading `Hawke Blow', stated:
A leading United States bank has predicted an economic nosedive for Australia next year.
And it's the Government's fault, according to influential investment bankers, Goldman Sachs.
The bank's ``Autumn Statement 1989'', says Australian authorities had:
Allowed a prolonged period of excess demand growth to persist;
Failed to respond to signs that activity had rebounded strongly in the wake of the 1987 share market crash;
Maintained easy monetary policy for too long during 1987-88 . . .
The newspaper article went on to say:
The report said current tight monetary policy had led to concerns that `a sharp economic slow-down' was imminent.
It compared Australia with the UK under the heading `Two Peas in a Pod' but said Australia . . . was the more likely to face a recession in 1990.
Australia's centralised wage fixing policy would make a recession more extended, it said . . .
These worries have been accentuated by a sharp recent decline in both consumer and business confidence in both countries the report said.
The writer of the article said:
The assessment will come as a severe blow to the Hawke Government, which quoted Goldman Sachs extensively during the 1987 election campaign.
The bank's International Economic Analyst, released in the middle of the campaign strongly endorsed the Government's economic management.
Whether it was wrong or right in its endorsement at that time, there is not the slightest doubt that the Government cannot now turn around and describe this as an unrespectable source.

What have been the consequences of all this? We have debt growing apace, we have the foreign debt clock ticking. We have a current account deficit of, let us say, $20 billion-it is probably more than that-for this financial year. That means that debt is accumulating in this country at $55m a day. That is the rate at which the clock is ticking. We are accruing debt at the rate of $2.3m per hour; $40,000 a minute. In the 20 minutes that it takes me to complete my speech our foreign debt will have clocked up by about $800,000. That is the pace at which things are going.

Where is all this debt coming from? It is coming from the fact that we are not paying our way in the world; we are not internationally competitive. As I said just a moment ago, we have a deficit in our balance of payments of at least $20 billion; it is probably more like $22 billion today. The Government says that we will see a slowdown in imports in the second half of the financial year and that will improve things. But where will the slowdown come from? If it was going to produce a really sharp fall-off in imports in the second half of the year, it would already have had to have started because there are lags in these matters. So the only way in which we can now achieve that kind of downturn in imports is if we have a real crash in the second half of the year. I am not suggesting that we will have a crash, but I am saying-and I can see the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) shaking his head-either we will have a crash or we will not achieve the forecast. One or the other must be true.

The result of this is that the Government cannot now let interest rates fall. If it let interest rates fall, the Australian dollar would take a nosedive of a major kind. Indeed, the Prime Minister more or less said exactly that the other day in his address to the National Farmers Federation. He said that that, of course, would then result in interest rates being driven up again-which is true. It might be said, `It is okay to criticise, but what would you do?' Indeed, we often have that kind of slick charge or response from the Government or, for that matter, from the toy politicians on my left, the Australian Democrats.

That reminds me of the example of the patient who has been going along to a doctor for 6 1/2 years and who suddenly finds that he has cancer. He goes to another doctor for a second opinion and then says, `What are you going to do about it? The first doctor has neglected me for 6 1/2 years and allowed me to get into this state, now what are you going to do about it?'. Mr Deputy President, I suggest to you that the first thing that person should do about it is change his doctor; sack the first doctor. Let us get that quite clear for a start.

I agree that, given the state to which the Australian economy has been reduced at present with interest rates at their present level and unlikely to begin to decline until well into the next year-the Australian Financial Review says the middle of next year-no-one will have a magic wand to produce a dramatic change in that situation, given the mess that Mr Hawke, Mr Keating and Mr Richardson have created. Mr Richardson has probably done more to destroy this Government's economic credibility--

TALK.START.PARA: —`Senator' Richardson.

—I beg the honourable senator's pardon. Senator Richardson has done more to destroy this Government's economic credibility in the course of the past three months than any other single member of the Government through his malign effect upon the decision in relation to Coronation Hill and other such matters. The first thing to do is to sack the doctor. The Opposition, in addition to helping sack the doctor, is going to give tax cuts, fully financed by spending cuts. It is going to return the proceeds of bracket creep. We are not just talking about fiscal policy. We are talking about a wholesale reform of industrial relations. We will be very much helped in that regard by the Hawke-Brooking judgment of yesterday. We are talking about micro-reform, real reform, of the waterfront, of coastal shipping and of the airlines, a major program of privatisation to induce some competitive spirit into government business enterprises. And we are talking about a productivity break-out-a word this Government never uses.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it staggering that anyone in the Opposition, particularly Senator Stone, could ever raise the spectre of what ought to be done about micro-reform. If ever any group in Australia's political history avoided micro-economic reform like the plague, it was the Fraser-Howard Government of 1975 to 1983-not one achievement in the field of micro-economic reform. We have just had a little list from Senator Stone. That is about all we can get. We cannot get written, definite policies on what the Opposition will do about any of this. All we have is a list from Senator Stone. He says that it is slick of the Government to say, `What are you going to do about it?'. The great difficulty facing Senator Stone and the Opposition is that over the course of the next six months the Australian people are going to demand to know what it is going to do about this. The Opposition will have to do better than recite a list. That will not work. It will have to say something definite.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I move on to some of the things that have been said by the Opposition, let me try to put this debate about debt into some perspective, not in any way to attempt to downplay the debt problem but at least to make sure that we understand what the problem is we are seeking to deal with. Australia's gross external debt of $137 billion represents a net debt of about $108 billion after we take into account our official reserve assets, et cetera. That is a debt ratio of about 32 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP). That is about 2 per cent less than the peak in 1986. Debt as a proportion of GDP is dropping. At the end of 1987-these are the last figures available-any suggestion that Australia's performance in world terms on external debt was in any way bad can be immediately dismissed by a comparison with other Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) countries. Australia's gross external debt as a proportion of GDP was almost exactly equal then to the OECD average. It was lower than the figures for Belgium, Denmark, Finland, Greece, Ireland, New Zealand, Norway, Portugal or Sweden. It was half that of Argentina and Mexico-the two countries that Senator Stone keeps raising as some sort of reasonable comparison.

Senator Stone has referred to the Macquarie Bank predictions of a few days ago. I think the bank suggested that external debt may get as high as 59 per cent of GDP by the year 2000. I suppose that in this game of economic forecasting anything goes. That is the Macquarie Bank's best guess. That is fine. Research done for the Economic Planning Advisory Council suggests that debt is more likely to stabilise at around 30 to 35 per cent of GDP by the mid-1990s. When we look at our external debt burden, we see that the Commonwealth is, in fact, a net creditor. In round figures there is $18 billion of debt offset by $21 billion of reserves. So we get down to the real problem. When members of the Business Council of Australia sit down to their debt summit they will look carefully at each other around the table, because sitting around the table will be those who carry 62 per cent of Australia's external debt. They will have a good long hard look at themselves.

The Commonwealth Government has been actively paying debt abroad, to such an extent that its foreign currency debt has fallen from $15 billion at the end of June 1987 to $9 billion at the end of June 1989. By the end of this financial year Commonwealth debt on issue will be equal to only 13 per cent of GDP-less than half of what it was four years ago. In fact, total Commonwealth debt just will not exist in four years time-provided, of course, that there is a responsible Labor Government re-elected, and provided that that responsible Labor Government continues to deliver Budget surpluses of the order that we have had in the last couple of years. None of what I just said seeks in any way to trivialise the problem of debt burden but it does seek to place it in some sort of realistic position, whereas what we are getting from the other side is sensationalist posturing.

The issue is clear: in order to slow the build-up in our debt we must reduce our balance of payments deficit. That, of course, is what the current settings of Commonwealth policy are aimed at doing. There are a number of key features. Let me run very briefly through those. First, we have been running, and will continue to run, the tightest fiscal policy since records in Australia have been kept. No other government of any political persuasion can claim to have run anything like the tight fiscal policy of this Government. Secondly, we have also had a workable wages policy which has delivered realistic and competitive wage outcomes at a time of unprecedented jobs growth. There we have just one of the glaring weaknesses of the Opposition's approach to this problem. The Opposition has never been able to come up with anything like a wages policy. All it can ever come up with is a bash the unions recipe for industrial relations disasters-for strikes, confrontation and the assurance of economic ruin. Thirdly, monetary policy is set firm to play its proper role in moderating demand. Last financial year it ran at 8 per cent compared with product growth of 3 per cent.

The Government concedes that it did not pick the strength of demand in the Australian economy. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) certainly did not pick just how well his policies had been received by the business sector, just how much they would kick demand along. But, in the end, if the biggest admission we have to make is that we did what we did too well, perhaps things are not as bad as some may seek to paint them. Fourthly, the Government has sought to lift product growth. We have had the most comprehensive economic reform program in Australia's history. It is long overdue. When one looks at the record one realises that the great sadness is that Labor has been in government so rarely that the real opportunities have been missed. Senator Stone's forebears, such as Black Jack McEwen, refused absolutely to look at the manufacturing base. All they cared about were minerals, wool and primary products. Consideration was never given to building up a manufacturing base. They had no policies on manufacturing. Such policies were totally ignored for three decades. That is what conservative government gave Australia. That is when the opportunities were missed.

This Government has been saddled with the task of reversing those decades of lost opportunities. To do that the first thing we looked at was structural reform. There has already been a comprehensive reform of the taxation system. We have had financial deregulation, we have had airline deregulation and we have had oil industry deregulation. We have reformed ports and coastal shipping. There have been productivity based wage rises, award restructuring, cuts to import tariffs, and a better skilled work force-one can go on and on. This is the first government to tackle any of those problems. But more than that, we have fostered greater investment. Investment was brought to a halt by the Fraser Government years. At the end of them there just was not any. Investment was completely stopped. Business lost all confidence-and not forgetting the million workers who were pushed out of work in the last two years of that Government. Investment has been stimulated by corporate tax cuts and imputation and by a fundamental rebalancing in the wage-profit share.

Last financial year business investment was 13 1/2 per cent of GDP. This year it is expected to be 13.9 per cent. We compare those figures with the slump of under 10 per cent that the Fraser Government years brought us. Domestic savings have been encouraged by tax cuts, more people being in employment, a fundamental shift towards superannuation savings and being able to deliver Budget surpluses. Those policies will turn around Australia's balance of payments deficit and in turn reduce the build-up in our external debt.

It must be remembered that the policy stance adopted by the Government not only is successfully addressing the problems of our external debt and balance of payments but also has led to a vigorous restructuring of Australian industry and has resulted in the creation of 1 1/2 million new jobs since the Government came to office. Before we came to office a million jobs were lost. We have reversed that trend by creating 1 1/2 million. That is what the Hawke Labor Government has delivered. But there is no suggestion in any Opposition policy, even in its rhetoric-no Opposition member has had the decency to mention it-of getting more Australians back to work. That is something that has never concerned conservative governments in Australia. It certainly does not concern the current Opposition parties.

In the last 24 hours we have had a balance of payments figure of over $2 billion. There has been a fair degree of hysteria from the Opposition about that figure. That hysteria is not shared by the National Farmers Federation whose leader, Mr Allwright, last night stated how relieved he was that the figure indicated a turnaround. Looking at the seasonally adjusted result, there is some room for optimism. It is still not sustainable-no-one in the Government would suggest that-nonetheless it suggests that there are better times ahead.

The main contribution to this outcome was a 6 per cent fall in seasonally adjusted imports, which is precisely what Government policies have been attempting to achieve. It should be noted that export earnings remained steady despite a fairly significant decline in wool receipts against last year's level. As I have said, there is some cause for optimism. Overall, the pattern in the figures is consistent with what was predicted at Budget time. Far from agreeing with what Senator Stone said earlier, what the Government's policies have been designed to deliver is a slow-down in demand without the short, sharp, shock routine-which usually turned into a long one under the previous three or four decades of coalition government rule-of bringing about a recession, forcing up unemployment and forcing those in the community least able to afford it to pay for the previous lack of any real appreciation of this problem.

There is a temptation to adopt some quick fix policy in this area and to say that monetary policy can be relaxed and interest rates lowered. No doubt, in accord with what Senator Stone said today, that is what the Opposition will attempt to do over the next six months. But six months is a long time. I have no doubt that, as we go through that period, the Government will be able to show the people that such a quick fix solution does not exist.

Senator Stone began by reciting a procession of figures and said that foreign debt is accruing at the rate of $40,000 per minute. I overheard this senior economic shadow spokesman for the Opposition and a backbencher discussing just what figures they might use that could best highlight, best distort, the real position but best give them some political hope. When Australia faces serious economic difficulties, such trite political treatment does not stand up. It is not good enough. The recitation of those figures by Senator Stone means nothing whatsoever. I have already been through the real figures of Australia's foreign debt and what it really means to Australians and the fact that 62 per cent of it-almost two-thirds-is private sector debt. We also hear today of Senator Stone's concern for home buyers. It must be a great relief to home buyers. They have not heard a great deal from Senator Stone about that over the years. In Senator Stone's previous life as a public servant, they did not get any joy out of him at all. But fortunately most of them remember and know what to expect from Senator Stone, and that is why they would not touch him with a barge pole.

To go past that, one has to look at what the alternatives are. What alternatives do the Opposition offer to the Government's policy settings? On fiscal policy the Opposition says that it supports and endorses the Government's tight stance. Of course, the Opposition has abandoned its previous commitment that it was going to tighten fiscal policy further. But given the Opposition's dismal record in fiscal policy in the previous Government, no-one would have believed that. It is on wages policy that we start to see just how threadbare Opposition alternatives really are. We have this great leap forward into enterprise bargaining overnight with no system above and around it; just this leap into the unknown. The Opposition's wages policy is going to do two things. Somehow it is going to produce lower aggregate wage outcomes than the accord does and, at the same time, it is going to produce better wage outcomes for individual workers. One cannot do one and do the other-and, of course, the Opposition has no intention of doing either. I am staggered that the Opposition learnt nothing from the years 1981 and 1982. That experiment in enterprise bargaining led to a massive blow-out in wages in Australia, one that the country could not afford. It could not afford it in 1981-82 and it will not be able to afford it in 1990-91.

What is left is monetary policy. This apparently is somehow going to be used by the coalition to eliminate inflation. I concede, Senator Stone, that the coalition could probably do it. If it got interest rates up to 25 per cent, it would stand half a chance. If the coalition had massive unemployment, a prolonged recession, it might do it. Of course, those are the tools to which Senator Stone and his predecessors have always had to resort. All the Opposition knows is to kick unemployment up and make a recession really hurt ordinary people. That has always been the way the coalition would go, and it is the way that any future government would go.

Of course, the coalition would not be the first to try it. Maggie Thatcher has had a go, and she has done really well with it! If one lives in the south of England, one is laughing; one has had a good few years. But if one lives in Glasgow, Birmingham or one of those other industrial cities, one has suffered dramatically. Unemployment has soared and the country has suffered greatly for it. But one also finds out that it does not work over time and that, as Mrs Thatcher has found out, five years later back comes inflation anyway. What can she do about it now? She tried sacking the Chancellor of the Exchequer. I am not sure that works either. In the end, no matter who is promoted or sacked, one just cannot do it.

What is worse is that this coalition and Senator Stone propose to abolish the capital gains tax for this so-called speculative gains tax. The only achievement of the Fraser years was, in the words of Costigan, to make tax avoidance the only industry that grew. But the Opposition is proposing now to do it all over again. The Opposition learnt nothing. It is all about returning billions of dollars into the pockets of the few. The Opposition always was and always will be. The accountants will be rubbing their hands with glee. The tax lawyers think it is marvellous. But one wonders what happens to Australia in the process.
What does the press-not the `socialist rags'-think of the Opposition? What does the Australian Financial Review say? It says:

The Opposition has created a political issue by proposing a weak and philosophically unconvincing proposition. Its policy response, instead of showing some fiscal spine, lacks any philosophic coherence . . .
The Australian states:
The Liberal Party's speculative gains tax plan has little inherent logic and encourages tax dodging.
The Sydney Morning Herald comments:
the policy gives an enormous windfall to around 1 per cent of Australia's richest taxpayers.

Is it any wonder that in the coalition party room, members of the shadow Ministry gather around telling each other how worried thay are about any suggestion that John Elliott will gain in a big way from this policy? The question is, if business generally, and big business in particular, gain out of this, just how much does one particular businessman gain? The fact is that he gains one hell of a lot. For all the criticisms about Labor enjoying any relationship with business, the Opposition still has to give an answer over the next six months as to just what it will do about John Elliott and that big windfall gain.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am always staggered when we engage in a debate in this place generated by the Opposition complaining about the economic performance of the Hawke Government. It is especially fascinating today when Senator Stone, the proposer of the matter of public importance before the Senate-which talks about the disastrous consequences of interest rates paid by home buyers, farmers and small businesses and the continuing lack of action by the Hawke Labor Government to deal effectively with the balance of payments and foreign debt crises-left himself one minute to provide a list of what his Party, which is putting itself forward at this very moment out in the community, proposes to do about those very problems. He had 20 minutes available to him in this debate. After 19 minutes of invective based on the proposal he has put before the Senate, in one minute he very hastily-with the orange light showing on the clock-rattled off a list of tax breaks, spending cuts, measures to restructure the labour market, deregulation and privatisation. That is the menu for the people of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to look at the economic debate in Australia. Here we have one brought on by Senator Stone, the spokes- person for finance in the proposed alternative government. On both sides of politics it is a debate which the Australian Democrats believe is myth driven. The same myths are used by the Government-which budgets for a $9 billion surplus, cuts welfare to the bone, deregulates everything in sight and even engages in the destruction of a trade union, casting in doubt the very right to strike in this nation-and, equally, by an Opposition which sheets home to the labour force all the blame for the economic ills of this country. According to all the wisdom on both sides, Australians are overtaxed, there is overspending at government level and Australians are overpaid. Those are the myths. They survive, I contend, largely because in our opportunistic and adversarial political system the experts, of whom we have heard much already in this debate, seldom let facts get in the way of a good argument.

I would like to look at those myths and establish some facts. The first myth is that Australians are overtaxed. On Senator Stone's hasty list was the proposition that the coalition would reduce taxation, on the heels of a government which has done that dramatically for the corporate sector-which was not even paying its 49 per cent tax rate anyway-and initially for the high income earners and, finally, for lower income earners, and proposes to do more for the higher income earners again.

The total overall tax paid as a percentage of gross domestic product (GDP) in Australia is in line with the average for similar industrial countries in a list including Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the United States of America and the United Kingdom. Our proportion of GDP is 31 per cent. We are sixth in a list of eight. So it seems that that is rather a hollow myth. On that list, the highest taxed are the French at 44.4 per cent and the lowest are the Japanese at 28.1 per cent, which is not dramatically below the 31 per cent of GDP that Australians pay in tax.

However, when looking at taxation statistics, it is worth noting that with respect to personal income tax we are top of the list at 45.6 per cent, especially when compared with the economies of Japan and Germany. But Australia's rate of tax on the corporate sector is quite low-well below that of Japan or even the United Kingdom. So the mix of taxation-and the failure of the corporate sector, even though it has been remarkably well treated by this Government-is a feature of our taxation system.

The second myth is that the Government overspends. Again, on Senator Stone's hasty list at the end of his speech, while the light was burning, was a promise that the Opposition would cut government spending. We need to remember, when trying to cast some light around this myth, that this Government produced a $9 billion surplus in this year's Budget and that public sector borrowing is virtually zero. However, I remark that I understand that New South Wales, under the premiership of Liberal Premier Greiner, is heading in the opposite direction with regard to public sector borrowing overseas. I am using 1986 figures here because they are the latest complete figures amongst the nations surveyed. As a percentage of GDP, Australia's spending comes out at 38.3 per cent. In the United Kingdom, under the dry economic bent of Maggie Thatcher, the figure is 49.5 per cent. In Japan it is 33.1 per cent and in the United States of America it is 36.9 per cent. The average for the seven major industrial economies is 40 per cent, compared with Australia's rate of 38.3 per cent, and the average for the nations of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development is 41 per cent. So that is another hollow myth.

We hear very often the bleat that Australian workers are overpaid and that the Opposition wants to deregulate the labour market and get rid of that problem. But is it a problem? Added to that myth should be the complaint that Australians do not work hard enough for all of the money they are paid. Let us look at that myth. I am looking at a survey of the Union Bank of Switzerland of earnings per hour, which is in common usage. I will take the figures for Sydney, even though it has the most highly paid work force in Australia. Those workers rank twenty-second in a selection of 52 world cities. The highest paid workers are those living in Zurich. Using as a base those workers in Zurich, who are paid $100 an hour, comparatively, in Los Angeles the figure is $72.10, in New York $67.90, in Tokyo $67.20, in London $57.90 and in Sydney, our highest paid city, $46.70. So that is another hollow myth.

Another complaint we hear in this myth-based economic debate is that welfare spending as a proportion of GDP in this country is the lowest of any industrialised nation. I stress that that has been reduced by the Hawke Labor Government, through its targeted welfare policies, from 6.3 per cent of GDP at the time of the Fraser Government to 6 per cent.

In these economic debates too little attention is paid to the real problems in this country. Perhaps the first problem is that all the decisions in this country are short term ones, whether made by governments or the private sector. Of course, we cannot have longer parliamentary terms. This Government put a proposal for that before the people of Australia-of course, it was a watered down proposition; this Government does not want a fixed term; the Prime Minister, whoever he is, always wants to have the final say-but the Opposition actively opposed it out in the community. In the private sector we have just had too much of a history of opportunistic corporate entrepreneurship in individual interests. That might change now that a few of them have fallen on their faces and they might not be the heroes of our society and our media much longer.

A second problem is that everybody blames everybody else for whatever goes wrong. Of course, we are having that in this debate. Somehow, perhaps, that is human nature. But I think the adversarial political system in this country is very much a measure of that and we will see a lot more of it before this year is over and into next year, I would submit, as we come into an election in which Tweedledum and Tweedledee will be desperately trying to persuade the electors that they are a little different from each other.

The last of the two serious problems should be linked. They are serious. As a nation we simply are not saving enough and hence investing enough local Australian money in our economy. Finally, the rent, interest and dividend outflows from foreign investment and foreign borrowings are hitting new and ever more glorious heights each year. They are serious problems. The Democrats actually agree with the Opposition's proposal that the Government has not acted in these areas sufficiently. But we ask the question: What about the Opposition?

The Democrats at least have had legislation before this Parliament to encourage savings through tax deductability on interest earned on savings accounts and to assist home buyers through the deductability of mortgage payments. The Opposition allowed its Leader, Mr Peacock, to fly kites on these issues in his mock election campaign earlier in the year. He was reined in. The Opposition rejected the Democrat moves in the Senate.

Then the tax package came from Mr Peacock. It simply presented a picture of increased social and economic polarisation and an increase in overseas indebtedness. The private sector now has its particular scare campaign running. It is not a mock election campaign any more. That scare campaign is focusing, as does this motion, on foreign debt. The private sector will have a summit next March. Sir Roderick Carnegie sought to reassure us all through the media during the last few days. He said, `We can do it. We have great confidence in this country'. It is always good to see confidence in this country. Sir Roderick said that we can get out of this foreign debt problem, that we did it in the 1890s, we did it in the 1930s and we can do it again.

But let us ask the question of Sir Roderick and of the Opposition and even of the Government: How did we do it in the 1890s and the 1930s? Is that the way that we will do it in 1990? We did it, of course, through depression. Perhaps for 1990 we should read `deep recession'. We did it through severe unemployment and great social deprivation. I want to add that our $9 billion surplus is not achieved without great and quite considerable social cost. In any case, cutbacks in government services have their own economic impact. The Democrats fear that Sir Roderick is right: both the Government and the alternative government appear headed in the direction of solving this problem a la the 1890s and 1930s.

The satisfaction of the Government and of the Opposition so far with our plateau of 6 per cent to 8 per cent unemployment in recent years is disturbing. The Government's toughness on unemployment benefits and further restrictions coming in in legislation that we will be dealing with in the next week or so are of concern. Of course, we are staring down the barrel of an Opposition which would remove unemployment benefits altogether for the long term unemployed in its proposed package. While deregulating the labour market, the strong will survive and the weak will fail. That is the way we are told we solve our problems-a chilling prospect.

The Democrats have other proposals. We have had them for a long time. First and, perhaps, foremost we should make those overseas borrowers contribute to this economy, particularly through removing the ability to negatively gear; discourage those imports at a luxury level; encourage savings-we have already had initiatives on that; allow enterprise and initiative to develop and encourage it in this country. Let us get some brain-based development in this country. There should be industrial democracy, not industrial chaos; appropriate regulation, not deregulation and privatisation for their own sake; and a change in attitude to surplus budgeting and welfare squeezing. Members of the Opposition will be out there trying to make the public believe that they are different, but I think the public is getting the picture now of Tweedledum and Tweedle-even-dumber. They have come together on tertiary taxes; they have come together on tax breaks for the wealthy; they have come together to concentrate ownership of the media; they have come together as birds of a feather; and they will continue to do that unless this community makes its feelings felt and looks for something different. The public opinion polls are showing that the community is doing that-looking for alternatives. We certainly need alternatives unless we are to sink severely into dire economic stress next year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I strongly support the matter of public importance brought on for debate by Senator Stone, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The disastrous consequences for interest rates paid by home buyers, farmers and small businesses of the continuing lack of action by the Hawke Labor government to deal effectively with the balance of payments and foreign debt crises.

There is no doubt that there is a crisis. I listened to Senator Richardson today. I would like to deal with some of the comments that he made. There is not much point in dealing with the comments that Senator Powell made; they are of the usual Democrats non-sensical variety, which makes it very hard to put one's finger on matters of substance, let alone establish any sort of coherent response to them. It is a blancmange of nonsense. The Australian Democrats, never having the requirement to be responsible because they will never be in power to do this, can say anything, and do say anything, no matter how irrational and nonsensical.

A major concern is the fact that Senator Richardson is not only a member of this Government but is the most senior New South Wales inner adviser of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke): he is his numbers man; he is the eminence grise-we can tell by looking at his hair-of this Government. This man, this senator, came into this chamber and spoke the most incredible nonsense, basically along the lines: `Don't worry, we know what we are doing. The Opposition doesn't'. He pursued the most incredible line: `Look, don't worry about the foreign debt. It is not the Government's fault; it is private enterprises'. He said, `Sixty-two per cent of Australia's external debt is theirs'-referring to the Business Council of Australia.

If Senator Richardson is so economically ignorant that he would make an assertion like that, we can understand why this Government has pushed Australia into such an economic crisis. The simple facts are these: our foreign debt does not emerge from someone like Skase or Bond running around the world borrowing money. It emerges from one very simple thing.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, only about 40 per cent.

—We hear again from the Australian Democrats the fairy at the bottom of the garden approach, as I think Senator Walsh keeps interjecting on this score. It does not emerge from them running around the world borrowing money. All that their borrowing does is alter the composition. It would be a good idea if Senator McLean could receive a little lesson in economics.
—But 60 per cent--

—If the honourable senator would be kind enough to listen, he would learn. Their borrowings simply alter the composition of the debt we face in the world; it does not alter its total. The Democrats have never been able to comprehend this because, frankly, it does not suit them politically to think about it. The reality is that we go broke every month-by $2.3 billion in the latest month-not because someone has rushed overseas to borrow money, but because Australia's total exports have not matched its total imports and its borrowing costs from overseas. In other words, like any family-certainly any family under this Government-we are not earning enough to pay our way. As a result, every month we as a nation have to borrow more from overseas to pay our bills. All that Mr Skase and Mr Bond have done is change the composition of that borrowing, because that borrowing otherwise would have to come into our money markets.

SPEECH.PARA: When we sell goods overseas we earn foreign currency; when we buy goods from overseas we have to buy foreign currency. If we are not earning enough we have to keep buying at a higher and higher price. The simple fact is that we are not exporting enough. As a result, as a nation suffering from the Government's economic policies, we face a disaster. In the latest month, $2.3 billion is our current account deficit. Basically, we have to borrow that money. For people like Senator Richardson to maintain what appears to be a central plank of the Labor Party's policy is to maintain the big lie. It is false for the Government to pretend that our massive deficit has nothing to do with our hopeless economic policies; it is a direct consequence of them. Every observer recognises that to be true.

The consequence is that the Government must slow down the economy. It has admitted that, so it must have some sense of responsibility even if it does not know how to act properly to resolve the problems. The Government recognises that it must keep interest rates high; it is doing nothing else to try to resolve this terrible problem. That is why it has a tight monetary policy. That is why it pretends it has a tight fiscal policy; it knows it is responsible for the balance of payments deficit. That is why it keeps talking about the need for things such as high interest rates. If it was not its problem, why does it bother to have high interest rates? Why is it talking about the need for tight fiscal policies? Why do its Budget Papers even mention the need to resolve the balance of payments problem? It cannot have it both ways.

The major disaster with the balance of payments and the current account deficit has meant that Australians will continue to face the massive interest rates that have forced so many farmers and businesses to the wall and so many Australians out of their homes. Interest rates will remain high, despite the Government's mouthings of promises that interest rates will soon fall. Such promises have been made continually by the Prime Minister. Basically, immediately we hear the Prime Minister say that interest rates will fall, we know that there will be a rise, because it has happened every time.

I turn to a consideration of the consequences to Australia of the massive balance of payments deficits in the last few months. One newspaper heading today is, `Near record deficit throws doubt on Keating's forecasts'. There is nothing new about that. Keating's forecasts on this matter have always been ludicrous. Another heading is, `BoP: Government snuffs rate hopes'; it is referring to the balance of payments and interest rate hopes. Another newspaper heading is, `$2.2bn deficit will keep rates high'; the `rates' referred to are interest rates. Another such heading is, `Government confronts its debt dilemma'. That is right. However, we do not know what policies the Government has to resolve its problems. The coalition has put out its policy, one that has been widely discussed over the last two months, despite Senator Powell's ludicrous comment that only one minute of Senator Stone's 20-minute speech was addressed to it. The Opposition has put its money where its mouth is. It has said, `This is the way to fix it'. We are still waiting for the Government to come out with any kind of policy, even an incoherent one.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have been waiting since the last election.

—Indeed. We do not know what the Government will do and neither does the Government. Mr Hawke has written a letter asking people for ideas and saying, `Please, chaps, can you think of a good way to get us out of this mess?'. Let us hope somebody writes back to him before the election which, I understand from Senator Richardson, looks like being in May, as he said that the Opposition has six months to sell its policies.

The interest rates paid by home buyers, pharmacists and small businesses are the disastrous consequences of the continuing lack of action by the Hawke Labor Government to deal effectively with the balance of payments and foreign debt crisis. Yesterday, 42,000 people signed a petition which was presented to the House of Representatives. Forty-two thousand people in South Australia are on the public housing waiting list, which has doubled under the Hawke Government and, coincidentally, under the Bannon Government because they have been in harness. Not only have they been in harness but also Mr Bannon, the Premier of South Australia, is the Federal President of the Australian Labor Party.
