SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beahan Sen M.E. .

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not argue that Australia's balance of payments situation is not a problem. Of course it is a problem. But it is a lot more complex than Senator Michael Baume, Senator Stone or Senator Powell seems to believe, despite the histrionics that accompanied each of their speeches. It is not all bad news, but I will come to that later. I am appalled at the propensity of the Senator Stones, the Peacocks and the Hewsons of this world constantly to attempt to talk down the economy. That is not in the interests of Australia as a whole. They seem to have little interest in the well-being of the Australian people or, for that matter, the Australian economy. Senator Stone and others want to talk down the economy for purely political ends, as has been made clear by all opposition speakers so far. They have raised this matter for debate purely because there is an election tomorrow in South Australia and there will be an election in Queensland the week after. There is more concern about these elections than about the impact of interest rates on ordinary Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: I am also constantly amazed at what I can only call the unmitigated gall of the Opposition, and particularly of Senator Stone, when one considers, firstly, the record of conservative parties when they have been in government and, secondly, the current policies of the Opposition in relation to the economy. The Opposition's record is important for two reasons. Firstly, as the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) has already pointed out, conservative governments have governed for 30 of the last 40 years. They were in office when many of the current problems developed. They were the cause of many of the problems of distortion within the economy with which this Government is grappling.

The second reason it is important to talk about the Opposition's record, is that it says a great deal about the character of the conservative mind. Let us look briefly at this record. Many of the distortions, as I have said, first appeared during the Menzies-McEwen era. While Senator Richardson briefly alluded to this, I will deal with it in a little more detail. At that time Australia was seen as the lucky country, rich in resources, with vast areas of land and almost limitless capacity, it seemed. This led to a sort of cargo cult mentality that we would always produce enough and that a sleepy Australia did not have to worry about what was happening in the rest of the world and particularly in our immediate region of South East Asia. This was the period in which we developed many of the bad habits which are now presenting as problems-bad habits such as over-protection, not facing the realities of a competitive world, bad work practices which we have been attempting to overcome not only through award restructuring but also through a whole range of other initiatives, bad management practices and unwieldly structures generally. While the Fraser Government generally was certainly more aware of the problems, it still did nothing to correct them.

I remind honourable senators of the report of the Jackson Committee to Advise on Policies for Manufacturing Industry which was delivered in 1975 towards the end of the Whitlam Government's term and was ready to be acted upon by the Fraser Government when it took office. That report was headed Policies for Development of Manufacturing Industry. The report was a stinging indictment of management practices in Australia. It did not criticise unions; it criticised management. No action was taken about that. I remind honourable senators of the report in 1981 of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System. It recommended deregulation of the financial market. Again, no action was taken. The conservatives backed off.

Senator Button referred yesterday to the 1977 Industries Assistance Commission report which recommended a general reduction in tariffs. Again, nothing was done about that. I remind honourable senators of a point raised by Senator Button yesterday: tariffs have been reduced since 1972 by 65 percentage points and not one percentage point is attributable to a conservative government. Labor has had to take the burden of all the change not only in that area but in almost every other area. The conservatives talk a lot about micro-economic reform but they did nothing. They did nothing about the waterfront, air transport, award restructuring or work or management practices. We have tackled all of those things. I am not suggesting that all of our initiatives have worked equally well or that we have finished the task of restructuring the economy, but at least we have had the fortitude to have a go.

If there is one thing that has characterised the Opposition over these years it is a lack of courage. Nothing has changed. Despite carping and consistent criticism of the Government's tight monetary policy, for example-and it is repeated in this proposal-the so-called Economic Action Plan, which I think Senator Button more accurately described as the `Fosters' family package', does nothing to change macro-economic policy. In fact, it is more notable for what it is not than for what it is. It is not, for example, about inflation adjustment, despite Mr Peacock's commitment to this just a few months ago. The one area on which I must agree with Senator Michael Baume is that the Australian Democrats' solution to this and other problems is gobbledegook and nonsense. Their idea of inflation adjustment for interest on individual savings is a nonsense which simply distorts the financial system without achieving anything. It is easy for the Democrats to come up with these sorts of solutions because, as Senator Baume says, they do not ever have to face the responsibility of government, so they never have to implement the silly ideas that they project.

The Economic Action Plan is not about wages. There is no explanation of how a conservative government would control the radical changes-and they are radical changes-involved in abolishing the centralised wage-fixing system and replacing it with enterprise bargaining and individual contracts. It is not about the new tax scales which Peacock has frequently promised, although there is a vague and uncosted reference to reducing the top marginal tax rate from 49 per cent to 39 per cent, thus making the tax system less progressive and therefore less fair.

It is not about, as I said initially, macro-economic policy and this is not just my idea. I quote from an article on page 13 of the Melbourne Age of 13 October by Ken Davidson. In the opening two paragraphs of the article he says:
The coalition expenditure/tax document makes no attempt to offer a different budgetary and monetary strategy to that now being offered by the Hawke-Keating Government.

Despite the pious noises about the creation of a more productive and fairer Australia, the document in reality offers an alternative budget for 1989-90 which has, for all practical purposes, the same bottom line in the form of a surplus, excluding asset sales, of about $8 billion.

So it is not in any sense an economic plan or a tax plan. It is in fact a cynical political document designed to play on the prejudices of some Australians by attacking the long term unemployed, education leavers, newly-arrived migrants, Aborigines, invalid pensioners, sole parents, and single income earners. It takes Australia back to a new dark age of inequality, social division and deprivation. It takes from those in greatest need and gives to the wealthy and those on two incomes who are comfortably well off. As Ken Davidson comments, it is a crude Robin Hood in reverse.

Far from taking the opportunity to set up some grand design to reshape the Australian economy, Senator Stone has participated-it ought to be noted that he is a key member of the Opposition team, the so-called kitchen cabinet that has put this package together-in putting together a traditional political grab bag of handouts and, like all previous coalition fistfuls of dollars, the package was not adequately costed and cannot be funded from the savings measures described. This is not the hard-headed, disciplined, fiscally responsible, economically rational former Treasury head that we all love and respect; it is more like that meretricious player that he so disdainfully rejected-John Hewson. The Opposition's package demonstrates the same lack of courage. The Australian Financial Review of 25 October 1989 refers to the Opposition as follows:
. . . proposing a weak and philosophically unconvincing proposition. Its policy response, instead of showing some fiscal spine, lacks any philosophic coherence . . .

It shows the same spinelessness and the same lack of courage. The important fact in this debate is that the Economic Action Plan explicitly states that monetary policy would be used at at least the same level as currently to reduce inflation. This means support for high interest rates. How the Opposition has the gall to debate this when its own policy statement put out as recently as a couple of weeks ago says that it has the same prescription to retain high levels of interest rates, to dampen demand and reduce inflation, beats me. We must add to this first the unfunded promises implicit in the statement and second the severe doubts about the accuracy of costings. The Department of Finance costed the savings at $615m compared with the savings in the document of $1,149m. Thirdly, there is the inevitable policy making and additional spending which will be promised in the run-up to an election. The result will be less scope to manoeuvre and a high probability that Dr Hewson and Senator Stone will have to engineer a recession through even higher interest rates to create the climate they need for the labour market deregulation which they are so fond of. It will be 1982 all over again with inflation high, unemployment high, in double digit figures, negative growth and a wages blow-out. We do not think that Australia needs that prescription.

Having failed hopelessly to offer an alternative economic strategy, Senator Stone and his colleagues try to talk down the economy. They totally ignore the positive elements in this week's balance of payments statement. They ignore for example the fact that it represents a 14 per cent fall in the seasonally adjusted deficit; that it contains a significant indication of export diversification, which we have been aiming at and working hard for and which is now happening; that it contains a welcome fall in seasonally adjusted imports; and that it demonstrates continued evidence of investment imports to feed the investment boom that is at a 40-year high-higher than anything the Opposition was ever able to achieve. Even the shadow Treasurer, Dr Hewson, finally acknowledged this in an interview on The World Today on Thursday, 23 November. It is also worthy of note that markets have generally received the current account figures quite favourably. There is a broad consensus out there in the market that the figures for the year are unfolding as expected at Budget time; that is, that they will peak in the early part of the year and improve in the second half.

Finally, in the few minutes I have left, I would like to look at the nature of the debt because a lot of simplistic nonsense is talked about it. It is not mainly public debt; it is mainly private debt-62 per cent of the debt is private debt. The net public sector borrowing requirement of the Federal Government is zero. In fact, we are net lenders, not net borrowers. We cannot, therefore, compare ourselves, as the Opposition likes to do, with South American countries whose level of sovereign debt-that is, public debt for things such as health, welfare, roads and so forth-is as high as 80 per cent of gross domestic product. As Senator Richardson has already pointed out, our debt is around the level of 32 per cent of GDP. It is over 60 per cent private in any case, and in most cases it is well geared so that it will be repaid. That is why the finance people are not so worried about it. It is a reducing debt also. As has already been indicated, that 32 per cent is a reducing amount. So there is no way in which we can compare ourselves with South American countries or with the sorts of difficulties that those countries face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the few minutes remaining I want to pick up some of the points that have been made by speakers on the Government side-Senator Richardson and Senator Beahan-in emphasising the significance of the matter of public importance that has been submitted to the Senate today by Senator Stone on behalf of the Opposition, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The disastrous consequences for interest rates paid by home buyers, farmers and small businesses of the continuing lack of action by the Hawke Labor Government to deal effectively with the balance of payments and foreign debt crises.

Earlier this week in the other place, in a debate on interest rates the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) made the very accurate observation that this Government has developed a policy paralysis. There are no answers to questions about interest rates. We had that confirmed to us today, par excellence, by Senator Button during Question Time, and I am pleased to see that Senator Button is at the table. There is virtually no movement on micro-economic reform, despite the much vaunted promises at the last election that this would be the Parliament of micro-economic reform. Increasingly, few policy decisions are being taken that have any rational economic coherence about them at all.

We are seeing a government that is living at the moment very much on the basis of the politics of the big lie and the politics of the quick fix. We just have to look at the decisions that have been made in relation to Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd, Coronation Hill, and the banks-subsidising their interest rates policy-to name but three of the more notable ones, to see what disarray this Government's economic policy making is in at the moment. That is the reason we have brought forward this matter of public importance today in the Senate. That is why every economic commentator around the place is expressing increasing concern about our balance of payments situation, the level of our national debt and the implications that that will have not just for the living standards of Australians today but for the living standards of our kids, our grandchildren and future generations.

The debt we are building up in this country, which is increasing at the rate of $2 billion per month, is a debt that future generations will have to deal with. It is a totally unsustainable debt which, if it is not brought under control in the very near future, will sink this nation in terms of the living standards of every Australian. Yet the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) addressed his Caucus earlier this week and said that our debt problem was not a crisis. That is the problem facing this country. We have a government led by a Prime Minister who does not realise that the debt that is accumulating externally at the rate of $2 billion a month is a serious problem. He says that we do not have a crisis. I have news for the Prime Minister: everyone else in Australia believes that we have a crisis. Virtually every commentator not only in Australia but increasingly around the world believes it. If one wants a very good description of what is happening and the attitude of this Government one can do no better than read from the Macquarie Bank's summary of Australia's economic challenge, the summary released the other day, which talks about the boiling frog syndrome. It says:
Throw a frog into a pot of very hot water and it will immediately jump out. No frog in its right mind wants to be cooked.
Place a frog into a pot of cold water, on the other hand, and it will usually stay there. Then, as you slowly turn up the heat, the frog acclimatises to the changing temperature and stays put.

As the water gets warmer, the frog remains unconcerned-it will sit there indefinitely saying, in effect, `she'll be right, mate'' . . . as the water gets hotter and hotter . . . until the poor old frog is boiled.

That is absolutely what is happening to this country under the policies of this Government. Let me pick up two of the fundamental points that were made by Senator Richardson and, very surprisingly, parroted by Senator Beahan today. They are part of the politics of the big lie that we have heard non-stop from the Government in recent years. We remember the Prime Minister's policy speech that by 1990 no child will live in poverty, interest rates will fall and, the beauty of all beauties the other day, that the pilots dispute is over.

One of the problems of the politics of the political lie is that it undermines the understanding that people have of the economic situation. We saw that today when Senator Richardson, followed as I said by Senator Beahan, said that the private sector accounts for 62 per cent of Australia's external debt. His whole approach was that the Government has no involvement in or responsibility for this, that it is not the Government's problem. That is a line that I have heard peddled by other Government spokesmen in recent months, including, notably, the Treasurer (Mr Keating). All that demonstrates is just how pathetically little the Treasurer and other Government spokesmen understand about economics. Obviously, the Treasurer has no understanding at all about the impact of government policies on the private sector.

Several points have to be made to show the real situation. The first one is that the Government's policies of disastrous economic mismanagement have led to a record high level of domestic interest rates in Australia. The second point follows from that: interest rates to commercial borrowers within Australia are twice or more times as high as they are in many other capital markets around the world, for example, in the United States and Japan, where rates are single digit figures. Here commercial rates are 20 per cent plus. The third point is that as a result of that it is not only inevitable but nothing more than sound business practice that if Australian companies have a need to borrow then those that are able to do so will look overseas for that borrowing. The alternative is to borrow within Australia at the crippling-high interest rates prevailing here as a result of deliberate government policies. If they borrow in Australia they will thereby jeopardise the viability of their businesses and, in many instances, their very livelihoods.

As to the fourth point in relation to this matter, I marvel at the rampant hypocrisy in the Government's implication that somehow or other the private sector is harming the economy with its overseas borrowing. It is hypocritical because the Government positively wants the private sector to borrow externally in order to prop up the value of the Australian dollar. The Government's whole economic strategy is based around this very point. If the private sector was not borrowing overseas, then the Government's whole economic strategy would be blown even further out of the water unless the Government took over the foreign borrowing role. If it did not take over that foreign borrowing role, then the Australian dollar would plummet in value. That would in turn feed heavy additional inflationary pressures into an already far too inflationary environment. The only solution to that situation would be to adopt the policies that the Opposition has been pursuing publicly for a long time now. They are now encapsulated in the Economic Action Plan of the Opposition. They involve a balanced mix of policies which are essential for the operation of this country.
